PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: DOBIE; FREE; HICKS; KLUGMAN; LUSHER; MACKELLAR
PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Sex Discrimination Legislation

To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities, for example, boys cricket team, boys football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie,Mr Free,Mr Hicks,Dr Klugman,Mr Lusher and Mr MacKellar.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth: that Regulations and an Ordinance now before the Parliament amend the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs ( Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the ACT Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law:
the power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (for example, X-rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
the power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
the power to require imported video tapes/discos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Film Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure:
that the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
that Censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes;
that further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Burr,Mr Groom,Mr MacKellar and Mr Leo McLeay.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Cross and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Generic Drug Names
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That there are far too many prescription drugs available and that abuse of these constitutes a serious problem.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-
1. That all drugs shall be prescribed and supplied by their approved (GENERIC) names only. Trade (Brand) names will not be used in any circumstances.
2. That information concerning possible side-effects of all drugs must be made as freely available as the drugs themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South
PETITION.PARA: Wales
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/ or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words 'Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, parents and teachers working for and in the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia, respectfully showeth that:
We support the Federal Government's determination to restore the community's confidence in public education.

We support the Federal Government's opposition to base grants to all non government schools (a) by reducing funds to those schools already operating above community standards and (b) funding other schools according to need.
We support the Federal Government's policy of negotiations and planning with State/Territory Governments regarding joint programs for improvements in Government schools in the next decade.
1. We ask that the Federal Government increase current funding for Government schools as promised.
2. We ask that the Federal Government provide promised funding for special programs to assist primary children with learning difficulties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Curfew
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show:

That the potential noise hazard to residents of Sandgate, Shorncliffe, Brighton and Nudgee Beach (including 4,000 aged people), will become intolerable when the new Brisbane Airport is operative in 1987, if protective action is not taken.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will, when the redevelopment of the Brisbane Airport becomes operative, ensure that:
(1) No jet aircraft use the 32'14' crosswind runway;
(2) The Department maintain the curfew on the runway from 10.00 p.m. to 6.00 a. m.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Rebate List: Infertility Treatment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain Citizens of Australia shows-that at present, certain infertility treatments including; Hormonal Drugs, Procedures and Laboratory Services, are not covered by any Health Insurance due to Non-Itemisation on the Commonwealth Rebate List. The pyschological and emotional stress of infertility is therefore increased by the added financial stress.

Your Petitioners therefore pray, that the Parliament will view our plight to create life with sympathy, by recognising our needs, and taking action to include the abovementioned items on the Commonwealth Rebate List.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia , namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation 's historical origin, and the source of its language and law
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable house will: Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. the Hawke Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements; and
2. the Government's proposed assets test legislation, presently under re- examination, is iniquitous and if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Government to:
1. totally abandon its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad inquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter, and;
3. following the report of such a wide inquiry, institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory Finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of Medicare has not resulted in a cheaper, fairer system of health care as promised by the Federal Government.
Rather, it is an expensive, bureaucratic scheme, depersonalising medical services and conducive to medical mediocrity.
While recognising the responsibility which exists to assist those in need, we humbly request the Government to review this system which moves towards the nationalisation of Australian medicine.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross,Mrs Darling,Mr Moore and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectively showeth that :
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin and Mr Howard.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of concerned people of the Electorate of Indi respectfully show their desire to stop the spread of Paterson's Curse.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House (the Government) act to implement the biological control of Paterson's Curse.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron and Mr Lusher.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debit Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth our concern over the continuing taxation of Parents' Club bank accounts by way of the Bank Account Debit Tax.
Your petitioners therefore pray that-

Parent clubs being set up by Government Regulation in the State of Victoria ( Regulation XLII) be recognised by the Australian Government as education auxiliaries, in the same way as are School Councils.
The Treasurer move immediately to exempt Parent Clubs from the tax in the same way as are School Councils.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Governments in Australia shows that:
General Revenue Grants to Local Government under Personal Income Tax Sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on Local Governments Authorities to participate in Federal Government programs for example Community Employment Program.
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in General Revenue Grants to Local Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to Local Government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bills were returned from the Senate without amendment or requests :
Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1983
Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1984
[COGNATE BILL:
PIG MEAT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1984]
Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the House rose last night, no adjournment debate having been allowed, as is now usual with this Government, we were discussing the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill and the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill. I had been referring to the importance of the pig meat industry and the fact that Australia had natural advantages which could help the pig industry be a more significant export industry than it is at present. I also pointed out that the lack of a plant variety rights scheme in Australia had reduced that export ability because, without that incentive for greater investment by private firms in feed grain yield development, our feed grain industry perhaps had not progressed in the production of feed for the pig industry, and for that matter I suppose the chicken industry, to the same extent as the industries of some of our competitors in other countries. Another negative point in developing the pig meat industry as an export industry is our bad reputation as a supplier to world markets because of our industrial relations record. The tally system which operates in most abattoirs in Australia is also a major deterrent to efficiency in the meat industry. But the greatest difficulty is in the area of inspection services.

SPEECH.PARA: The inspection services at present are no longer appropriate. The time taken by the Government to make the appropriate changes illustrates the attitude of this Government in not giving a high priority to taking action to implement efficiency reforms in the inspection system. An example of this is the Mayfair Hams and Bacon Co. abattoir and processing works at Bendigo in Victoria. Until January 1984 this works, which employs 300 to 400 people and processes 5,000 to 6,000 pigs a week, exported more than $2m in meat products. The Victorian Government was charging $400,000 a year for its inspection services which consisted of one inspector and two staff to apply stamps to carcasses. I make the point in passing that it is not only at the Commonwealth level that there are problems with charges for inspection services. Under its new scale of fees, the Federal Government was charging more than $500,000 for 21 inspectors and a veterinary officer. For profit reasons, Mayfair was forced to forfeit its export licence following the dramatically increased charges by the Commonwealth. Of course, that saved it more than $500,000 in Federal levies and, at the same time , stopped all exports from Bendigo.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The matter raised by the honourable member is totally irrelevant to the Bills before the House.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It improved the profitability of Mayfair but reduced exports by more than $2m a year and reduced employment in Bendigo by 50 people including government inspection staff. The State Government then had to employ about seven new staff to do the job it already had been charging Mayfair to do. I hope that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is having urgent discussions with his State counterparts to ensure that, where pork is used only on the domestic market but killed at export registered works, only the domestic fee is payable, particularly in the case of Victoria, which now charges less than the dramatically increased Federal fee. It seems wrong and absurd that last year the total inspection cost for pork producers was $5.9m and the total value of exports was $4.1m. One can see from that that the pork producers of Australia have a legitimate grievance. I call on the Minister to take urgent action on what is, on the information given to the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh), the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, rather an absurd situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw the attention of the House to the fact that, notwithstanding the request of the industry to have the research levy increased from 10 cents per head to 15 cents per head, the Minister has flatly rejected that increase. The reserves, as indicated in the last report, which was presented to Parliament recently, have almost run out and the present levy will generate only $800,000 of the $1.2m required to maintain the existing level of research. I submit it is necessary to have more research. We have researchers of world renown in Australia, especially in nutrition and animal welfare. The Government, which seems to be able to find millions of dollars for its pet socialist theories, evidently cannot find the extra dollar for dollar money for this important matter of pork meat research, but would rather see a cut of 33 per cent in funds in real terms. There is a desperate need for a rise in the levy and the industry as yet has not received the answer to its last approach, made about two months ago. I therefore ask the Minister to give very serious consideration to increasing the levy.

I also draw the Minister's attention to another problem in the pig industry which is of increasing concern to the producers, that is, the changes that are taking place in the marketing structure within the industry which are leading to increased vertical integration and reducing the opportunity for independent family operated smaller producers to have a genuine market for their pigs. There is already a closer involvement of feed companies, usually overseas owned, in the production of pork in Australia than is the case in the United States of America or Canada. Now there is the additional concentration of independent wholesalers being taken over by those companies or leaving the industry. This is reducing the ability for a genuine market in pig meat-that is, an open market with declared prices, et cetera-with fewer open market buyers and increasing direct selling from the feed company without the wholesaler or from the wholesaler, as part of the feed company, to the supermarket. There is a need for some form of weekly independently set price indicator or some other mechanism to sustain an open price and a genuine market for pig meat products and for independent producers to have a future through the retention of some form of open market.

I turn to the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill, which corrects what the chicken meat industry sees as a minor anomaly in the original Chicken Meat Research Act 1969. The principal Act established a joint Commonwealth-industry research scheme in which the Commonwealth matched dollar for dollar a research levy imposed on hatched meat chickens. The Opposition accepts that the original Act is somewhat inflexible in that, whilst the levy receipts were on a dollar for dollar basis with the Commonwealth, other receipts from the sale of assets or receipts from research projects, et cetera, were not. This, of course, includes penalties for late payment of the research levy. This led to a situation in which access to the unmatched reserves was restricted by the need to exhaust the matched funds first. People familiar with the industry, as I am sure you are, Mr Speaker, will know that this is something which normally did not occur because of the regular receipt of the levy.

The Opposition applauds the fact that this Bill establishes two separate accounts within the research scheme trust account-one to cover funds matched by the Commonwealth and the other for unmatched funds. The Australian Chicken Meat Federation, which represents growers, processors, stock feed manufacturers, breeders, hatchery men and service industries associated with chicken meat production, believes the new arrangements will provide greater flexibility in meeting research funding requirements. The Opposition does not oppose the Bills, but it must be said in conclusion that it is good to see the Minister finally beginning to consult with industry on matters affecting his portfolio. I hope that he will continue to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill and the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill. The purpose of the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill is to amend the Chicken Meat Research Act 1969 in order to facilitate the use of funds for research. The 1969 Act established a joint Commonwealth-industry research scheme for the chicken meat industry. The Act provided for a trust account and an Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee which would make recommendations concerning expenditure from the fund. Moneys from the trust account are to be used for scientific, economic or technical research into the chicken meat industry. Funds for the research scheme are raised by a levy on meat chicken hatchings with the Government providing a matching contribution on a dollar for dollar basis. As has been noted already, the amendments in the Bill are of a minor nature. They are aimed at facilitating the use of funds for research. The principal amendment is to provide for two separate accounts within the trust account. The provision applies to a number of other research committees already.

SPEECH.PARA: Chicken meat represents more than 90 per cent of all poultry consumed in Australia. During 1983 the average Australian consumed approximately 19 kilograms of poultry meat which represented some 20 per cent of total meat consumption. Estimates and projections for the poultry meat industry contained in the February 1984 quarterly review of the rural economy indicate that by 1987 Australians will consume an average 21.4 kilograms of poultry per person, representing a market share for poultry of 23.1 per cent. Of course, that is an expected increase on the existing share of approximately 20 per cent.

The growth of the chicken meat industry is impressive when one considers that it is only a number of years ago that the industry was established on a single commodity item, the frozen chicken. The next commodity produced was fresh whole chicken. Following that, we have seen a large range of cut up chicken products which have been packed in a variety of ways. As the industry grew so the range of products has also grown and the variety of products offered still continues to increase. Various processes now offer a complete range of products from the frozen whole chicken to chicken pieces, tray packs, small goods, smoked chicken, pre-packed heat and serve products and even, in some supermarkets now, pre- stuffed chickens.

There is no doubt that one of the greatest advantages of chicken meat is its constant quality. The product is grown under rigorous health, husbandry and nutrition regimes to a given weight, and processed under controlled conditions. An even quality product for the consumer is always ensured. The evenness of product quality has assisted enormously in the take-away food business where factors such as the strict weight, quality and size specifications must be maintained. Funds allocated over many years for chicken research have undoubtedly assisted in ensuring the high quality product that is available today on the market.

The poultry meat industry, through the Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee, continues to support research in a number of areas and at a number of institutions. The majority of those research funds are allocated to disease research with nutrition the second most supported discipline. The 1982-83 annual report of the Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee, which was tabled in Parliament during March, shows that expenditure from the trust account to the year ended 30 June totalled some $446,000. Of that, net research accounted for $ 430,000 which was supporting 24 new and 17 continuing projects. The Commonwealth contribution towards those projects was some $218,000. In addition to the major research undertaken in the areas of disease and nutrition, the Meat Research Committee also funds research into physiology and genetics, management and behaviour, public health and meat quality. There is no doubt in my mind that the Committee makes a substantial contribution to the improved quality and production of chicken meat in Australia.

There are a number of producers of chicken meat within my electorate of Bendigo and each of them makes a significant contribution to the local economy and to the generation of jobs within the area. They are all well run efficient enterprises. The proprietors have a very good appreciation of the value of the research work undertaken by the Committee as well as an appreciation and understanding of some of the concerns which have been expressed about aspects of the industry, particularly aspects such as animal welfare.

The question of feed costs is one which has concerned producers in my area for some time. The cost of feed will always be of major significance in the profitability of the poultry meat industry. Honourable members with an interest in that area will of course remember well the high cost of feed ingredients, particularly wheat, in late 1982 and 1983. Many would know that the poultry industry complained strongly, and perhaps in many cases even bitterly, about what it saw as its effective subsidisation of drought fodder subsidy schemes. I certainly received many similar representations from producers in my area and obviously made very strong representations to the Government on that question of drought fodder subsidy relief. But 1984 is quite a different year from 1982 and 1983. There are significant quantities of rain affected wheat throughout Victoria and the eastern States and this should prove very suitable and priced appropriately for true stock feed wheat.

It is pleasing to see that in the industry paper presented at the recent Outlook Conference it was noted that the preparedness of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to discuss the recommendations of the Standing Committee arising from the Industries Assistance Commission report on the wheat industry with both the stock feed and poultry industries, prior to final recommendations being taken to the Australian Agricultural Council, was described at the Conference as both heartening and timely. The view expressed at that Conference confirms again the very good support for and the very popular vein in which the Minister for Primary Industry is perceived and accepted by primary producer groups throughout Australia. As I indicated previously, there is no doubt that the Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee continues to make a very substantial contribution to the production of chicken meat in Australia and I strongly support the amendments in the Bill before the House.

I wish also to make some brief comments on the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill. This Bill seeks to amend the Pig Meat Promotion Act 1975 and it also makes a consequential amendment to the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971. Other changes in the legislation give the Pig Meat Promotion Committee the power to administer funds and change the name of the Committee to the Pork Promotion Committee. The Bill also makes a number of lesser changes of a machinery nature to the legislation. The 1982-83 report of the Pig Meat Promotion Committee describes in good detail the general promotional activities undertaken by that Committee during the year. The report shows that $2,601,000 was spent from the Pig Meat Promotion Committee trust account during 1982-83. That was a significant increase in expenditure over the amount spent in 1981-82. The report also notes that the promotion of fresh pork in particular continued during 1982-83 with emphasis being placed on new fashion pork. That is a promotional term which has been used to describe a range of mainly fat trimmed and boneless pork cuts. Television was one of the major advertising mediums used.

In late May and early June last year there was an important addition to the promotion of fresh pork in that a campaign promoting all cuts of fresh pork was mounted. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), touched on a number of aspects of that campaign. The Committee also spent a substantial amount of money during the year on market research. Its report notes that further consumer research will be carried out during the year. As in any industry, it is important that that research be carried out so that producers are able to meet the needs of consumers in the market. That research will be important in providing the way ahead for producers in the type of product they ought to be marketing.

I refer briefly to a related matter. I note with interest and some pleasure that the Federal Government funds a number of research projects in the industry. I am pleased that $11,000 has been granted to a research project presently being undertaken by the Division of Animal Health in the Department of Agriculture in my electorate of Bendigo in Victoria. That research is looking at the treatment and control of enzootic pneumonia. That is valuable research for the industry. I was pleased again to see in the report of the Promotion Committee that my electorate of Bendigo has done fairly well in terms of the funds it receives from that Committee. Indeed the Committee allocated funds last year for the promotion and organisation of the national pig fair, which was held at Bendigo.

I should like to raise two more matters before I conclude my remarks on this legislation. One aspect which has been mentioned in the debate is the question of industry trends and pricing. I note from a recent edition of National Farmer that the Pork Promotion Centre, with funding from the pig levy, will from now on be making its own monthly survey of pig industry trends. The centre is determining at the moment a sample of 400 producers whose farms represent a typical cross-section of Australia's pig industry. Every month those farmers will be phoned and asked to report their production levels, their stock movements, their expansion or contraction intentions, and regional price movements. All of that information will then be fed into computers, where it will be available to industry both intrastate and interstate. Again, that will be a valuable aid to the industry for long term forecasting.

I conclude by commenting that when one is talking about pig legislation one is reminded of the Orwell novel Animal Farm. Indeed, I think a number of members may have seen the animated version of Animal Farm shown last Saturday night on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television. There is a message in Animal Farm, and I certainly enjoyed seeing it. I guess it is relevant in a sense to this legislation because when one thinks of pigs one thinks of animal farms. Many of us serve in this place in an endeavour to build a better and fairer nation, a nation which is more concerned with those less fortunate people in the community. However, we have to be wary that, in so doing, we do not allow our own living standards and styles to rise to such a level that we are living in some luxury and fail to provide for those who are in much greater need. I think that is an important message from Animal Farm. The Bills are fairly straightforward and I commend them to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow an amendment to the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the marketing of all meat products is interconnected and calls on the Government to aggressively support the marketing of Australian meats'.

Whilst we are dealing with narrow matters in respect of what are termed white meat industries, I wish to say something about the problems of the red meat industry and the way that these industries are interrelated. Indeed, the white meat industries-the pig and chicken meat industries-will be dramatically affected by the total situation in regard to meat products.

I have statistics which indicate that it is traditional that all meat products are interrelated in terms of sale. Irrespective of whether one is talking about cuts of beef, pork, chicken or sheep, the total meat products that are available on the Australian market are interrelated. For instance, if the prices in one area, perhaps in pig meats are high, consumer preferences shift to other forms of meat products. If beef prices are high due to drought or shortage, of course consumer preferences within Australia shift to another area. Although this legislation deals with chicken meat research, the total situation in regard to supply, demand, prices and the economic standard of the industries affected in Australia are interconnected. It would be foolish to say that the pig and chicken meat industries would not be affected if there were, for instance, dumping of large quantities of beef on the domestic market. The statistics that I have drawn out for 1980-83 indicate that over-supply in one area immediately produces a dampening and damaging effect across the board in all industries. Thus the Government should take note of the amendment that I will move at a later stage and move aggressively to support the marketing of Australian meats so that all sections of the Australian meat industry receive the Government's basic support.

Honourable members will be aware of the drastic situation that applies throughout this nation in regard to the slaughter and processing of Australian meat. They will be aware also that some 7,000 meat employees have lost their jobs over the last few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—Seven thousand meat employees. We are talking today about small industries. The front pages of daily newspapers indicate just what would happen in the coal industries in New South Wales and Queensland. But the meat industry has lost 7,000 employees over the last few months. Much of this in fact can be tagged to the Government's approach to the marketing of meat products. I read with interest, for instance, in July, comments by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) when he was in Tokyo having trade discussions with the Japanese Government. At the conclusion of his comments about the relationship between Japan and Australia with respect to coal, beef and agricultural products he said: This is why I believe my meeting with Mr Abe yesterday was so significant. He gave me a very clear and unambiguous undertaking that 'Japan has no intention of solving trade problems with third countries at the expense of Australia'.

SPEECH.PARA: That phrase has been quoted often by the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to justify certain stances that he has taken. But in fact that phrase was used by Mr Abe in Japan in July last year. Goodness knows what it means. One can only assume that the intention with regard to our beef and mutton industries is that Australia will not be played off the break by Japanese negotiations with the United States. Mr Abe, as reported by Mr Hayden, described the Japan-Australia relationship as firm and unshakeable and described our commercial association as an 'economic alliance'. It was also said that we are both very much part of the Asian-Pacific region. I think that that is the basis for the Government's philosophy on the marketing of meats and the trade relationship established by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. That comment was made by Mr Hayden on 26 July. It is interesting that on 28 July the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) was reported as saying:
The United States had asked Australia to agree to voluntary restraints on its exports of beef to the United States market.
Mr Bowen is quoted as saying:
If a voluntary restraint program does not prove possible the United States may be forced by its own domestic legislation to seek to apply quotas on imports this year.

That is, the United States may have to impose import quotas on Australian beef. There we have the Minister for Trade telling the Australian meat industry, the beef industry in particular, that we will enter into restraints in marketing Australian beef in the United States. What happened within six months? The United States did a deal with Japan and now flogs its beef to Japan. Who has been played off the break? The Minister for Trade, having acquiesced to a demand from the United States voluntarily to restrict the flow of beef into America, then sits on his hands while the Americans turn around and flog beef to Japan, taking away our traditional markets.

In my view the Minister for Trade displayed a great deal of incompetence in this matter. As I said earlier, the inter-relationship of all meat products is affected by the incapacity of the Minister for Trade to understand that the Americans were not dealing fairly with Australia in this instance. They sought voluntary restraint in July last year and within six months are selling their surplus beef to Japan. Having convinced Australia voluntarily to withdraw to a great extent from the United States market, the United States then sells its surplus beef against us in our traditional market. Goodness me, if that is not a serious matter and a display of serious incompetence, I would be very surprised.

It is up to the Government and the Minister for Trade to explain themselves in these circumstances. The Minister has not sought to do so. He has stayed away from Japan in every instance and stayed away from hard and proper negotiations. No doubt the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was unaware of these processes when he was in Japan in February and had his discussions with Mr Nakasone, the Japanese Prime Minister. At a conference in Osaka on 3 February, as reported in the Melbourne Age, Mr Hawke said:

I have secured, I believe, in discussions with Mr Nakasone and others an understanding that provided that Australia remains a competitive and relaible supplier-which we will-then the share that Australia has enjoyed in these traditional markets will be maintained.

That share in traditional markets, expressed in those terms, is a percentage that is maintained. An actual figure is not indicated. It is not tonnage. A share indicates a percentage of the total market. The Prime Minister said he understood the Japanese Prime Minister to agree that Australia will hold that share of the market. It was only after that instance that we became aware here that the Americans were seeking to move their beef into Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not mind the honourable member for Mitchell talking about beef when we are talking about chicken and pigs; but if he wishes to have the sort of debate which we had the other day on this question, I am afraid that in my reply to the second reading debate I will also have to divert from matters before the House.
—The honourable member has foreshadowed an amendment which has opened up the debate and which will allow the Minister to respond in the manner in which he may seek to do.

—I understand the Minister's sensitivity because of all the individuals involved in this sad and sorry case he has proved to be the most incompetent and the most ineffectual in his negotiations on behalf of Australian primary producers and in particular on behalf of the meat producers of Australia -whether they be beef producers, chicken meat producers or pig meat producers- because their markets are interlocked. There is no way in which they can escape the situation that they sell one against the other on the domestic market, and an oversupply of beef on the Australian market will dramatically damage the prospects for the sale of chicken meat and pig meat.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke claimed in private discussions with Australian journalists in Osaka that he had an undertaking from the Japanese Prime Minister that he would see that Australia's share of the traditional Japanese market would be maintained. That was the commitment from the Prime Minister in Japan. Within a few days the Ministry for Agriculture in Japan denied that that was the statement of the Prime Minister. In fact, one Press report in the Sydney Morning Herald dated 14 February-referring to a source from Japan-stated that the talks on Australian beef
. . . had been delayed because the Japanese were unhappy at the way the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, had interpreted--
notice that word 'interpreted'-
his talks on trade with the Japanese Prime Minister, Mr Nakasone.

It is the Prime Minister's interpretation of what he thought went on but in fact did not. Therefore, he seriously damaged the prospect for the sale of Australian beef to Japanese markets because of his wish to hunt headlines. Media reports in Tokyo following the discussions indicated that Mr Hawke had gained firm assurances from Mr Nakasone that Australia would maintain its traditional share of that market. All of this time, under the closer economic relationships with New Zealand, Australian markets are being attacked--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The amendment that the honourable member has foreshadowed does not deal with the Prime Minister's visit to Japan or New Zealand; it deals with the marketing of all meat products being interconnected. It is certainly not dealing with the marketing of beef, as he has related.
—If the honourable member is saying that the Prime Minister was on a junket I am afraid I will have to believe him.

—Order! There is some substance to the point of order taken by the honourable member for McMillan. While the foreshadowed amendment has widened the debate, I think that the honourable member for Mitchell should make his comments relate more to chicken and pig meats.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have dealt with the role of the Prime Minister in this issue. I wish now to quote from the Minister for Primary Industry who, on 9 April in a discussion on the PM program on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio, was talking about the sale of Australian meats. He said that it was a very complex picture. He indicated that he was going to Japan to patch up the damage done by the Prime Minister. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we're not just flying up there at the drop of a hat, I think we are going at exactly the right time, at the Ministerial level. I don't know why everyone wants to try and heighten this as if we don't know what's going on.
One the same day, the Minister of Trade said:
I don't think anything was wrong, I think it's a question of interpretation.
He was referring to the Prime Minister's comments. The Minister continued:
We actually admit we get more beef into Japan in quantity terms and possibly in the terms of interpretation they were saying well, you will get more beef, to that extent you won't be disadvantaged.

That is gobbledegook. It is a complete contradition of what the Prime Minister was saying, and it is ducking for cover. On 9 April the Minister for Primary Industry said that he was going to Japan at exactly the right time to try to solve this problem on behalf of Australia. In a report from Tokyo printed in the Australian on 18 April, Rod O'Brien, quoting from Japanese scoures, said that he was informed that Australia's refusal to listen is a constant point being made Japanese buyers of Australian beef. The article stated:

As an example, Mr Kerin outlined, that among other things, the Australian side would push for increases in the chilled beef category of the global quota. This approach has been taken for years by Australia and Mr Kerin has inherited, and accepted it.
Japan, on the other hand, has said it does not want an expansion of the chilled tonnage because chilled beef must be released soon after arrival--

The comments made by Mr O'Brien are revealing. He is saying that the Minister for Primary Industry went to Japan and did nothing because he was there on the wrong basis. He was there in circumstances that he did not understand. In fact he was trying to resolve a difficult situation created for Australian meat producers by the Prime Minister. In the State of New South Wales it is a disastrous and desperate time for the meat industry, a time when pig producers, poultry producers, sheep growers and beef cattle producers are suffering. When 7 ,000 workers have been sacked throughout Australia, when abattoir after abattoir is closing down we would have thought we would see an effective and dynamic approach by the Australian Government to the problems of marketing Australian meats, but we have not seen that. In New South Wales, despite the closure of these plants, despite the number of people who have been laid off, the New South Wales Government continues to maintain the antique of all abattoirs at Flemington and over the last few years has propped it up with a total allocation of $20m. I am referring to an organisation that has made losses of $25m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member should be brought back to the legislation. He is way off track in his remarks.

—As I said before, the amendment foreshadowed by the honourable member for Mitchell has broadened the debate considerably, but I remind him once again that it would be advantageous if he could relate his remarks to the Bills. I call the honourable member for Mitchell.

—As my time is coming to and end, I will reiterate some of the main points I made in regard to the marketing of meat produce throughout Australia and internationally and to the role of the Australian Government in these issues . The role of the Australian Government has been abominable. First of all, in one instance in July last year we had the Minister for Trade agreeing to a reduction in the amount of beef Australia would sell to the United States. Where did that beef go? It stayed in Australia and competed against chicken, pig and sheep meats. I repeat: That beef stayed in Australia. Then, the Minister, not recognising what the Americans were doing, failed to take any effective action when he found out that American beef producers were undercutting Australia in the sale of beef on the Japanese market. That is a nice ploy that the Minister for Trade should try to explain.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry was then thrown into the matter in April. He said that he thought it was the right time to go to Japan. It did not matter that it was two weeks earlier than he had planned. He had to do something about the mess the Prime Minister had created there. The Prime Minister, by the way, is a person who gets his fixes from reading his name in the headlines of newspapers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. The Chair should bring the honourable member into line.
—They are very sensitive.
—Order! I think that the honourable members for McMillian has made his point once again.

—Honourable members opposite are extremely sensitive to a throwaway line made in the course of the debate. The Prime Minister is at the nub of this. He went to Japan, with a quick tongue. He is a weak and insignificant man who likes to see his name in newspapers. Why else would he make statements that so seriously damage our meat trade and so seriously damage the future of Australian producers of all types of meat, both white and red? The Prime Minister is at the nub of it. The Prime Minister caused this problem. The Prime Minister went to Japan and created the problems involving the Japanese Government. He is supported by such a low-key Minister for Primary Industry that one would not know where he was. The Minister went to Japan to try to resolve the matter. He said it was the opportune time. He came back a few days later and said: 'Well, they were not ready to talk to me'. The Minister would have known that before he went, had he done his homework. Now he is going to Japan again. What incompetence! The man has a degree in economics. The only trouble is that he cannot translate that into practice in trade negotiations. These three men who represent the Government, the Minister for Trade, the Minister for Primary Industry and the Prime Minister, have failed this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill 1984 is to correct an anomaly in the Chicken Meat Research Act 1969. During 1969 three Acts were passed by the Commonwealth Parliament, which established a joint Commonwealth Government-industry scheme to undertake research for the chicken meat industry. The research scheme is funded mainly by a levy on meat chickens hatched, with a matching contribution by the Commonwealth Government on expenditure from the levy. It is worthwhile to record that this research scheme is the result of proposals submitted to the Federal Government by the chicken meat industry for the introduction of a statutory research scheme along similar lines to those operating for a number of other rural industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The relevant legislation passed in 1969 was: First, the Chicken Meat Research Act, which established the Chicken Meat Research Trust Account; second, the Meat Chicken Levy Act, which provides for the imposition of a levy on meat chickens hatched; and third, the Meat Chicken Levy Collection Act, which provides the legislative authority for collecting the levy. The scheme is designed to provide a co-ordinated program of research in relation to the scientific, technical and economic problems of the meat chicken industry.

The current rate of levy is 10c for every 100 meat chickens hatched. The maximum rate of levy provided in the legislation is 25c for every 100 meat chickens hatched. The levy is reviewed each year. I understand there are no current proposals by the Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee to change the rate of levy.

Levy receipts are matched by the Commonwealth Government. Other receipts from the sale of assets or produce from research projects, interest on investment of resources and penalties for late payment of the levy are not matched by the Commonwealth Government. In the past access to the unmatched reserves has been restricted by the need to exhaust the matched funds first. This is impracticable as the levy continues to be received regularly.

The principal amendment contained in this Bill is to provide for two separate accounts within the research account. The first account will cover funds matched by the Commonwealth Government, the second account will deal with funds not matched by the Commonwealth Government. This arrangemnt will provide greater flexibility in meeting research expenditure.

The industry levy currently raises approximately $241,000 per annum. For the financial year 1982-83 nearly $220,000 was provided by the Commonwealth as a matching contribution in respect of expenditure made for research over that period. In addition, approximately $90,000 was paid into the trust account from income derived from investments, sales of products, sales of shares and penalties for late payment of levy. Research grants and related expenditure approved to date for the 1983-84 financial year amount to $524,427. Unmatchable reserves held in the trust account amount to approximately $320,000. This sum includes interest amounting to approximately $289,000 earned on investment of reserves since 1970 to the present.

The cost of research into nutrition of the meat chicken from 1969 to the present time has amounted to approximately $1.2m. It is the policy of the Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee to approve grants to research projects on the basis of industry need and requirements. Frequently research grants are made to only two or three groups in any one area of research. During this financial year the Committee has allocated approximately 42 per cent of research expenditure to universities and colleges, 27 per cent of research expenditure to State departments of agriculture or primary industry and 12 per cent of research expenditure to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisations.

Since the introduction of the research scheme approximately 41 per cent of expenditure for research projects has been allocated towards research into poultry diseases; 16 per cent of expenditure for research projects has been allocated to public health related projects.

The chickens produced in modern hatcheries normally grow faster than their predecessors did. Physiologically they are under more stress and are therefore more susceptible to disease. Newcastle disease poses a continual threat to the Australian chicken meat industry. There is great danger of it being introduced into Australia by accident or design. The disease is evident in Europe, the United States of America and Asia. Only one strain of Newcastle disease, that is , V4, is present in Australia. This strain does not produce any symptoms in birds but has allowed for the development of a vaccine that may be effective against other strains of Newcastle disease. Extensive research into Newcastle disease has been carried out both in Australia and Malaysia for a number of years. The list of chicken diseases seems endless: Marek's disease, avian viral disease, mycoplasma infection, infectious coryza, infectious bursal syndrome, infectious bronchitis virus, infectious laryngotracheitis, acute death syndrome, mycoplasma synovial infection, early chicken nephritis, avian encephalomyelitis viruses, avian lymphoid leukosis, leg weakness and so on.

Another important area of research is to improve the nutrition of chickens. Triticale, a wheat-rye hybrid, is an alternative grain that has been examined by the Committee for use in obtaining greater meat production in chickens. The Committee has examined a wide range of foodstuffs which are not useful for human consumption but could be nutritious to chickens. The Committee also sponsors farm management research and extensively promotes farming efficiency, particularly with respect to management of broiler chickens and breeder chickens .

Chicken slaughtering techniques are also investigated by the Committee. Normally meat chickens are marketed at about seven weeks of age when their expected average live weight is around 1.8 kilograms. It is important to present or 'dress' chickens in a salable condition. It is also important to reduce the amount of offal remaining in the finished product to maintain product integrity. The total number of meat chickens slaughtered in the seven months to January 1984 was approximately 124 million. Consumption of meat chicken in the same period is estimated to be 19.4 kilgorams per person, a slight rise from early 1983. Slaughterings are forecast to increase by 2 per cent while average slaughter weights should rise in line with trends apparent in the Industry over the past four or five years. It is expected that Australia will export only 1.3 kilotonnes of chicken meat this year. Exports are principally to Papua New Guinea and the Pacific islands.

Food costs are a major component of total production costs in the poultry industry. It appears likely that in 1984 there will be significant quantities of rain-affected wheat which should be suitable for, and priced as, stock feed wheat. Feed wheat prices are expected to be much lower than in 1983. Accordingly profitability of the chicken meat industry should improve as a consequence of falling feed costs. Furthermore, production of poultry meat in 1984 is expected to rise by approximately 3 per cent to approximately 315 kilotonnes.

In addition to the research work being carried out by the Committee, a number of companies also carry out research into packaging and supermarket presentation . For example, the illumination of certain coloured lamps can highlight chicken meat more favourably than naturally would be the case. No actual work has been carried out by the Committee on packaging. This has been an industry project. The industry prides itself on even quality of products and all packaging carries a brand name. This is to maintain product quality and accountability by the industry. Fresh poultry is packaged in clear plastic bags and frozen poultry in an opaque cryovac package.

One of the best advantages of chicken meat is its constant quality. By sound and disciplined production techniques an even quality product for the consumer can be offered all year round. The take-away food business has always demanded chickens of even quality and strict weight and size specifications. The outlook for chicken meat in the medium term is relatively favourable. Feed cost increases are generally expected to be less than the rate of growth of poultry prices, while supplies of competing meats are not expected to return to the high levels of recent years until late in the 1980s.

The Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill 1984 amends the Pig Meat Slaughter Levy Act 1971 and the Pig Meat Promotion Act 1975. Specifically, clause 6 of the Bill provides for the repeal of section 4 of the Pig Meat Promotion Act 1975, which established the Pig Meat Promotion Trust Account. The Bill provides for the closure of that account and transfers funds standing to the credit of that account to the Pork Promotion Committee, established by this Bill. Clause 7 of the Bill amends section 5 of the Principal Act to provide that after July 1, 1984, all money received by the Federal Government for promotion funds from both the pig slaughter levy and any other sources are to be paid direct to the Pork Promotion Committee. The Committee will pay its own accounts. The Committee will now be subject to the usual accounting procedures required of statutory bodies and its accounts will be audited by the Commonwealth Auditor-General. The Bill provides for a number of machinery changes, including the provision for a quorum of three-members or deputies-at Committee meetings. The above changes have the support of the Australian Pork Producers Federation.

The Pig Meat Promotion Act 1975 established the Pig Meat Promotion Committee composed of four members. Clause 11 of the Bill changes the name of the Pig Meat Promotion Committee to the Pork Promotion committee. The Committee is funded by a levy imposed by the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971. The current promotion levy is 60c for each pig slaughtered for human consumption. In 1982-83 promotion levy funds collected, penalty payments, interest from investments and miscellaneous income received by the committee amounted to approximately $2.5m. There was also a balance of more than $1m from the previous year. There is no contribution to committee funds by the Federal Government. Expenditure by the pig meat promotion trust account in 1982-1983 amounted to more than $2.6m.

The Pig Meat Promotion Committee has done an excellent job in carrying out well conducted market research and has designed its program campaigns accordingly. the committee has been promoting a range of new fashioned pork cuts, which are a selection of fat-trimmed, lean boneless cuts. The advertising campaign has been designed to overcome consumer perception of pork being a fatty wasteful meat. A major public relations campaign is being carried out to inform housewives and people involved in the food industry of the correct values of pork in the human diet. In the next twelve months the Pork Promotion Committee will be undertaking a massive promotional campaign in support of pig meat products. Already advertising and promotion by the Committee has lifted pork, ham and bacon sales enormously. Regrettably, promotion is completely concentrated on the domestic market. The Committee performs an important role with respect to the provision of information to producers and the collation and dissemination of industry statistics. It also conducts market research to establish consumer preferences and the perception of pig meat products.

There are approximately 14,000 pig producers in Australia. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated that the number of pigs slaughtered has increased from 4,161,000 in 1981 to 4,200,000 in 1983. The gross value of pigs slaughtered during 1982-83 is estimated to be $412m compared with $399m in 1981- 82. An 11 per cent improvement in average saleyard prices for pigs is expected in 1984 compared to the previous year. Feed costs are expected to decline. The two major factors responsible for improved prices are anticipated to be increased consumer demand resulting from an increase in the pricing of other meats, plus a decline in the level of slaughter.

As a result of the very low prices received by pig producers in 1983, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated that total pig numbers are expected to fall by 1.5 per cent to 2.46 million by the end of 1984. Also, over the same period sow numbers are expected to fall by 1.4 per cent, production of pig meat by 0.8 per cent to 240 kilotonnes, and total consumption by 1.3 per cent. However, by 1986 pig producers expect a significant build-up in pig prices and a subsequent increase in production reflecting expected improvements in net returns. However, many pig producers are concerned as to the future of the pig industry. Some producers claim that over the last 20 years there has been a significant decline in the number of pig establishments, with a reduction in the number of small piggeries. It is estimated that the share of the national pig herd under the corporate integrated control is now approximately 20 per cent. The level of corporate investment an vertical integrated operations have important implications for pig production units owned by individuals solely involved in pig production.

One concern is the effect of integrated prodution, that is, the same company controlling the supply of feed grains, production of pigs and processing and sale of the final product as against the smaller family unit that is engaged in production of pigs alone and needs to be able to sell its product to a processor . Accordingly, the preservation of market outlets is of vital concern to the non -integrated pig farmer, particularly when corporate investment can take over processing operations.

A number of pig producers are desirous of expanding the export pig meat trade. Other pig producers have serious reservations about such a move because of the fluctuation in access to and profitability of export markets and the consequent effect those problems could have on the domestic market. It is noteworthy that exports of pig meat in 1983 rose by approximately 9 per cent on the 1982 figure. However, exports still account for only an estimated one per cent of total production. A small quantity of live pigs has been sold to Singapore for breeding stock. Exports of pig meat are expected to increase slightly in 1984 but to remain a very low proportion of production. It is likely that most of these exports will go to Japan and Papua New Guinea. Mr Brian Jackson, Group executive director of Afrifoods Group, Elders-IXL, told a recent pig marketing workshop that Australia has all the requirements for a major pork export industry. He claimed that successful exporting countries added value to their product before exporting it. For example, export industries should be based on converting Australia's agricultural commodities into higher value-added exports. It was claimed that the export markets for pig meat are quite significant. Japan is the major importer of pig meat. Over the next decade many Asian countries are expected to dramatically increase their demand for imported pig meat. The industry recognises Singapore as a huge potential importer of Australian pig meat. At present many Asian countries are importing pork from Denmark, the United States of America and Canada. The pig meat industry is confident that Australia will become increasingly competitive in the export of pig meat.

It has also been claimed that the structure of the Australian grain industry, particularly the Australian Wheat Board, is a major obstacle to the development of value-added indutries based on grains. It has been alleged that the Australian Wheat Board refuses to permit the development of a feed-wheat indstry with variations developed for feed purposes. It has been suggested that it is unlikely that an export industry will arise until there is some freedom in the domestic wheat market. If Australia is to produce cheap pig meat then the producer must have the opportunity of easy access to grain. This would have benefits for intensive pig and poultry feeding. All commercial producers of pigs use milled feed grains made up of a range of grains and proteins for optimum growth of pigs. Mr Jackson claimed that his company had received inquiries from a number of foreign organisations interested in establishing export intensive meat industries in Australia, including pig meat, poultry and grain feed beef.

The export pig meat industry would appear to represent the best opportunity in this area. Federal and State governments must adopt a program of accelerated development of value-added agricultural export industries in Australia. The Hawke Government, an authentic Australian Government, has instituted a number of sound initiatives designed to develop and maintain such industries. The development of such industries would create thousands of jobs and generate significant export earnings for Australia. Australia's pig breeding, nutrition, husbandry and management technology has rapidly caught up with the rest of the world.

Finance collected from producers on the levy of pigs slaughtered for human consumption under the Pig Meat Slaughter Levy Act 1971 is also allocated for research and related purposes. The James Cook University of North Queensland in Townsville has undertaken a number of pig research projects and is an important research centre for the investigation of pig disease.

The development of improved production procedures and a concerted effort by the industry to reduce costs deserve the highest priority. If the pig meat industry is to continue to maintain a secure foothold as a major primary industry in Australia then it must accept the challenge of developing and expanding export markets. The industry is far more advanced in almost every area than any other pig meat industry in the world. The Hawke Government supports the continued growth of the Australian pig meat industry and urges the industry to accelerate the development of an export industry of pig meat to Asian countries.

To sum up, these two Bills are further written evidence of the Hawke Government 's determination to pursue its historic goals of national reconciliation, national reconstruction and national recovery of Australian primary industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills before the House today are the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill 1984 and the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill 1984. The House has already been made aware that these Bills are neither large in their content nor in their purpose. However, they are necessary Bills of the type that the Government must bring before the Parliament on occasions to ensure that these industries can be assisted. The main purpose of the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill is to give the promotion committee control of its own funds. That is something that I am sure the Opposition will support because it gives independence to those people who know the task best. The Chicken Meat Research Act 1969 made no specific provision for moneys collected as a penalty for late payment of a levy to be paid into the research account. This Bill corrects that anomaly. The Bill also establishes two separate accounts within the research account, the first account to cover funds matched by the Commonwealth and the second account to cover funds not matched by the Commonwealth. This provides greater flexibility in meeting research expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: All in all, the Government has set out to improve the opportunities for the two industries to operate and to improve their product and their market prospects. I do not think anybody had any great objection to that. Nevertheless, when the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) spoke he indicated to me one of the great problems confronting the white meat industries.The chicken industry, through vertical integration and through other things, has become one of the major providers of meat. Plenty of us in this chamber remember when chicken was a Christmas time luxury. It has now become one of the more common-place items on a family menu. Nevertheless, chicken is still, and will always remain, in competition with red meats. Of course, that is healthy and good for the consumer . Australia has relied heavily on the red meat industry as an export earner as well and quite clearly, as was stated by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), when we get to the situation of the white meat industries needing to export, of course the whole export arrangements of the present Government come into question. Consequently, the honourable member for Mitchell foreshadowed an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill which states:

Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the marketing of all meat products is interconnected and calls on the Government to aggressively support the marketing of Australian meats.

Any person who interjects when the Opposition, quite constructively, tries to bring this matter to the Government's attention is only defending the Government from its own sins. Instead of looking to the welfare of meat producers and recognising the link between export sales and local sales and the protection of those industries, there is interjection after interjection. These interjections were made by the representative of a country electorate who should be deeply concerned about the welfare of his constituents and the export markets, for instance, of beef. Like so many members of the Australian Labor Party he is obliged to put the welfare of his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Party ahead of his constituents. I recently had the job of pointing out to the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) that he might start to recognise who elected him. The people of his electorate elected him. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is a little worried about how he should reply to the foreshadowed amendment. What have we got? More than anything else we have a beef industry which relies on exports. More particularly it relies on exports to countries such as Japan. It has become very clear to everybody that we are losing sections of that market . Every time we lost a bit of that market more pressure was placed on the chicken and pig industries. The Prime Minister, in recognising this after having it brought to his attention by the Cattle Council of Australia, went to Japan and, during his discussions with the Japanese Prime Minister, he raised this matter. According to what the Prime Minister told us, he got some assurances from the Japanese Prime Minister. When he produced his Press release he used the words 'I believe'. He said:
I have secured,--
he added 'I believe'--

in discussions with Mr Nakasone and others an understanding that provided that Australia remains a competitive and reliable supplier-which we will-then the share that Australia has enjoyed in these traditional markets will be maintained .
He also said:
. . . its share in the traditional areas of supply which, of course, includes mineral products and primary products-particularly beef.

That is what the Prime Minister was talking about. Having received some assurances, which I believe were probably given by Prime Minister Nakasone in good faith, the Prime Minister, in traditional style, overlooked the first rule of a competent businessman, and that is to keep one's mouth shut when one is in front. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the quorum and thank all Government members for being here today to listen to this powerful speech that I am about to make on the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill and the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill. I would also like to thank the Government Whip for allowing me to speak here today. I hope that the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin) runs the primary industries of Australia better than he has attempted to run business here in the House today. The Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill is being introduced to help the promotion of pork.
