—Order! There is far too much conversation in the House.

—I can handle members of the Government. They do not concern me much. The sort of interest they take in the pig and chicken producers of Australia is practically nil. SPEECH.PARA: The Bill seeks to change the name of the Pig Meat Promotion Committee to the Pork Promotion Committee. The pork industry has done a tremendous job in the last few years promoting its product. Pork is a name that I guess is easier for producers to use to enable them to sell more of their product to the housewives throughout Australia. Administration of the funds will be in the hands of the producers themselves. I think that this is a model that all primary industries can follow. That having been done, the industries themselves ought to be given the opportunity to run their own affairs. This is the sort of Bill that ought to be applied, not only to the pork industry but also to the beef industry, the wheat industry and a number of other primary industries in Australia.

The levy is to be paid direct to the Committee. Again, I think this is an excellent idea. The levy will not be handled half a dozen times by the bureaucracy. It will be collected and will go straight to the producers to do as they see fit. It will be audited, of course. Government has to do these things. A proper audit will be done at the end of each financial year. This is certainly the way to help producers do the job of promotion. The Commonwealth is not involved in providing any funds. What worries me is that the Senate may set up a committee. Once senators get together and get committees going anything can happen. All I am doing is asking the primary industry producers of Australia to wake up to what is going on, to get together and make sure that we nip the animal liberation movement in the bud before it gets rolling.

—I call the Minister for Primary Industry. Might I suggest to the Minister that as there has been a fairly free-ranging debate he can answer most of the questions that were raised if he wishes to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-It has been an intensive and a free-ranging debate. I honestly do not know where to start. For the information of honourable members, and perhaps the listening public, the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill 1984 and the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill 1984, which are being debated cognately, relate to a name change, some funding changes and some administrative changes with respect to two Acts of Parliament. I thank honourable members for their contributions, particularly the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who put forward thoroughly researched and constructive contributions which actually referred to the Bills before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I must say that I was rather sorry for the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), who gave a speech for the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh), who I understand from a journal I read recently was a public speaking champion. What we got, in keeping with his expertise, was the usual billy-goat nonsensical approach to any matters raised in the House concerned with agriculture, with the usual level of personal abuse. I am not going to focus on personalities. I think what is important and what the people want to hear are the ideas expressed by their representatives, not name- calling which passes for debate. Of course, members of the National Party of Australia are addicted to this sort of behaviour. They always confuse abuse with debate.

The points raised by the honourable member for Murray in the latter part of his speech showed some research, some interest, and some knowledge of the industries that are under debate. He also ranged rather widely onto to plant variety rights , industrial relations, the tally system, and the Mayfair situation in Bendigo. What he says about the export inspection charges being greater than the value of the exported product is quite true. However, as I have said before and as people know, the problem is that only one per cent of the pig product is actually exported, and that is mainly offals. To export an abattoir needs an export licence, hence the Export Inspection Service inspection and higher charges. Some plants have surrendered their export licences. Some have been involved in diversion rather than incur higher maintenance and inspection costs. Other works which are still exporting are exporting more than just offal from pigs. I presume that they are more diversified works and that they are killing products other than pigs.

Other contributions to the debate raised points of interest. The whole question of research funding is the subject of two Cabinet submissions from me at present . Honourable members would realise that during the last Budget we raised the level of research funding for some agricultural products, and there is a constant demand for continual and further research funding. Another speaker raised the situation in Korea. He said that because we cannot sell meat in Japan we also cannot sell it in Korea. I suppose I should reflect on that in terms of the amendment. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) pursued his usual union-bashing line, despite the fact that the Hawke Labor Government has presided over the lowest level of strikes ever in this country. The industrial relations climate is generally more acceptable and more beneficial to primary industry and industry generally than it has ever been before. What the honourable member for O'Connor said really justified what I said the other day with respect to the Opposition's hypocrisy and its despicable behaviour over the Japanese beef trade.

Members of the Opposition have shown in their comments today on this legislation that their only focus is an attack on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They are not worried about the cattle industry, the processing industry or the meat workers in it. All they are interested in doing is attacking the Prime Minister. They have raised the question of Bourke's and ACTU-Solo when, of course, the historical record shows that the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Prime Minister's involvement in Bourke's was the weapon that effectively broke resale price maintenance in this country. It was a very good day indeed when that happened. The Prime Minister has provided all of the speeches he made during his visit to Japan and Asia. He has informed the House of his talks in those countries. What he said about beef and the agreed statement between him and Prime Minister Nakasone was a general statement of great utility and benefit in continuing trade negotiations.

The Opposition is doing exactly what it did when Prime Minister Whitlam was abroad. As with the present Prime Minister, we then had a Prime Minister who could actually go abroad without us being ashamed. One of the advantages of being in government is that when one goes abroad one learns of the appalling blues of the previous Government. I will not go through all that, but I just ask members of the Opposition to focus on the fact that it is my understanding that a former Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade actually invited Rumania to export pig meat to Australia. It would raise a bit of a storm if that matter were fully investigated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Mr Anthony, when Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, was instrumental in ensuring that unfair imports remained--
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member is perhaps making an explanation.

—They are really jealous of the fact that the Prime Minister of this country is popular, has a good Government, and is running the country in the interests of Australia. All they can focus on is attacks on him in some personal way. One gets a great sense of deja vu. In 1974, when the Japanese cut off imports of beef from Australia because of the oil price shock and the actions of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the then Opposition blamed poor old Frank Crean. It is the great re-run. All that members of the Opposition can think about is something in the past, and that is what they are running their present attack on.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just focus on the Australian beef industry and the comments of the honourable member for Mitchell. The honourable member said that there is a relationship between the United States negotiations with respect to the agreed tonnage last year and the present trade negotiations. Let me go into that in a bit more detail because the honourable member either does not understand or he is ignorant or he is simply being destructive of Australia's interests, as most members of the National Party are in this place. I would have expected a bit more sense from the Liberal Party member.

The situation was that at that stage we did not have all the meat available to fill the quota because there was a drought and the estimates provided at the start of the season proved wrong towards the end of the season. The United States allocated quota on the basis of information available to it and the Canadians and New Zealanders took up that additional quota very quickly. In the end we exported some 285,000 tonnes of meat to the United States. It is true that the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) agreed to voluntary restraints because that effectively gave us access to more tonnage than we would otherwise have been given if the United States had triggered the quotas under the meat import law. At the time we were working closely with the United States with respect to overall trade liberalisation. It was not in the interests of our co- operation or of the beef industry that we push the Americans into quota arrangements at a time when both countries were negotiating trade liberalisation with respect to the Japanese market.

The meat sold by the United States to the Japanese market is different meat from the meat that Australia sells to the United States. We are not even comparing like with like. I am not going to go into all of the technical arrangements. However, the problem with respect to United States access to the Japanese market does impinge upon Australia's access for meat only in one respect. The squeeze is on the meat in the middle, if we arrange meat going into that market in some hierarchy from high quality to a more normal run of beef cuts through to offals. The United States share of the market in offals has been going up very rapidly, as has the quota beef at the high quality end.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you call offal?

—Diaphragm meat, for example. The Opposition has nothing to be particularly proud of with respect to the Japanese market. We know the figures exactly because the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) put them in Hansard the other day. In terms of total imports going into Japan-these are Japanese beef statistics, quota and non-quota-Australia's share dropped from 75 per cent to 53 per cent, whereas the United States share rose from 16 per cent to 41 per cent. That happened under the previous Government. From 1976 to 1982 the quota increase into Japan was of the order of some 32,000 tonnes and Australia secured during that period an increase of only 10,500 tonnes. That is, it achieved only one-third of the increase. One of the big problems in the offal area is that Australia's share under the previous Government dropped from 43 per cent to 12 per cent. This is at the centre of some of the negotiations about which, as the honourable member for O'Connor quite rightly pointed out, I will not now go into detail because the negotiations are on-going.

SPEECH.PARA: The other day during an urgency motion I pointed out that members of the beef cattle industry have a far more balanced view on this question. I read partially into Hansard a statement by the Cattlemen's Union President, Mr Ian Park, who is not actually a wide-eyed socialist. The statement was for publication in the magazine of the Cattlemen's Union. The statement says quite plainly and in a balanced fashion:
It is not clear yet how much beef Australia will export to Japan in the current Japanese fiscal year.
But one thing is clear-the amount of beef will be increased, even though our percentage share of the market is likely to decrease.
That is because the Japanese global quota is expanding each year under the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs.
Last financial year, Japanese beef imports increased from 135,000 tonnes to 141 ,000 tonnes.
Of this amount, Australia supplied 87,000 tonnes, or around 60% of the market.
Japanese imports will increase again this financial year.
An increase of 6,900 tonnes already has been negotiated with the US authorities .
Australian officials now are to commence talks on the increase Australia can expect.
Initial reports suggested the Australian increase would be at least 2,500 tonnes.
This may not be the case any more, as the US received a larger than expected increase, and the Japanese Government will be under pressure from its own farmers to minimise imports.
Australian officials will seek the best possible deal, and will be backed up by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, who will fly to Tokyo later this week.
But cattlemen should be clear on the fact that the negotiations concern an increase in access to the Japanese market.
There is no suggestion that our exports will be reduced-the only question is by how much they will increase.
In these terms, the result of the negotiations will have little effect on the Australian cattle markets.
Demand can only firm-it will not fall.
The improved position of the US is only to be expected.
The US has a mammoth trade deficit with Japan, and therefore greater influence than Australia in negotiating trade access.
But Australian officials still have some strong cards to play.
Australian beef is cheaper than the United States product, and Australia has proven reliability as a supplier.
These points will be put forecfully to the Japanese Government.
At the same time, the presence of the Minister for Primary Industry will clearly indicate Australia's concern at its dwindling share of the market.

That sets forth the position in a balanced fashion. I have a tonne of quotes here but I do not have time to go through them. An editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald again put forward a rather balanced view on this whole question. There have been other reports in newspapers. As anyone knows, one can selectively quote from newspapers. At least we know the position of a very important cattlemen's organisation because it is on the record. That is a view rather than a value judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Cattle Council?

—The President of the Cattle Council, Maurice Binstead, has been in Japan and has made statements which are supportive of the factual situation. Of course, having been more closely apprised of the details of the negotiations with Japan likewise he will not go into the details of on-going negotiations. The Opposition has also made some comments about timing. It was propitious that I was going north basically to a trade conference in Korea. We did not know when the negotiations between the United States and Japan would be concluded. It was propitious that I was in Japan at that time. I was going to Korea representing the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen). The deal with the United States was concluded on 7 April and I was in the right place at the right time. The previous arrangement for me to go to Japan on a wide range of questions had also been decided in advance and is well known to the Japanese Government. So there is nothing Machiavellian or mysterious about that. There was some good fortune in it.

SPEECH.PARA: Our officials from the Departments of Trade and Primary Industry have been negotiating on this matter for a long time. They started negotiations under the previous Government. We know exactly where we are and the lack of understanding by the Opposition is understandable. I think what it is really after is the Prime Minister. It is not worried about the cattle industry at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come out and speak to the meat workers at Riverstone and see how you go.

—The Opposition when in government shut down 32 abattoirs so it should not go into all that nonsense. It is true that in April the Koreans issued a meat tender for the first time since December 1983. The main situation in Korea that is relevant is that it has diverted many resources into pig production. It has a surplus of pig meat. It has some idea of importing other meats from other countries for its people to use in their diets. It issued a contract for the first time which was entirely for boned-out beef. It is true that New Zealand gained 66 per cent of that contract. That was 2,700 tonnes. We gained 900 tonnes . It is not a question of the Government being involved in this. The only area where government to government negotiations really become absolute is with respect of Japan or to any country where there are laws in the buying country. The reason why we did not win on that tender is basically because of the fact that all the meat was boned-out and the fact that our saleyard prices had risen by 40 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no implication that Korea is taking an offset position because we may or may not have bought something from Korea. It is certainly insistent that the trade imbalance between our two countries needs to be given attention. We are working on that. But that is the basic reason. Saleyard prices in Australia have risen by 40 per cent and the Korean Government takes commercial decisions in this matter because it is a fair and honest trader. It is not interested in scoring points off any particular political party which happens to be in government in Australia at the time.

The final matter I give some attention to is the amendment foreshadowed by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). This is really a motherhood amendment. I am not sure whether he wants us to give statutory backing by setting up a pig meat marketing corporation or a chicken meat marketing corporation. I do not know whether he wants us to fund Inghams and the other big two or three chicken integrators. I do not know whether he wants simply to yell and scream or whether he wants us to pay money somehow. As the honourable member knows, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation is involved mainly in export promotion, but also in some domestic promotion. We have spoken with the pork producers with respect to a statutory authority for them. We have also spoken to chicken producers with respect to contracts for them.

The problem with the Opposition's proposal is that it is really a motherhood one and is not really specific. The honourable member should really focus on the fact that white meat is the main competitor of red meat. Is he suggesting that we aggressively support all meats or that we give equal treatment to red meats and white meats? The problem is that chicken and pork are basically in the hands of private enterprise. There is no statutory authority. Promotion is in the hands of the industries.

The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) does not want any government involvement judging from his comments; neither does the honourable member for O' Connor. They take a more basic free enterprise approach to the chicken and pig industries than does the Liberal member for Mitchell. The Australian Government is actively supporting the marketing of all Australian meats, but it recognises full well that the main competitor in this country for red meats is white meat. Unless the honourable gentleman wishes to specify what his amendment is all about, the Government will simply reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the second reading debate on the Chicken Meat Research Amendment Bill the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) referred to the last Korean beef tender and the reasons why New Zealand gained so much of that tender. He made a point about the price at which beef could be purchased in New Zealand compared with Australia. There is no doubt that it is cheaper-it has been publicly quoted. I ask this question quite sincerely on behalf of all meat producers of all types of meat in Australia: Was that lower price for New Zealand beef subject to the supplementary minimum price scheme in New Zealand? The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) and I have made the point that the supplementary minimum price scheme, which is costing the New Zealand Government several hundred million dollars a year, is a direct subsidy for the export of New Zealand's agricultural product and therefore would constitute unfair trading if that tender were won by New Zealand against Australia through the intervention of that scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: In his concluding remarks the Minister said that the price of beef in Australia had risen and asked therefore how we could expect to win that tender. I have with me the most recent edition of Stock and Land, which is a Victorian agricultural weekly newspaper, dated Thursday, 26 April. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) and I can see quite clearly that the graph for bullocks, vealers or cows-the three types of beef-shows that the prices for this calendar year so far are below what they were at any time last year. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am advised that the $40 difference between Australian cattle prices and New Zealand cattle prices relates to the period from December 1983 until the present, when the tender has been issued, and it is relative to New Zealand prices. TALK.START.PARA: —The Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill is a technical but important piece of legislation. It amends the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, which was introduced to aid in the interpretation of statutes and in the shortening of language employed in statutes. Parliaments and courts deal in words, and the interpretation of the words of Acts of parliament is for the courts and lawyers a major and formidable legal task. Anything that lessens the burden of that task is to be welcomed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me illustrate briefly some of the reasons why that task can be so difficult . Firstly, there are the inherent ambiguities and imprecisions of language. Strain as we may, it is often extremely difficult to make a concept as clear as we would like it to be. Secondly, there are the complexities of concepts which are sought to be embedded within a statute. An example is the taxation legislation, which has reached a stage where it is impossible to understand the nature of the legislation which is being put before this House. I speak in particular of all species of recoupment legislation since the recoupment legislation introduced by the previous Government. Thirdly, we have much evidence of sloppy and unnecessarily technical and verbose drafting.

Once again taxation legislation forms a striking example. It is as though the draftsman sought to encompass every possible contingency, and consequently the Act become extremely lengthy, extremely verbose and words and concepts trip over each other. The interpretation of legislation has become a minefield for the courts, for the advisers and for those who are caught up before the courts. As we all know laws should be certain, knowable and accessible. There are those who believe that there are ways of making things very much simpler and that laws can always be expressed simply. Certainly that is the desirable aim, but I would ask anyone who thinks that short simple concepts promote certainty to have a look at section 92 of the Constitutions which, expressed in very laconic terms, provides that trade, commerce and intercourse among the States should be absolutely free. That is a statement which one would think would be perfectly plain. After all, we know what is meant by 'trade'. We know what is meant by 'commerce'. We know what is meant by 'intercourse'. We understand the word 'free', and what can be simpler than the concept 'absolutely free'? Yet of all the provisions of the Constitution that single provision has probably taken up more time of the courts and caused greater difficulty in its application to the changing scene of Australia's national life.

Let me turn to the purposes of the Bill which is now before the House. It has a number of purposes. First, there are a number of amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act are of a purely technical or drafting nature. For example, I refer to proposed new section 8A, 8B, 8C, 10A and 22, which will deal with such matters as implied repeals, the effects of the expiration of an Act, reference to part of an Act, references to amended or re-enacted laws of States or Territories, and the meaning of such words as 'financial year', 'calendar month' and 'calendar year'. They are all very technical and all very dry but useful to the lawyers.

Secondly, the Bill provides for amendments that reflect changes in technology. For example, what will become section 25 deals with such matters as references to writing documents. This gives a wider definition to 'document' to make it reflect the requirements of modern technology. Proposed new section 25A provides for the production of records and the like which are kept in computers and similar equipment. Thirdly, the Bill introduces a number of amendments to overcome idiosyncratic rules of interpretation and to ensure that technicalities do not impede the administration of justice. Examples are to be found in what will become section 25C, section 25D and section 25E. For example, proposed new section 25E provides that one attains a particular age on the commencement of the relevant anniversary of one's date of birth rather than the day before the date of birth, as is presently the law. The reason for this is too arcane and quite unnecessary to be explored now.

Fourthly, standing alone is an amendment described by that robust person, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) as a sexist amendment or an amendment to overcome what he said was a 'sexist way of dealing with matters of gender'. To hear the Deputy Prime Minister express that view and no doubt to hear his colleague in the other place, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), has some rather laughable aspects. The Deputy Prime Minister said:
The existing Acts Interpretation Act provides in section 23, and has so provided since 1901, that words importing the masculine gender shall include the female, unless the contrary intention appears.
One would think that that statement is fair enough and no objection can be made to it. The Deputy Prime Minister went on to say:

I propose by this Bill that this sexist way of dealing with matters of gender should be altered so that the provision simply provides that, unless the contrary intention appears, words importing a gender include the other gender.

We are at least dealing with two sexes. So the Deputy Prime Minister does concede that one cannot get away from the subject of sex if one is talking about human beings; they are after all either male or female. Why is it that the Deputy Prime Minister and this Government have to contribute to the debasement of the English language, inspired by simple-minded zealots and condoned and supported by Ministers whose indifference to the English language is matched only by their craven desire to appear to be in the vanguard of every attempt at reform?

I wonder what would happen if the Deputy Prime Minister got his hand on prayers and literature. What would happen to 'Our Father'? Would it become 'Our Mother'? Would it become 'Our Father/Mother', or would it become 'Our Neutral Gender Father/Mother'? Of those honourable members who might read cowboy novels, I ask: What would happen to the word 'cowboy'? Would it become 'cowperson'? Would we read such sentences as 'A cowperson rides over the horizon', or 'A cowperson comes into town'? What would happen to the word 'fatherland'? After all, the Germans refer to their land as the Fatherland. If I recall correctly the Russians refer to their land as Mother Russia. Will it become 'personland'? One does not know, but that kind of nonsense incorporated into an Act of parliament is no more than a ludicrous and tiresome waste of the Parliament's time.

I come next to what is certainly the most important piece of the legislation- that is the radical change which is proposed to the rules of interpretation of statutes. Before coming to what is proposed, let me state the present state of affairs. I can do no better than quote Mr Justice Gibbs, as he then was. In a judgment given in 1975 on a case between the Attorney-General and the Commonwealth, Mr Justice Gibbs said:

'. . . in Australia it has been accepted that in construing the Constitution, as in the case of any other statute, although regard may be had to the state of things existing when the statute was passed, and therefore to historical facts and to earlier legislation, it is not permissible to consider what was said in Parliament or at a constitutional convention by those who debated the measure.

Parliamentary debate-that is, what happens in parliament-has always been rigorously excluded within the courts. In a case between South Australia and the Commonwealth, the uniform taxation case, the Court refused to permit the tendering in evidence of the second reading speech of the Minister to show what was claimed to be the purpose of the Commonwealth's uniform taxation laws. As matters presently stand, it is a practice to give continual, central and overwhelming importance to the text of the statute. Marginal notes are excluded from consideration for reasons which go back to the nineteenth century and which need not detain the House. Generally, all parliamentary and Executive material is excluded. Drafts of the Bills are usually excluded, although drafts of the Constitution have been referred to for the purposes of interpreting the Constitution. Reports of committees of inquiry may be consulted to seek to ascertain the mischief that an Act of parliament is directed to overcome, where the proposals of the committee have in large measure been accepted.

What I have just said is no more than an incomplete and over-simplified statement of the rules that apply in a highly refined and technical area. The central point is that it is the text of the statute itself which has been regarded by the courts as being of overwhelming importance and it is difficult to get the courts to consider matters outside the text of the statute. It is now proposed to permit the courts to have recourse to a wide variety of material. Under section 15AB, as it will be, it is provided that, subject to what later appears, where any material not forming part of an Act is capable of assisting in the ascertainment of the meaning of that provision, consideration may be given to it either to confirm the meaning of the provision in the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text, taking into account its context in the Act and the purpose and object underlying the Act, or alternatively to determine the meaning of the provision where it is ambiguous or obscure, or the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text is manifestly absurd or unreasonable. So we have two situations where extrinsic, or outside, material may be referred to-either where one desires to confirm the ordinary meaning or where the ordinary meaning of the text as it appears is ambiguous or obscure or is manifestly absurd or unreasonable.

For that purpose the court is entitled to consult any material that it judges to be capable of assisting it. The provision we are considering sets out, without limiting the general powers of the courts, the specific matters that the courts may look at. Let me go through them briefly and comment on them as I go. The first is all matters not forming part of the Act that are set out in the document containing the Act. That would include marginal notes, which all of us here look at for the purposes of understanding what an Act of Parliament is concerned with but which the courts, because of historical rules, cannot and do not look at. The courts will be able to look at any relevant report of a royal commission, law reform commission, committee of inquiry or other similar body laid before either House before the time when the provision under consideration was enacted. Of course, what is a relevant report is a matter entirely for the court. It can look at parliamentary reports, treaties or other international agreements. It can look at explanatory memorandums relating to the Bill which contains the provision it has to look at. It can look at the speech made to the House or the Senate by a Minister on the occasion of moving that the Bill be read a second time.

That is all very good and it is all very helpful, and I think that what is proposed is a most useful and beneficial measure and one for which Senator Durack is squarely responsible, because these matters go back to his time. But let us not kid ourselves as to how useful some of this material will be. For example, one unacquainted with the operations of Parliament might assume that the purpose of a second reading speech is to convey in clear and impartial terms the effect of the proposal put before a House. But we all know that often a second reading speech does not do that. It has a number of purposes. No doubt one is to seek to explain the substance of what is before a House, but the second is a purely political purpose. It is perfectly plain that over the years Ministers have presented to a House second reading speeches on contentious Bills which misstate or obscure the intended effect and the actual effect of the legislation before the House. A second reading speech is a highly political document and courts having recourse to second reading speeches had better keep that squarely in mind. A second reading speech is often a vastly oversimplified document.

The various kinds of documents to which I have referred are not part of any closed system. It is a matter entirely for the court to consider what it should look at. The list includes relevant material in the Journals of the Senate and the Votes and Proceedings of the House of Representatives or in any official record of debates in either House of Parliament. So those who speak upon this measure today should do so conscious of the fact that when it comes to the courts to interpret the meaning of this measure, should the courts ever be asked to do so, they may be asked to consider the speeches made in this House for the purposes of determining what it was, if anything, that Parliament had clearly in mind.

Perhaps one other provision should be added as a separate sub-provision or sub- paragraph to the list of specific material that courts may consider. I would put it in these terms: 'Anything else which diligent and ingenious and persuasive lawyers can persuade the courts to look at'. It is true and it is sensible that the measure before the House does require the courts to consider, when looking at extrinsic or outside material or the weight and importance to be given to such material, the desirability of persons being able to rely upon the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text and the need to avoid prolonged legal or other proceedings without compensating advantages. That is sensible and desirable, but it is perfectly plain that there will be cases where desperate counsel-all of us who have practised at the bar for any time have been in that position-will seek to persuade the court to have regard to a whole variety of material for the purposes of making a provision read or interpret in a way that suits their case. After all, if an Act of Parliament is against a lawyer and he is in court, then it is obscure in meaning and he needs to look to other material. If it appears to be in his favour then, no matter how tortuous the reasoning, the lawyer will say it is all perfectly plain and the court does not need to look at anything else. I commend this provision to the profession, not only because it will provide the profession with a lot of interesting work but also because fundamentally it will improve greatly a court's capacity to consider material which it thinks relevant when it comes to looking at obscure and difficult provisions. In conclusion, the genesis of this provision is to be found in the amendments introduced by Senator Durack in 1981 in section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act, as well as in the symposium convened under his authority in February 1983. We should all be conscious of the fact that, whilst this Government is putting the proposal into effect, the genesis goes squarely back to the work done by Senator Durack as Attorney-General.

Let me finish by commenting on one consequence of the proposal which does not appear to have attracted attention. This House cannot amend the Constitution. We are now proposing one or two sets of rules of interpretations. One set will be the rules that apply presently, as developed by the law, by the courts, in the interpretation of the Constitution. The other set will be the rules now before this House which will permit extrinsic, outside material to be examined for the purposes of understanding what a provision means. Therefore, we will have, it seems to me, two different sets of rules working side by side, one applying to the Constitution and the other applying to all Acts of this Parliament. And we have the irony, if it were open to them, of members of the High Court of Australia looking back on the constitutional debates and looking back on such matters as what Quick and Garran thought was the meaning to be attributed to certain provisions of the Constitution as a result of the convention debate. That is, if the courts could consider, in interpreting provisions of the Constitution, what was said at the time the Constitution was being got together, as they will be able to consider debate in Parliament, then we might have a wholly different interpretation of such sections of the Constitution as section 92 and the provision dealing with the external affairs power.

I will expand on that for one or two minutes. It is ironic is it not, that there has been a great deal of debate in this House in recent times about the external affairs power and the proper width of the external affairs power. It is perfectly open to us, for various reasons, be they legal or simply political, to entertain different views as to the meaning of the external affairs power. All of us in this House know that the High Court has given a very wide interpretation to the external affairs power. However, one can only say that it is an interpretation of that power which would be surprising to those who participated in the convention debates. If one looks at what those learned authors Quick and Garran thought to be the effect of the external affairs power, then it is perfectly plain that they and their contemporaries did not believe that it went as far as the High Court has held that it goes.

Be that as it may, and without going into the niceties of whether the High Court was right or wrong since the High Court is, after all, the final court on these matters and it is perfectly pointless to express opinions as to the rightness or wrongness unless one has an opportunity to influence the Court to change its mind, which it would not, then the position still remains that we will have these two sets of rules of interpretation marching side by side, one applying to statutes of this Parliament and the other more limited set applying to the Constitution unless somehow the High Court is able to enlarge its own view as to what it may properly and constitutionally look at for the purposes of interpretation of the Constitution.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Tertiary and Technical Education-Atomic Weapons Testing-Secondary Schools Staffing in Broken Hill-Manufacturing Industry: Unemployment-The Economy-Local Government-Australian League of Rights-Hawke Labor Government

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to spend a few minutes today talking in general terms about tertiary and technical education in Australia. I do not think there is any need to stress the importance of it for the future of this country, but what worries all of us, I think on both sides of this House, is the increasing lack of opportunity for many younger and older Australians to participate in technical or tertiary education simply because the opportunity and the places do not exist in the facilities and institutions that we have currently in this country. Whilst that is a very general statement, I will back it up in a few minutes by explaining what is happening in my own area of the Gold Coast and the lack of opportunity there for so many people who wish to pursue higher education.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, some 40,000 students were refused admission to tertiary institutions in this country, which is an enormous number of students. We have one of the lowest participation rates in the Western world, and we do have to make substantial efforts to provide the places for these people if we are going to pursue any sensible development in this country. In my own State of Queensland the participation rate, unfortunately is one of the lowest or the lowest in Australia. Only 46 people in every 1,000 participate in tertiary education in Queensland. In New South Wales the figure is some 62 per 1,000. The problem has arisen basically because of the Government's encouragement to the students to stay at school, which is a worthwhile and commendable objective; there is no doubt about that. The second reason that we have this problem of lack of opportunity is that people are realising more and more that the days of getting jobs without any training and the development of any skills have long since gone , and that their future will depend on the training they get in tertiary and technical institutions.

So the problem is not likely to go away. In fact, it is going to increase. The Government recognises this. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) certainly recognises it. But it is no use coming to Queensland, as she did a few weeks ago and, in a de facto way, berating the Queensland Government for not providing the places for tertiary institutions. The fact is, rightly or wrongly, that the Commonwealth Government provides the funds for these institutions, and therefore it is the Commonwealth Government that has to make provision for extra places for those who seek them.

Let me spend a couple of minutes outlining the position on the Gold Coast. In the first place, we have no tertiary institution whatsoever in that area. We have nearly 60 schools for a catchment population of some 250,000 people, and that is without any prospective growth; that is as it is at the moment. Taking the figure of 46 per 1,000, which is the Queensland participation figure in tertiary education as it is now, one comes up with a student body of about 11, 500 Gold Coast students wanting to attend a tertiary institution, and that, as I said, is at the very lowest rate of 46 per 1,000. If one takes it to 62 per 1, 000, as occurs in New South Wales, then that Gold Coast area alone would have a potential student population of over 15,000. Taking either of those figures-12, 000 or 15,000-and even at 12,000 potential students, that is twice as many students as currently attend both the universities of James Cook, in the north, and Griffith in Brisbane, which have a combined student population of something over 6,000. The 12,000 potential students that the Gold Coast area would produce is half the number of all the students at all the colleges of advanced education in the whole of Queensland.

Let me turn to technical and further education in the Gold Coast area. In Queensland the participation rate is about 120 per 1,000; in New South Wales it is about 220 per 1,000; in South Australia it is something like 280 per 1,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The State Government is supposed to be funding TAFE.

—It partially funds it, as the honourable member should well know. On the Gold Coast we have a hopelessly overcrowded TAFE, and that is because of the enormous growth in recent years. It has 18,000 students now, and on those population figures and those potential student figures, it should be providing places for about 50,000 people. Just so that the honourable member for Petrie ( Mr Wells) does not get too excited, I am outlining the proposition; I am not apportioning any blame. All I am saying is that we have a problem, and the honourable member should recognise it.
—I agree with that.

—Right. If one took, in my own area, a participation rate in TAFE colleges of about 200 per 1,000, then we should be providing places for about 50 ,000 students. Without going any further the problem must be clear even to some of the members on the other side. The solution to the problem, of course, is money. It does not matter who is in government, there are always limits, of course, to the amount of money available for education. So how are we going to solve the problem? I would suggest that one of the options that should be more closely examined is to start levelling off the funding that is being given to the school area of population and start diverting some of those funds into technical and tertiary education. The fact is-and I think it is well recognised- that in the last few years there has been enormous development in most schools in Australia, to bring their level of facilities and educational levels up to a standard which is considerably higher than it was five or six years ago, and certainly a massive growth in these facilities as compared with those that existed when most of us who are in this chamber went to school. There has been enormous growth.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot go on and on pouring money into schools to raise the level of their resources if, at the same time, when students leave school, we are not providing any opportunities for them to go on into tertiary or technical education. If there is a finite limit, as we all recognise, on the amount that can be spent on education, surely it must make sense that we start at this stage levelling off the school funding, because I believe that schools have reached a standard which is probably adequate; but we must put more money into technical and tertiary education so that people who want to pursue or who have to pursue their studies, to give them a break-even chance of getting a decent job in this country in the future, are provided with the facilities to do so. We should not continue to ignore areas like the Gold Coast, where places should be provided for probably 50,000 or 60,000 students when all we are doing now is providing some 18,000 places, and that includes some full-time students and some part-time students.

I know that the Government recognises the problem. What I am suggesting is an option, and I hope very much that the Government and the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs will look seriously at that option as a way of providing some assistance for students in further education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with some serious cases of cover-ups and denials concerning atomic testing at Maralinga. The first comes from a letter from an ex-Royal Australian Air Force serviceman who worked at Maralinga, and I quote from that letter:

SPEECH.PARA: During my service in the RAAF at Maralinga in 1960-61 I discovered something which I believe should be disclosed, namely, that British atomic weapons were stored at Maralinga adjacent to the airstrip, that is, operational tactical weapons, distinct from test weapons. These were held in a sophisticated building at the north-western end near a taxiway and dispersal bay (please find diagram enclosed). During certain inquiries I made relating to this discovery, which had to be very discreet, I found that there was based in Australia, at Edinburgh ( South Australia), a number of Vulcan and Victor bombers of the RAF. Also based at Darwin, Northern Territory, was No. 542 Squadron, RAF which had reconnaissance Canberra bombers.

The reasons for the Victors and the Vulcans being based here at the time was officially given as being here for the purpose of testing the Blue Steel stand- off missile. However, I do not believe this because, after leaving Maralinga at the end of 1961, I went to Woomera to work for the WRE (Weapons Research Establishment), and I witnessed the testing of Blue Steel during 1962-63-64. During 1962-63 there was a number of tests but not near enough to justify up to 6 to 8 aircraft based at Edinburgh.

In 1964 the tests with the Vulcans and the Victors virtually stopped but the aircraft numbers remained the same. I believe the real reason the Vulcans and Victors were here was to deliver those weapons stored at Maralinga.

When Maralinga range closed in 1963, the weapons I mentioned were moved to Woomera and I further discovered that they stayed there until 1966. Also at this time the Vulcan and Victor bombers left Australia.
The letter is signed, and that was the end of the quote.

It is to be expected that there will be denials that Australian soil was used to store tactical atomic bombs, but I am confident that the information in this ex-serviceman's letter is correct. To those who would try to deny or cover up this information, I say this: You tried to deny and cover up the fact that the British Government had buried plutonium at Maralinga, and we all know now that plutonium was buried at Maralinga. Denying and covering up usually comes from the higher levels. I refer the House to the Adelaide News of 10 October 1978 and the headline 'What Plutonium! There's none there'. That denial was from none less than Sir William Penney, later made Lord Penney. It was he who was in charge of the British atomic tests here in Australia. Again, I say that this reporting of the storage of tactical atomic bombs at Maralinga and later at Woomera can be relied upon in spite of the flood of denials we will hear following this particular release.

I come now to the further denials concerning British atomic tests at Maralinga- denials, cover-ups and more cover-ups. The matter concerns the British atomic tests at Maralinga and their use of cobalt 60. Cobalt 60 has a half-life of 5.3 years. If injected into the atmosphere it adversely affects people in the fall- out zone for many years. The concept is known as the enhanced radiation weapon, or part of the 'dirty bomb'. This was revealed this week. On Monday, 30 April, before Senate Estimates Committee C, as reported at page 60, in reply to a question by Senator Maguire about waste buried at Maralinga, Mr Ryan, Acting Deputy Secretary, Department of Resources and Energy, said:
The airport cemetery contains such things as Cobalt 60.
'Airport cemetery' is the term used for burial sites for waste.

Now let us look at the cover-up since 1968. I refer to the Government report AWRE.0-16/68 by the United Kingdom. It was the Atomic Weapons Research Establishment report AWRE.0-16/68 entitled 'Final Report on Radiological Contamination of the Maralinga Area and Emu Site'. It was classified 'Restricted ', one of the lowest levels of security classification, and became known as the Pearce Report after its author, N. Pearce. An unrestricted version was finally released in May 1979 by the Australian Department of National Development under the imprimatur of Kevin Newman, the then Minister. The only difference between the restricted and unrestricted reports is deletion of any reference to cobalt, beryllium and natural uranium contamination.

Obviously, the British wanted to keep quiet about the work they may have been doing on a possible cobalt bomb; hence the deletion of references to cobalt 60. Beryllium, apart from being a major hazard when inhaled, is an efficient slower- down of neutrons and can be used to increase bomb efficiency. Natural uranium is used to increase fallout from fission-fusion-fission bombs, so obviously all the potential for dirty bomb tricks had been studied. The disclosure of the burial of cobalt 60 at the Maralinga airport cemetery and the sanitised edition of the report AWRE.0-16/68 must give rise to the greatest disquiet and these concerns will not go away. We need and the public need a full judicial inquiry into the atomic tests at Monte Bello, Emu and Maralinga. I would like to refer here to the Adelaide Advertiser of 10 October 1978 quoting the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Bill Hayden. The article states:
Mr Hayden said the public could not feel confident that proper safety measures had been adopted at Maralinga.
Mr Hayden went on to say:
In the circumstances I do not see how the Government can avoid a full public inquiry into this whole affair.

The edited version of the Pearce Report, in the foreword, points out that the original version gave information on the nature of the test material used-cobalt 60, et cetera, no doubt. The foreword goes on:
In addition the report specifically records the location of various burials and their contents.

It also records the burial of recoverable platonium amongst the Maralinga burials. But, of course, we needed the courage of RAAF serviceman, Mr Avon Hudson, to force the previous Government to finally own up, resulting in the UK Government being forced to come and remove it.

As further evidence of the disquiet, I would refer to the AIRAC Report No. 9- the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council. I refer, in particular, to the Buffalo series of tests at Maralinga. For test No. 8, code name Kite, the date was 11 October 1956. The bomb was dropped from a plane and was classified a low-yield bomb. On pages 39 and 70 of that report we find reports of gamma radiation fallout, including a very large dose in Port Lincoln and an even greater dose at Mr Gambier. These records, including the map provided on page 39 , do not indicate that the wind change had carried the atomic clouds down into that area, but quite clearly, the Council could not cover it up completely because it had to give the recordings that were gained both at Mr Gambier and at Port Lincoln. It adds to my disquiet when I find that I have received a communication, which I will disclose later, that says that Sir Mark Oliphant's brother has given information to a neighbour that during some of the tests in the late fifties the radioactive levels were so high that they actually shifted the decimal point of the recordings. That information has been conveyed, as I understand it, to the Premier of South Australia, and a copy of that communication is on its way to me. For these reasons, I think that the Government must take charge of this issue. We must have a judicial inquiry so that people can come forward and so that people can be subpoenaed to give that evidence. Further, the evidence and the reports that the Government currently has must be made available for such an inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the city of Broken Hill there are three high schools. There are the state high schools, the Willyama High School and the Broken Hill High School, and, of course, the Catholic High School. At the beginning of this year, when those schools commenced operations, they were 13 teachers and one school counsellor down. In other words, they were expected to start the school year with 14 staff not available. By 15 March they were still seven teachers short and on that day a large protest meeting was held. The majority of school children from the Broken Hill High School and the Willyama High School and the primary schools in the area decided not to go to school and attended a demonstration through the streets of Broken Hill and marched on to the State office block asking for representatives of the State Government to do something about their plight. In the following week the school teachers of Broken Hill-those in the state school system-went on strike over the same issue.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a new issue but it is an issue that has been in the pipeline for a couple of years, and I remember that last year the school teachers in the area were making protests to the Australian Teachers Federation and to the New South Wales Government about the teaching staffing problem in the city of Broken Hill. At the moment in Broken Hill, in the two high schools, as a result of the demonstration, four teachers have been provided, and the rest are only primary trained. These teachers, of course, are doing their very best, but I think it is essential that students in country areas should have the same opportunities and the same well-trained teachers as students in city areas. The problem is that this situation exists not only in Broken Hill but also in most country areas of New South Wales. Of course, the more isolated the area, the worse the situation becomes.

What is causing this situation? I believe that it is the fact that there are planned changes to the transfers and promotion systems in the school system in New South Wales. Perhaps if I could just read from a study entitled ' Perspectives: looking at education', dated 28 February 1983, this might explain what the situation is and what is causing this shortage of teachers in the country areas of New South Wales. It states:

A planned change to the system of lateral transfers and promotion of teachers to promotions positions within the State schools system has been announced by the Department of Education. The planned change, prepared as part of the Department's Equal Opportunity Management Plan, will have far-reaching effects on the teaching service as a whole.

The new plan has been designed to remove an aspect of indirect discrimination against teachers who are on the promotions lists. The proposed changes will introduce a bias-free promotions practice by removing the priority enjoyed by mobile teachers who occupy substantive promotions positions over those waiting for promotion.

New lists will be created from which all appointments to vacant promotions positions will be made. This be piloted for a period of five years, with the new lists to be published and distributed in May 1984 for the implementation of 1985 appointments.

The problem with this promotion system is, as I see it, the fact that it comes out of the equal opportunities legislation of New South Wales State Government. I am sure that most honourable members would agree with that equal opportunities legislation. But it creates problems, certainly in the Public Service, of which the teachers are part, and it will mean that in State areas of New South Wales, particularly in the country areas, we are going to have real problems. What is happening at the moment is that a number of teachers who perhaps asked to go to country areas are saying, 'If I go out to Broken Hill, or to White Cliffs, Tibooburra, Moulamein, or Balranald, or to those such places, there is a very good chance that I will not get back from there simply because no one else will want to come out there, particularly if there are no promotions in the pipeline for teachers who come to country areas'.

One of the main groups that have pushed for this equal opportunity in the teaching profession is that of women teachers based mainly in coastal areas or in cities. They feel that it is very difficult for them to move. They may be married to a professional man or to a person who has a business and may find it very difficult to move; whereas for males it is not so difficult to move because usually the housewife is prepared to travel with that male teacher. But, in travelling to these outback areas and to these country areas, many teachers find themselves disadvantaged as, indeed, do many people in the Public Service. I know that people in the Department of Main Roads, when they travel to these areas, if they are very young and they do not have a house, are continually on the move, and they find themselves disadvantaged when they go to buy a house when they return to the areas that they originally came from. Also, some of these people who come from coastal areas or the city have their parents or their families back in coastal areas, and they wish to return there. Everyone can understand that. So there is this reluctance to go to country areas. But, in the decision as to whether to go there, I think that there should be some incentive for these teachers to go there, and I think that removing this rapid promotion system is really discriminating against those teachers.

We talk about equal opportunity. It may be that there is equal opportunity there for school teachers who do not want to move into the country. But what about the students? The State Government of New South Wales has introduced this legislation, and I believe that governments which introduce legislation should wear that legislation. What will the State Government do about these teachers? In Broken Hill, as I said, they were 14 down at the beginning of the year and one can travel to any school, I would say, in outback New South Wales and one would find that, if the situation is not already there, it is developing.

I am speaking here today to try to implant into the minds of parents in country areas that they should approach the teachers in their schools and find out if this problem exists in their schools. I am sure they will find that if it is not already there, it is in the offing. They should then try to do something about it by forming lobbying groups to approach the State Government. It is no good just hoping that the problem will go away, because it will not go away. The State Government will not make any moves unless there is some type of pressure put on it, because we all know that the Teachers Federation is city based and that it does help greatly in the New South Wales State Government's election programs. So I am asking the parents of country New South Wales to think of their children and to approach their schools and the teachers in those areas. I must say that the teachers in the outback schools in New South Wales have been trying to do something about this for a very long time because they have seen the problems there. But they have not been assisted greatly, and I would ask all politicians, whether they be State or Federal politicians, to try to do something about that.

Most of the members of this House know of the importance that countries overseas place on education. Having in the last couple of years visited Japan and Korea, where education is given the utmost priority, because those countries realise the importance of it-and we can see what has happened to those nations in the past years because of their eduction; they realise what is gong on-and having seen that, I realise what is going on. Some of us here also have had children who have studied for the higher school certificate and for the school certificate, and we know the traumas that those youngsters go through, without having the problem of having to sit idle in the school or spend the time in the playground or just do nothing because they do not have the right teachers to teach them those subjects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is to blame?

—The State Government is to blame-and I think it is also another reason why we should be looking at the Sex Discrimination Act. These Bills that come in sound very good, but when one gets the results of those Bills flowing through we shall find our nation in serious problems. So I reiterate to the parents of students in country New South Wales that they approach their teachers in the schools, ask them what the problem is, ask them about this rapid promotion scheme and what has happened, and ask them about the equal opportunities plan of the Department of Education in New South Wales. Hopefully, those parents will get together. The teachers have tried-without success, because the Teachers Federation is city dominated and coastal dominated. They are getting nowehere very fast. I would ask the parents of New South Wales to stand up and be counted , and let us get our children a decent education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to express the anguish of workers and employees in my electorate who have lost their jobs because of the situtation that our manufacturing industry is in, where staff are being laid off as a consequence of loss of orders. I also voice the anxieties of those who are still working but who will face dismissal if the level of industrial activity is further reduced and of those over whose heads hang, like Damocles' sword, the plans to restructure our industries.

SPEECH.PARA: My electorate contains well over 2,000 industrial undertakings, mainly small and medium size industries that are labour intensive and employ tens of thousands of people from the district. Many of these industries and their workers are feeling the double effect of the self-imposed depression by the former Fraser Government and the alarmingly high influx of imported foreign manufactured goods from cheap labour Asian countries. The job losses attributable to these two factors, firstly to the harsh and discredited monetary policies of the former Liberal-National Party Government and, secondly, to the lifting of our import restrictions, are enormous. The combination of these two deadly prescriptions for economic disaster left hundreds of thousands of our fellow Australians unemployed.

On 5 March 1983 the Australian people rid themselves of the Liberal-National Party Government and, with it, its harsh and inept economic policies that in seven years brought this country to the brink of economic ruin. The new policies of consensus and confidence in the new Hawke Labor Government have, in our short period of office, resulted in a sustained economic recovery that is unfolding today before our eyes. Together with millions of Australian wage and salary earners, I welcome the policies of the Hawke Labor Government. I applaud its resolution to abandon the inept and fruitless economic policies of the former Fraser-Howard axis which have recently been formally enshrined into the policies of the Peacock-Howard Opposition. Our Labor Government with its competent management of the economy has rekindled consumer and business confidence and has set us firmly on the road of economic recovery. However, I have given warning before, and I am again warning in this House, that unless we extend every possible assistance to our manufacturing industries, our economic recovery may be short-lived and our unemployment level will remain high, if not even higher than it is at present.

Today we are witnessing a recovery of business activities and a recovery of profits. Unless these profits are channelled into new productive investments, the level of our unemployment will remain high. The hopes of hundreds of thousands of Australians of finding employment under a Labor Government will be thwarted. The only way to avoid this disaster is through the policies of this Government which offer incentives and assistance for new investment in our industries. However, it has to be clearly understood that such investment will not be forthcoming without adequate protection from the onslaught of foreign multinationals on our industries.

American and Japanese capital concentrated in fewer and fewer hands, with the assistance of the international banking system, is being used to develop a plan to control and integrate a global world economy, not in the interests of peoples in the countries that they operate from but in the interests of high profits to multinationals and their shareholders. They have devised a new global division of labour, whereby the labour-intensive operations of manufacturing are carried out in cheap labour countries while the control of technology is retained in developed countries. The profits are thus maximised and repatriated to the mother country. The effects of the multinationals' expansion into Asia, Africa and Latin America, instead of helping development in those countries, have actually thwarted development which would have otherwise taken place. They have imposed on the underdeveloped countries a secondary role, the provision of cheap labour, and they have thus continually kept them in a state of underdevelopment and economic dependence. It is this new economic world order, the new global production plan of the transnational economy, which is pressing for de- industrialisation of Australia. According to this new global capitalist plan, Australia is designated as a supplier of raw material and agricultural produce. I quote from an article in the Age of 26 April, which indicates Australia's poor prospects for future development:

Australia devotes a relatively low amount of its resources to national research and development, and it is not expected to improve its position in the near future, according to a study by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.
The OECD found that in the 1970s in Australia the percentage of gross domestic product devoted to research and development, the available research manpower and expenditure per researcher fell.

The OECD report considers Australia in a group of middle-sized nations-Italy, Canada, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland and Belgium. Australia performs less research and development than any of these other nations in the fields of electrical/electronics, chemicals, transport equipment and machinery. Even in basic metals we are ranked second last to the Netherlands.

There is no doubt that the multinational companies are cutting investment as far as our research and development is concerned. Australia is already feeling the effect of the multinationals' world economic plan. Our industries are being squeezed out of the domestic markets and, daily, workers are losing their jobs. There are a number of industries in my electorate which are being threatened by unrestricted imports from cheap labour and high volume production countries, mainly from Asia. The industries I mentioned are well known in my electorate and , indeed, they are well known Australia-wide. Because of Japanese imports, the continuation of manufacturing of large-screen television sets by Philips is in jeopardy, and so is the manufacturing of space heaters by Pyrox because of dumping by the Japanese company, Rennai, to mention only a couple.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the Government doing about it?

—I will tell the honourable member in a minute. Yesterday 250 workers from Philips, workers who are producing the television set that won the Australian design award, marched to the Parliament House in Melbourne to express their fears that they will lose their jobs. They sent me the following telex:

SPEECH.PARA: Philips colour television employees this morning assembled at the steps of the Victorian Parliament House and proceeded to Senator Button's Melbourne office, who had prior notification, but were refused entry and confronted by locked grill doors. A delegation was then refused entry to deliver a petition to his office. We request you take this matter up with Senator Button as a matter of urgency.

I will certainly take up their sad plight with Senator Button. I expect to see him today. I will tell the Minister that thousands of workers will lose their jobs if we allow the continuation of unrestricted foreign imports. I will ask the Minister: 'What are we going to do with those workers, many of whom are highly trained? Are we going to retrain them to be waiters or laundromat assistants, or are we going to send them into the Roxby Down uranium mine?

I am concerned but I am not alone. Let me quote here a person whom I admire for his intellect and outspokeness. I quote from Sir Mark Oliphant's address at a recent prize-giving for young scientists by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd. Sir Mark said:

I hope that the Government, unlike its predecessors, will recognise the necessity to foster the industries which are not only vital for our economic well-being and our defence, but which provide more employment and more interesting employment.

You who are to receive prizes today, will be tomorrow's leaders in science. You will also become influential citizens who realise that the prosperity and independence of Australia depend upon maintenance of our vital industry. Among you will be teachers who can pass this forgotten message to their students. Some of you may like to enter politics to fill the growing need for mature scientists and engineers in government so that we are not left forever to the mercy of politicians whose background in law, accountancy and so-called liberal arts, seems to make them conscious only of money. Those whose main aim in life is riches and the power which riches bring, should not determine the future of our country. Dignity and self-respect are lost if we allow every profitable activity in this country to fall into the hands of foreigners. We must be an independent nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be little doubt that unless there is a return to a strong private sector investment program, the prospect of mid-term to long-term economic recovery is very dismal indeed. While it was heartening to note that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) belatedly acknowledged this economic fact of life, his response to the grim prospect of another recession next calendar year gives no comfort whatsoever. The Prime Minister and his Government continue to claim the credit for what is a rather fortuitous improvement in our economy at present, and that, as we know, is largely attributable to the breaking of the drought and the effects of the previous Government's wage pause. But, of course, to take credit in those circumstances is all part of politics, even though it happens to be incorrect.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, the Prime Minister and his Government blatantly refuse to accept any responsibility for either the collapse in private sector investment or the practical measures it must quickly take to make a certainty of rapid and sustainable recovery. The extent of the collapse of private investment under this Hawke Government has been dramatic. To draw it into focus it is necessary to recall that under the previous Government private investment more than trebled. It increased to $16 billion in 1982-1983, that rise being a component of an overall increase of 70 per cent in real terms since the demise of the Whitlam Government and after taking inflation into account. Since the Hawke Government came to power in March last year, the dramatic collapse has happened, and worse, it continues.

Let me back that statement with some available figures. The Australian Bureau of Statistics predicts that private sector investment will fall from that $16 billion in 1982-1983 to $11 billion this financial year in real terms; before sliding to $9.8 billion the following year and that, if it happens, will be the lowest since the Whitlam years.

What has been the reaction of the Prime Minister confronted with this stark reality, a position flowing from his own policies? His firm resolve to continue to spend more than he conscripts to the Government's coffers is to continue, so we can fairly assume that restrained spending is not in prospect. There will be no sacrifice, in effect, at the altar of economic sanity under this Government. Already accumulated deficit spending approximates $50 billion. The Government's crazy commitment to a further increase of the order of $7 billion in its next Budget, will take the total to nearly $58 billion in little more than one further year. I would like to talk about the effects of that, but it will have to wait for another day.

However, there is little or nothing arising out of the Government's economic mismanagement which will encourage those with capital to invest long term. In fact, the opposite will almost certainly continue to be the case. The Prime Minister's only reaction is to try to exhort and bully the private sector into investment. It should not have taken long for him to learn that his exhortations are not likely to succeed. All Australians should be told that there is no immediate prospect of a return to the required high levels of private sector investment unless after tax business and corporate profits are allowed to return to something approaching levels which equal a fair return on funds already invested. There must be a fair return on funds already laid out before there can be any more invested.

Instead of words, the Prime Minister must show hard evidence of the conditions which will lead to improved profitability across the whole range of private, commercial endeavour. We should be reminded that it is from after tax profits that investment funds traditionally come. But even if private investment can be financed by any one or any combination of accumulated profits, capital or borrowings, the experience and expectation of reasonable profitability must be present, particularly in these days of government inspired uncertainty. Unless this fundamental pre-condition exists, there will be little long term investment of any sort and certainly little speculative investment.

I think it is fair to observe that the Australian electorate speculated last March when it elected the Hawke Government. It must await a return on its speculative investment, and I do not see it coming. The business sector also waits and that sector will not be cajoled by the Prime Minister or anyone else into investment decisions until it is sure that the need for unnecessary speculation is, as far as reasonably possible, removed. Regrettably, uncertainty and doubt are not likely to disappear, and that is because, largely, of this manic obsession of the Prime Minister to hold an early election.

Whilst it is true that the notion of calling an early election is not now new, this Prime Minister has sunk to new depths in feeding the media on the inevitability of an election after less than one year in office. It has become conventional wisdom, as I will say later. The ensuing destabilisation and expectation of an election is being imprinted on the minds of electors and business alike with all the cleverness and paraphernalia of a latter-day Dr Goebbels. It now seems to be conventional wisdom that we will and should have an election after less than two years of this Government and this Prime Minister. No wonder there is massive uncertainty. No wonder the prognosis for private sector investment is so bad. No wonder the predictions for Australian economic wellbeing in calendar year 1985 and beyond are dismal.

In terms of pure political survival, of course, the Prime Minister's electoral intentions may be very well justifiable. However, in terms of responsible government and the responsibility entrusted to this particular Government, the cynicism of the Prime Minister must deeply worry all decent Australians. Look at what he and his Government will not do until after an early and unnecessary election. They will not announce decisions on asset testing and pensions. They will not tell us what amendments are in their mind to the prices and incomes accord-and amendments are inevitable. They will not tell us details of the Bill of Rights which we now suspect is to become a Bill of non-freedoms. They will not tell us their decisions on capital gains, wealth, death and gift taxes. They will not tell us their policy on an inviolate industrial relations scene.
