They will not tell us their policy on Aboriginal land rights and all that it will mean and imply for our great mining and pastoral industries. They will not tell us what they are going to do before the next election about taxing lump sum superannuation payments. They are not going to tell us a whole host of other things before they go to the poll because they know them to be unpopular, and this Goverment is not about taking unpopular decisions.

Only if this Prime Minister is given an unearned second term will the nation see the kind of Whitlamesque approach we all fear. That will happen under pressure from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. It is certain. The electorate will have to speculate again on the self-professed-and that is all it is-integrity of this Prime Minister in an election which is already diverting the Government from the effective economic management for which it was given responsibility as recently as March last year. An early election will be expensive enough in itself, but it will be not nearly as expensive as a second term for a Hawke Government prepared to do all those things of which only extreme left wing socialists are capable. An early election, apart from the uncertainty and a lack of stability in the lead-up period, will be further testimony to the record list of promises broken by this Prime Minister. The promise to which I refer now is the one he made on 15 February 1983, when he said:
Under my Government, parliaments will run their full time.
That will rank for notoriety with that other famous promise, in a long list of famous broken promises, made when he said:
We promise to not take money out of pensioners' cheques.
That has happened already, in November last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The grievance I wish to raise in the House today concerns the need for Federal and State legislation to assist in the transformation of the operation of local government authorities in Australia to make them relevant to the 1980s and beyond. There are currently some 839 local government authorities throughout Australia which together constitute what is recognised as the third tier of government. Those authorities employ over 138, 000 people, which is 8.7 per cent of the total government civilian employees throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The authorities have a collective total annual outlay of approximately $4,000m and are responsible for the implementation of a diverse range of social and economic functions at the local level, including planning and development control, the delivery of community and health services, local democratic functions, the control of council investments, and an increasing range of political and social initiatives on behalf of the residents of the local government authorities. Additionally, the local authorities whether they be cities, municipalities or shires, are the focus of local community activity in many forms. Despite this, local government throughout Australia is constrained by outmoded and inadequate State Government enabling legislation. There is, regrettably, insufficient recognition of the role of local government in State constitutions and no recognition of local government in the Federal Constitution .

It is pleasing, however, to note that a sub-committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention has been formed to work on the recognition of local government's role and functions for the Australian Constitution. In the State sphere, Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia have formally recognised local government in their State Constitutions. The Victorian provision, in particular, goes beyond a mere formal recognition of local government and raises the issue of local government franchise, suspension or dismissal, and provides some small measure of protection to local communities against arbitrary central government action.

I hope that many of the issues that I am raising today transcend traditional party lines, because I note that approximately a third of the members of the House of Representatives have had some direct local government experience as employees or as elected representatives. I believe that for too long local government authorities and hence the people they represent have been political pawns to be increasingly dictated to by central government in relation to matters which ought to be the subject of decision making at the local level. Additionally, dedicated aldermen and councillors who give their time to local government service are not yet given the necessary support by the Federal Government, State governments or local councils themselves to carry on their tasks effectively. In fact, after six years as an alderman on the Sydney City Council, I can assure honourable members who have not had local government experience that local elected representatives are as much subject to the 'Yes, Minister' syndrome as are other levels of government.

Too often, limited resources are available to elected representatives. The entrenched bureaucratic interests of particular council departments and the lack of overall supervision by elected local representatives results in an allocation of resources at variance with the priorities of the elected representatives. I would hope that every member of this Parliament would support the principle of accountability of public servants-including at the local level-to the elected bodies and representatives and ultimately to the people who employ them. As a new member of the Parliament, I was delighted to see that the one thing that I have seen which has united members on both sides of the House was the almost compulsory viewing in the parliamentary dining room of the Australian Broadcasting Commission program Yes, Minister.

Local government representatives need, I believe, sources of independent advice and policy support outside the traditional sources of local government operation . The clear evidence is that local representatives need far greater resources to be able to contribute to policy formulation at the local level and to widen the horizons of local government. The Hawke Labor Government, I believe, is to be congratulated on its historic establishment of the first national ministry of local government, and that Ministry has already begun to work co-operatively with State governments and local government in a responsible way. However, the office, I believe, needs to be allocated further resources to allow it to be more effective in promoting local government as the genuine third tier of Australian government.

Of vital importance, in my view, is the need for that office to play a leadership role in collaboration with State departments of local government to ensure that aldermen and councillors have support in policy development to allow local government to realise its potential. Generally-and, unfortunately, regrettably-State departments responsible for local government give negligible support to elected representatives in policy formulation or in any other areas. I urge the Federal Minister for Territories and Local Government, Mr Uren, and his Department, to work with State departments and local government itself, to develop an extensive research capability for the benefit of that third tier of government.

However, I do not pretend that local government alone can be responsible for national planning decisions, and there is a need for the Commonwealth and the States, in co-operation with local government and the private sector, to co- ordinate questions such as the location of jobs and functions with changing population patterns, to promote sustainable employment growth, housing, security , equitable means of access to community services, energy conservation, and environmental quality. In the States, the operation of local councils is controlled by legislation which is woefully inadequate and in many cases has even failed to keep pace with what are accepted current practices and responsibilities of local authorities. To give one example, in the State of New South Wales, the New South Wales Local Government Act was amended only last year to enable local government to carry on community welfare services, despite the fact that local government had been carrying on services in community welfare, including meals on wheels services, for about 30 years-30 years without legislative backing for that quite fundamental community service.

These deficiencies of State legislation, I believe, are even more apparent when seen in the light of increased local government involvement in areas not traditionally associated always with local government-for example, housing, new forms of revenue raising, and political and social campaigns of general concern to the community. What is needed, in my opinion, is action by the Federal Government to initiate, in co-operation with the States and local government, a total review of the functions and resources of local government throughout Australia and the relevant State enabling legislation, with a view to enabling joint action to be undertaken to make local government, as I have indicated, a genuine third partner in the Australian Federal system.

The establishment of a national inquiry into local government financing and the operations of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act is a welcome first step by the Commonwealth to show leadership on this issue. For all those who are committed to the principles of local democracy, decentralised decision-making and service co-ordination, I appeal to all members of the House who share those views to support a total overhaul of local government functions and powers in each of the States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is that the people of Australia are not really aware of what the present Government is all about and what it is really up to. We have this public perception of a government which is very moderate and very reasonable, but the reality is very different from that. My concern is that we have had, in recent times, a number of pieces of controversial and disturbing legislation which have been debated in this place on non-broadcast days. My concern is that this is a deliberate tactic of the Government to ensure that the people do not know what is going on in this particular place. I thought today that I should just inform the people of Australia what is actually happening.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent times we have had the sex discrimination legislation-a most controversial piece of legislation. It undermines the institution of marriage in a very serious way. For example, one cannot give any preference to a married couple over, say, a de facto couple, or a man with a mistress, in terms of employing people or in terms of finding accommodation for those people. I am sure that the general population would be most concerned if they really knew what this legislation was all about.

In the House yesterday we concluded debate on amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act. Under those amendments the former oath of allegiance has been taken completely out of the Act and has been replaced with a pledge. One of the matters of concern to many people is that reference to the Queen has been totally removed from the pledge under that legislation. I believe the people of Australia have great respect for Her Majesty the Queen. I am no reactionary. I believe that we have to be forward looking. We have to be concerned for the future, and we have to remain in touch. But we should not pull down these institutions which have meant so much to Australians in the past and which have done so much for Australia.

Another matter which will be of great concern to so many people around Australia arises in the pledge provided for in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. There are two pledges really; there is a pledge which I could call the 'atheist's pledge' and another pledge which could be called the ' religious pledge'. Under the legislation which exists, the religious pledge takes first place and the what I am calling the atheist's pledge takes second place. But they have been reversed in this new legislation. We have the Minister concerned, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), at the table at the moment. He is yet to explain why he has put God second, whereas God was first under the existing legislation.

Why is the Australian Labor Party so against the Queen? What has the Queen done wrong? What has upset the Labor Party? It was interesting yesterday during the debate on the Citizenship Amendment Bill when one Labor member said-and it may not have been reported in Hansard but I certainly clearly heard it-'She didn't help us in 1975'. Perhaps that is the reason. Perhaps that is why the Labor Party is so concerned about the Queen and wants to get the Queen right out of Australia and out of every possible piece of legislation. We recall the bitter debate that took place in 1975. We were very much involved in that. I recall very clearly being in Melbourne during the 1975 campaign in the city square at the corner of Collins Street and Swanston Street. I remember very clearly the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in a rage, attacking the then Governor-General , Sir John Kerr. Of course the Labor Party forced him out of Australia and now it wants to force the Queen out of Australia.

Look at the measures that have been taken in recent times. The national anthem has been changed. There was no reference to the people of Australia. All right, there was a vote taken on the national tune some years ago, but not on the national anthem; so that has suddenly happened. Photographs of the Queen are being removed from public buildings all around Australia. As I mentioned, reference to the Queen has been dropped from the citizenship pledge. That is a serious matter of great significance. The former Crown Solicitor has become the Australian Solicitor. 'Let us get rid of the Queen', says the Labor Party, 'Let us get rid of all reference to the monarch'.

Another matter of serious concern is the suggestion that we should have a new Australian flag. I believe that most Australians are very, very proud of their flag. We have two great Australian flags in this chamber. I believe it is a beautiful, well-balanced flag that reflects the history of Australia and the symbolism of Australia. But all around the country we have Australian Labor Party members and senators saying: 'Let's change the flag'. This has been mentioned during recent debates and no one on the other side has denied that he wants to see a change in the flag. I think that the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) said in a recent debate, 'Oh, I don't think the flag should be changed at the moment; that may not be a very wise thing to do'. I think he was looking at the politics and the votes of it all, but he said that the debate about the flag should continue.

On the last Australia Day earlier this year, a Labor senator in my part of Australia, from north-west Tasmania, spoke at the Australia Day ceremony at Devonport, and he said, 'Yes, we should change the flag. We should have a green and gold flag, and there should be a kangaroo on the flag'. That was his idea. He said that because we won the America's Cup, we should change the flag. What sort of sense of history does that display? There is more to Australia than just one event. What about the servicemen and women who have fought for Australia in the wars and in the various conflicts in which we have been involved, and those who have died for Australia? What about taking into account their feelings, and the feelings of all the rest of Australians and the way they feel so strongly about the flag? No action would be more divisive than to continue this campaign to change the Australian flag. We know what it is all about. The ALP wants to change the Australian flag by 1988. It wants to get rid of the Queen by 1988. It wants to make Australia a republic by 1988, and it wants to get rid of our great Australian flag by 1988. This is the plan. It was said yesterday, I believe, by one of the Labor members, 'Look, you cannot create a republic in Australia without a change to the Constitution'. That might be, in a strict legalistic sense, correct; but one can go down that path towards republicanism gradually, by little changes here and there.

TALK.START.PARA: —By stealth.

—Yes, by stealth. In that way, eventually Her Majesty the Queen will have no influence in Australia. What is wrong with the system that we have at the moment? What is wrong with Australia? We are a great country. We have achieved so much in our short history. We provide a great way of life for people ; and so many millions of people have come to Australia because they are attracted by the way of life here, by our high standard of living, by our high standard of health, education and welfare and so on. They want to come here for a better life for their families and their children, and they are attracted for those particular reasons. Why have these things happened? We have great institutions. We have great traditions. I suggest that if these traditions and these institutions are dragged down into the dust and are destroyed by the Australian Labor Party, we will not be a better country. Look around the world. Where is there a better country than Australia? I think that more respect should be shown for the Queen, for the flag and for our institutions by members of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Steedman Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few remaining minutes of the debate today, I wish to bring to the attention of the public the activities of one of our most vocal racist and anti-Semitic organisations. This particular organisation has been around for a long time, especially in rural areas, and I have chronicled its activities many times in the past. The organisation is the Australian League of Rights, and its director, Eric Butler, I am not proud to say, lives in my electorate of Casey. His second in command, Edward Rock, does nothing to grace the adjoining electorate of Diamond Valley, as the honourable member for that electorate, Mr Staples, will attest.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference to this organisation has recently been brought to my attention because of the activities of Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, who applauded the aims of the League and sent a supporting message to one of its conferences. We all know that Queensland has long been known as a haven for right wing extremists, and the League has always had a good following in that State. We may recall the support given to the League by Raphael Cilento, who, in relation to immigration policies, wrote such comments as 'You can get an average of four to eight diseases from people who come here', or, 'I'm more afraid of Indonesian germs than Indonesian arms'. My attention has also been drawn again to this group because of its recent activities throughout rural Victoria in opposing proposed land rights legislation. The League's director, Eric Butler, has been on many platforms recently spreading his own particular brand of racism and attempting to incite hatred against our indigenous population.

I have been in conflict with this organisation since the early 1960s when I first began publicising its activities, and it seems that, unfortunately, it is time once again to remind the people of Australia just exactly what this organisation and its many front groups stand for. In an introductory pamphlet published by the League, the member's list their aims as: Promoting loyalty to God and the Crown, to advocate genuine competitive individual enterprise and personal initiative; to attack and oppose goverment-by-regulation; to emphasise the value of Legislative Councils and the Senate; to oppose and expose all anti- British propaganda and actions irrespective of their origin. It goes on in this vein. It does, I must admit, sound very much like the diatribes we have been receiving from the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) during the recent citizenship debates. But these high-sounding, if conservative, objectives hide the real aims and directions of the League.

Eric Butler, its director, has been well-known for more than four decades as an extremist pamphleteer as well as the leader of our main racist organisation. His racism was once described by the Catholic Institute of Social Order as 'a brand of anti-Semitic literature that is rather more dangerous than the low-brow rubbish, because on the whole it does not make such a crude and violent appeal to the emotions and can, therefore, reach a wider audience'.

The Heritage Bookshop, the League's point of distribution for its literature, disseminates all sorts of facist, racist and other forms of printed hatred. Some of the less subtle titles refer to the Myth of the Six Million Jews or The Dangerous Myth of Social Equality. The League has books that claim ritual murder by Jews of Christians during the Feast of the Passover, where children are bled white, crucified, tortured, beaten and starved. There are articles by people who , in their time, were leaders of the nazi parties in England and the United States, such as Colin Jordan and George Lincoln Rockwell. A pamphlet circulated throughout Melbourne in the early 1960s in support of the white Australia policy claimed that coloured migrants in Great Britain were responsible for the alleged spread of sexual licence, venereal disease and leprosy. But the real villain, the pamphlet states, was the 'international Jewish conspiracy' which seeks 'to achieve world domination by encouraging intermarriage between Negroes and Eurpoeans'.

To support his position that the 6 million Jews were not murdered by the nazis, Butler used to quote from a book by a Hungarian author, the book called The World Conquerors, which put forward this theory. He omits, of course, to identify the author as a notorious anti-Semite, and ex-member of the Hungarian nazi organisation, the Arrow Cross, a war criminal, and a man who was deported from the United States in 1950 when his background was exposed.

But the net is wide when the League and its followers search for scapegoats to inflame their paranoid delusions. I suspect honourable members of this House did not realise that John McEwan, once a Deputy Prime Minister of this nation and Leader of the Country Party, was in fact 'a tool of Judaic policies', or that Winston Churchill, his family and ancestors has also been similarly controlled- that is, according to the League. But perhaps Butler's most famous work is an edition of The Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion, a book purporting to be a plan drawn up by the Jewish leaders to ensure world domination. It has been proved a fake many times in the courts. Butler's book entitled The International Jew-The Truth about the Protocols of Zion bears no date of publication and has a disclaimer inserted in the back by the printer. We are told that the Jews, via Rasputin, controlled the Russian royal family; they also organised the Bolshevik revolution; they controlled the nazi movement; Hitler himself was Jewish, being a bastard son of Baron Rothschild; the Jews are also in control of world capitalism; they run the United States Federal Reserve, and the Bank; they also ran the nazi Luftwaffe; and they founded the Jesuit Order-a very talented group. We are told they were also in control of President Roosevelt, and that Dr Evatt, Sir Keith Murdoch and Dr Coombs were all under influence via the medium of Professor Harold Laske of the London School of Economics. The Jews were also, by the way, behind the Spanish and Portuguese inquisitions, and they were also the hidden directors of their own persecution, their motive being to get themselves dispersed so they might infiltrate unsuspecting countries that gave them refuge. That is the sort of trash in this book. The final claim on the last page of Mr Butler's book was that Christ was not a Jew.

But how did this man, at one time a member of the Anglican Synod, a shire president, and a person who ran as the independent candidate for the Federal seat of Deakin, move into an organisation originally based on the Douglas social credit theories and branching out into anti-fluoridation and communist and Jewish plots at every turn? It seems that they were made for each other, and at an early age Butler devoted his life to pushing his conspiratorial theories at every opportunity-and he had plenty. Church leaders, civic leaders, politicians, all gave him a platform to spew out his particular form of hatred. He had friends in high places. But before we move on to them, it may be interesting to reflect on the role that this great supporter of the British way of life played leading up to and during the Second World War. In 1935 he was assuring Australians that the nazis were being maligned and that we should not trust the reports that were leaking out about the persecution of Jews. In 1938 he covered 15,000 miles in Victoria and New South Wales supporting the fascist regimes in Italy and Germany. After a supporter had brought charges of conspiracy against two High Court judges, the security service began an investigation into Butler and his organisation. The inquiry found 'certain similarities in comment' between articles written by Butler and broadcasts made by the wartime English traitor John Amery. Incidentally, after the war Amery was hanged by the British Government for treason. The inquiry also found that articles 'showed sympathy to Japan in her efforts to establish a new order in East Asia'. When such matters were 'projected into a field in which are to be found opposition to war loans, attempts to defeat the operation of wartime regulations, and the use of arguments similar to enemy propaganda, there is undoubtedly, in our view'-said the Commissioners-'every reason for some action to be taken'. So much for the great patriot.

So, we get down to the support that the League of Rights has enjoyed amongst conservative sectors of our community, including members of Parliament from the Liberal and National parties. The League is always ready to provide speakers to address lunches, dinners, churches, business groups, service clubs, and political organisations. It attempts to influence opinion leaders, particularly the clergy, teachers, Press and businessmen, and in the past it has especially had the support of certain members of the clergy. But Mr Butler's main supporter in the Parliament was the recently retired member for Moreton, Sir James Killen. I too have read the stories of Mr Killen's great wit, humour, et cetera; the recent member for Moreton. I have never believed it. I remember the man many years ago, the man described by Dr Evatt as the 'junior McCarthy of the House'. I have no time for such a person as Killen, who was a frequent speaker at League of Rights gatherings, a person who went with Eric Butler to England in 1962 to campaign with other right wing groups against Britain's proposed entry to the Common Market, and a person who was extremely vocal after the unilateral declaration of independence in Rhodesia. In fact, the League set up another front organisation at that time called the Australia/Rhodesia Association, about which I am proud to say I played a major part in its demise.

Butler has lectured around the world, including in Canada at the invitation of Ron Gostick, leader of the anti-Semitic Christian Action Movement, and in London at the invitation of Chesterton, leader of the fanatical League of Empire Loyalists. He got wide publicity in the 1960s when top rating radio television commentator Norman Banks, who was a frequent visitor to and apologist for the apartheid regime, gave him air time.

As my time runs out I return to my original point. In times of economic uncertainty we often find the growth of racist organisations seeking scapegoats and appealing to the prejudices some people have. They can only succeed if they have access to the presses, to the air waves and especially to people in high places. Butler and his League of Rights have been a blot on the history of this country for some 50 years, and they still continue to churn out the same hatreds . These days, of course, they are aimed at the newer more vulnerable members of our society. To have their organisation lauded and applauded by a member of the Senate is an insult to all men and women who fought to free us from the threat of fascist dictatorships. Under the guise of anti-communism they create and stir up divisions in our society, divisions we cannot afford. Let the people of Australia recognise them for what they are and strongly condemn Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106 as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

—I refer the Prime Minister to the confirmation by Senator Ryan in the Senate yesterday that the assets test would apply retrospectively, meaning that all those affected will have their penalty determined on their assets as at 24 August 1983 regardless of when the test actually commences. Will the Prime Minister withdraw the Government's decision? If not, will the Government seek to minimise the alarm and uncertainty which continues to occur amongst our elderly and which is created by this assets test by undertaking to announce the details of the assets test before its premature election?

—I hope that the question by the Leader of the Opposition indicates that there is a return on his part to the position which he espoused in the Parliament in 1981 when he supported the concept involved in an assets test. All I say is that what the Government has done responsibly is refer the question of the possibility of an assets test and the way it should best operate to a representative committee. I am awaiting the report from that committee. The Government will make the appropriate decisions at the time it receives it.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of reports indicating that the British police, in their search of the former Libyan People's Bureau in London, found arms, ammunition and bullet-proof vests, as well as forensic evidence indicating that it was from those premises that the gunfire which murdered Police Constable Fletcher and wounded a number of other persons on 17 April originated? What action does the Minister intend to take in view of the blatant disregard for the norms of international behaviour by the Libyan Government? What action does the Government intend to take to support the actions of the British Government in the light of this appalling affair?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with honourable members, I am aware of the reports which were publicised in the last 24 hours. As the honourable member pointed out, there was apparently a blatant breach of the Vienna Convention, which established the proper modes of conduct internationally in this sphere. The Australian Government was deeply shocked by the shooting incident at the Libyan People's Bureau in London on 17 April. At that time the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs expressed the Government's concern. We are appalled at the apparent callousness of the Libyan authorities in relation to the incident, the misuse of the People's Bureau premises in London, and the abuse of diplomatic privilege. The Government calls upon the Libyan authorities to identify and bring to justice the person or persons responsible for the dreadful incident to which I have referred.

ANSWER.PARA: We consider the Libyan response to date to the crisis created by the shooting to be quite inappropriate. I have directed the Department of Foreign Affairs that the Libyan representatives in Australia should be told this directly. We fully understand the decision of the British Government to break off diplomatic relations with Libya. I have noted reports that the British Government may decide to call for a review of the Vienna Convention and diplomatic relations as a result of this episode. If it should do so, Australia would be willing to join in any international consideration of the problems which the shooting incident has revealed so starkly, but no one should underestimate the complexity of the issues and the difficulty in securing international agreement to any significant revision of the Convention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In view of the Government's overall intention to avoid contentious issues before holding a premature election, I ask a question of the Minister regarding his land rights legislation. The Minister will recall stating in this House on 16 November last year, in answer to a question in relation to his uniform land rights proposals, that he had 'discussed this matter fully with Mr Burke', the Premier of Western Australia. In a public statement last month Premier Burke stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Western Australian Government has told the Commonwealth not to interfere with the State's handling of Aboriginal land rights.

In view of that statement, does the Minister still intend to proceed with his planned legislation to impose uniform land rights on the States? If so, will he introduce that legislation before or after the next election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the timing of the proposed legislation, there has been a steering committee consisting of Aboriginal leadership and lawyers nominated by them which has been working on some of the legal concepts in respect of the legislation. I have assured Aboriginal leaders that we will not introduce any legislation until they have had an opportunity to consider it fully and discuss it with their Aboriginal communities. I have received a request from the steering committee for further time. I think the reality of that means that legislation as such probably would not be ready and could not be discussed effectively prior to the beginning of next year.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it extraordinary that members of the Opposition who lived with land rights legislation which created considerable problems not merely for Aboriginal land councils but also for the mining industry and who chose to do nothing about it for years should now be urging upon me a course against the wishes of the Aboriginal people. Perhaps the shadow Minister would do well to spend a bit more time talking to Aboriginal leadership. He would understand that this Government will respond to its demands and wishes and not to the yahoo behaviour of honourable gentlemen opposite.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Transport been drawn to statements made by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory that the Queensland Government will pay for a 1,600 kilometre rail link between Darwin, Alice Springs and Mount Isa? Has the Minister received any correspondence from either the Northern Territory or Queensland governments on this proposal? How does the Chief Minister's support of this proposal stand against his repudiation of the necessity to upgrade the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that on 14 July last year there was a joint announcement by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and the Premier of Queensland that they had decided to undertake a detailed feasibility study of a proposal to construct a railway line from Mount Isa to Tennant Creek, Darwin and Alice Springs. Honourable members may recall that at that time the Chief Minister said that a preliminary estimate had been carried out by the Martin Corporation Ltd, which is a subsidiary of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce , and that that preliminary study was very encouraging. The honourable member may be aware that also on that day the Premier of Queensland said that the cost of the proposal would be some $700m, that it could be financed by way of long term loans and that those loans could be serviced by freight revenues earned from the carriage of freight between Mount Isa and Darwin.

ANSWER.PARA: In specific answer to the honourable member's question, I have not received any correspondence in relation to the proposal from either the Premier of Queensland or the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. I have no doubt that, given the fact that some 10 months have elapsed since the announcement, the feasibility study ought to have been completed. It may be that the Chief Minister or the Premier of Queensland could make that report available. Certainly, they would have the Martin Corporation's preliminary assessment available. Perhaps that could be made available to the honourable member and other members of the House. Let me say in respect of the attitude of the Northern Territory Government to the upgrading of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin that here we have a supreme example of the double dealing style of the Northern Territory Government. In the Northern Territory the Government and its Chief Minister were parading the cause that the Stuart Highway ought to be upgraded. But down here in Canberra the Chief Minister specifically was saying that the Stuart Highway north of Alice Springs was quite adequate and did not need upgrading. Naturally, when dealing with applications for approval of projects on that highway, consideration had to be given to the explicit statements of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. In addition only a few days ago the shadow Minister for Northern Development said that he had recently visited the Northern Territory also and that the roads in the Territory were excellent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been up and down the road.

—That is right. He said they were excellent; he is confirming that. Those matters have to be taken into consideration. Despite that level of representation and despite the opposition of the Northern Territory Government to the upgrading of the Stuart Highway, the honourable member for the Northern Territory has made strenuous representations and efforts. He has worked very hard here to cope with a Northern Territory Government which is quite double dealing in the way it treats the people of the Territory. For instance, the Chief Minister said to the people in the Territory that he is king of the kids. There is little doubt that he treats them as though they are a bunch of kids. The Territorians deserve some better quality of government than that. They deserve better representation than that. For those reasons, as I indicated I would in debate in the House on 5 April, I acceded to the request of the honourable member for the Northern Territory to send an officer of the Department to carry out an inspection of the highway between Alice Springs and Darwin. That inspection was carried out between 9 and 13 April and, as a result of that inspection and the strenuous representations of the honourable member, I was pleased on 23 April to approve five projects for the upgrading of the Stuart Highway amounting to some $17m and bringing to $24m the work that has been approved on the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin. Thanks to the honourable member for the Northern Territory the people of the Territory will get a better highway system despite their Chief Minister.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. What additional controls does the Minister intend to impose upon pricing arrangements for the sale of coal to Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, we have never had any controls on pricing; so there is no point in trying to suggest that any additional ones could be imposed. The question we have always had to take into account is export control and that is the same aspect that we are now left with. However, the real issue in terms of export control-we followed our predecessors' ideas on this-is parameters. We set parameters in respect of the ability of coal producers to enter into negotiations so that they could come back to the Government and give advice of what they had been able to achieve within the parameters so that we could have intelligent export control from the point of view of tonnage negotiated. The great disappointment of the negotiations, which are not altogether completed because the Newcastle six group is still negotiating, is that those companies agreed to settle on prices without any Government approval. Also, with respect to the companies that attempted to get a better price, the Japanese decided to penalise them by reducing their tonnages.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a very sad situation. The coal producers had an obligation not only to the Government but also to the nation to honour the arrangements made with governments, both present and past, that they would try to adhere to parameters of pricing. If they had done so, I am pretty certain we would have got a much better price. If they had done so, the Canadians would also have supported us because they desperately needed a better price. But, certainly, once two producers caved in-one well in advance and the other whilst over there-the others had no alternative but to settle because the Japanese allegedly said to them that unless they settled, even at a reduced price, they might not get any tonnage at all. The result has been a disaster from the point of view of the coal producers having any ability to negotiate coal prices.

From my point of view the difficulty we are continuing to experience is the failure to get some co-ordination between the coal producers themselves. Study groups have operated in the last 12 months to discuss the problems and set the parameters. It appears that they were unable to agree amongst themselves. Recently, when I put forward at the Australian Coal Association Congress a proposition that we could have an advisory council in which they could all participate, including the representatives of the Queensland Minister because they need to be in it, at that stage it appeared to get a very good reception. But 48 hours later the Premier of Queensland said it was no good, that they would not participate. Subsequent to that, the executive of the Coal Association came to see me and said that its representatives would not participate either. That is the ridiculous situation they have got themselves into.

The point that we must look at which is worthy of note is that Japan is now paying the same price for coal and iron ore as it paid in the 1960s. That is how far down the track we have gone as a result of being unable to assist these people to negotiate effectively. It is a bit of a challenge now for the Government to develop a mechanism whereby future negotiations can be conducted in the national interest, and that would also be in the interests of the coal industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney- General. Is the Minister aware of a group calling itself the People's Coalition for Civil Liberties? Is he aware that this group is reputed to be a front organisation for Bob Santamaria's National Civic Council? Has the Minister seen literature put out by this group accusing the peace movement of being a communist conspiracy aimed at undermining the willpower of the Australian people ? Can the Minister assure the House that this group has no connections with legitimate civil liberties organisations throughout Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter was raised in the Senate on 1 May and I have had the advantage of discussing it with the Attorney-General. I understand that at a recent peace march somebody distributed a leaflet on behalf of the People's Coalition for Civil Liberties. Nobody has heard of that organisation before or since. It is deemed to be a fly by night group that cannot be identified. The Attorney-General, in answering the question, said that they were not legitimate. They had never been identified-

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General said that in the Senate. Perhaps I ought to phrase it another way to get it right. The Attorney-General said in the Senate that this group had no connection with any legitimate group. I think that is the position because, as I understand it, nobody has been able to identify any people associated with it and certainly it has not been possible to identify them with any cause that has been related to a genuine civil liberties activity in Australia.
—What is a legitimate group?

—A genuine civil liberty is not hard to identify if one looks at the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which mentions free speech, free assembly and matters of that nature. So when the peace movement was carrying out its legitimate exercise in a democratic way, saying what it should legitimately say, that the world should disarm, I think everybody would agree with that.
—Are you going to lay down the law as to what they can say?

—No. It is very interesting to see the anxiety of the Opposition . It seems to have a close association with this group which nobody else has been able to identify or find. Perhaps it is the Liberal Party of Australia under some other pseudonym.
—What will you do? Put us in gaol?
—No.
—We would never put you in gaol; you stay right there.

—As the Prime Minister said, the Leader of the Opposition is the most valuable asset we have. The operations of this group certainly have not been condoned by any civil liberties organisation. It seems to suggest that people engaged in demonstrations for the cause of peace are Marxist-Leninists. Certainly that cannot be accepted, even by the Opposition. The people who participated in that march came from all walks of life right across the world. I am delighted to note that the Leader of the Opposition nods his approval of these remarks. I have nothing to add except to say to the honourable gentleman that he has nothing to fear.

—Will the Minister representing the Attorney-General request his colleague in the other place to investigate and report to the Parliament on the circumstances surrounding an interview before the March election last year by the Australian Federal Police of the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition about his alleged possession of a Cabinet document of the then Government about the Middle East? Did the tape recorded interview show that the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition denied having possession of the document although it had been shown by him to a former staff member who was an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs? Did the Deputy Leader subsequently tell the Federal Police that he wished to change the transcript of interview and admit that he had the Cabinet document? Can the Minister personally give any information to the House on these matters?
—Was the right honourable gentleman referring to me?
—Yes.
—Did I say that I had certain information?
—You were interviewed by the Federal Police about a Cabinet document relating to the Middle East I understand.
—The answer is no.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Communications been drawn to the recently announced policy of the Opposition that foreshadows a sell off of the publicly owned telecommunications authorities to the private sector? What would be the consequences of such a policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. It is with the most weary sense of deja vu that honourable members have heard the Opposition announce its intention of again attempting to flog off Telecom Australia and, for that matter, any other public enterprise that is not chained down. It is a classic example of a sacrifice by what the Prime Minister has referred to on many occasions as a desperate Opposition at the altar of obsessive ideological purity. The Opposition had one shot at this when it was in government previously when it set up the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia but not even that inquiry extended as far as selling off Telecom's operations. However, the recommendations of that inquiry in respect of privatisation ultimately struck a fearful paralysis in the ranks of the then Government because some of its members, in those days concerned about country interests, realised the implications of privatisation.

ANSWER.PARA: In direct answer to the question, the consequences, of course, of such an insane suggestion, if it became policy, would be felt in the provincial and rural areas of Australia. That is where the benefit of a single publicly owned and socially oriented telephone network is seen. In fact, the internal subsidy operates in favour of rural subscribers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not read the policy correctly?

—I notice that the honourable member for Bennelong is interjecting. I recall statements by him on this matter making his position quite clear. I would have thought he would be the last one who would be able to dispute it. The subsidisation-this is the crunch-is made up from profits generated in what is known as the golden triangle-Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. It runs at $300m annually. I repeat that: The subsidy from urban to country subscribers exceeds $ 300m annually. Let there be no doubt that the aim of those obsessive so-called economic rationalists opposite is to reduce tariffs in urban areas at the expense of country and remote areas.

ANSWER.PARA: We are seeing in Britain and the United States at this time the same type of attack on the telephone system. I think it is necessary to quote from a story in the latest edition of Time magazine which was entitled 'Letting Loose Some Monsters'. Honourable members opposite ought to read it. It states:

True to predictions by many experts, telephone rates have gone up, by an average of 37%, since divestiture says the FCC. Price increases by Bell Atlantic , the holding company for telephone operations in six Eastern states and the District of Columbia, are typical. Its flat-rate charge for phone service jumped nearly 30% in Pennsylvania, the lowest monthly rate rising from $9.60 to $12.28. It has begun installing message-unit service in some areas, basing tolls on time and distance of calls. The company increased pay-phone charges from a nickel to 15c in the District of Columbia and from a dime to 25c in Delaware and Virginia. It increased directory-assistance charges throughout its area, ranging up to 35c in Pennsylvania and Delaware.

The crazy idea of selling off organisations like Telecom, if put into practice, would have the most dire effects on the rural community in this country. Fortunately for them it will not even be considered by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you looked at the State railways subsidies recently?

—The honourable member for Hume has interjected pretty regularly. I challenge any member of the National Party in this place to explain this matter to his rural electors. It is about time National Party members stood up to be counted on this issue. I find it very difficult to believe that National Party members could possibly support this sort of stupidity. They ought to have the decency at least to explain to their constituents how much extra they would pay in telephone bills if this harebrained idea were ever implemented.

—Is the Minister for Communications aware of the recent statements by Mr Myer, Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and Mr Whitehead, Managing Director, which imply that they are confident that the ABC will be given a second television channel and that it will be a part pay or radiated subscription television channel? Does this mean that the Government has already decided that the Special Broadcasting Service will be abolished and the 0-28 channel given to the ABC and that the commercial interest applications for a pay service have been rejected also in favour of the ABC? Has the Minister given the ABC management any reason to be so confident of either of these issues for them to speak in this way?
—The answer to all parts of that question is no.

—Has the Acting Treasurer seen a report which claims that the underlying rate of inflation gives no cause to rejoice? Will the Acting Treasurer indicate whether there is any substance to that claim, and what is the Government's response to the claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw that claim made in a recent financial newspaper headline. There is no substance to the claim, and I am going to have quite a bit of joy in explaining why there is no substance to the claim. The Government's response to the claim is one of astonishment and, if I knew how to spell the word, I would say 'incredulity' as well. I want to make it clear that this claim has been made in only one newspaper. I also want to make it clear that, as far as I can see, the fault does not lie with the journalist who wrote the article because the body of the article does not in any way justify the headline.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the facts, and I am grateful to the honourable member for Hunter for giving me this opportunity to tell him and the House what those facts are. When the Government took over the economy of this country we had an underlying rate of inflation, a legacy from the Liberal and National parties, of 11.5 per cent. Without any adjustments whatsoever for health insurance, and I emphasise that, because there have been some misleading statements from the Opposition front bench in particular, the underlying rate of inflation right now is 7.6 per cent. Even Acting Treasurers are supposed to be able to do their sums. If I deduct 7.6 per cent from 11.5 per cent, the conclusion comes to me that there has been a reduction of 3.9 per cent.

I understand that the honourable member for Hunter has at some time during the past been a teacher of economics. I believe that he would admonish me if I did not remind the House that another way of looking at the underlying rate of inflation is to look at the last quarter's rate and multiply by four. It is no wonder that the shadow Treasurer is pointing his finger at me because he used to enjoy doing that at times.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the occasional good quarter.

—On the very occasional good quarter. The Special Minister of State reminds me that it was the 'Lynch-pin'. If we multiply by four the unadjusted rate of inflation for the last quarter of 1.2 per cent-the March quarter-I believe it comes to 4.8 per cent. I am reminded that the December quarter rate was 2.4 per cent. If my sums are correct, if I multiply that by four it comes to 9.6 per cent. Even if we look at those statistics we find that there has been a reduction in the underlying rate of inflation of 4.8 per cent, and that, of course, is another cause for great rejoicing. Wherever we look, whatever the adjustments, whether they are for health insurance, food prices or whatever, there is every cause for rejoicing in the news that has been given to us.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go on and say that in the period ahead, as the Medicare adjustment leads to a lower rate of increase in the nominal wages growth through the wage indexation mechanism, it can be expected that there will be a further easing in the rate of inflation and a winding down of inflationary expectations. The reason for that is the successful introduction of the prices and incomes policy. I paid my tributes in this chamber last Tuesday to those who have been responsible for that. There is more rejoicing about that ahead for us as well. It is no wonder that honourable members opposite are seeking to avoid the facts. I have noted that the Leader of the Opposition and his deputy have also sought to spread the type of message that was in the headline-that the underlying rate is not one for rejoicing. It is, of course, not so unexpected that they should do so because they have a long history of distorting the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Communications: As reversal by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board of Directors of carefully laid ABC plans to centralise the scattered Melbourne facilities at East Burwood will cost the taxpayer at least $3m, has the Minister reprimanded the Chairman of the ABC, Mr Ken Myer, for this irrational course of action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government is not in the business of reprimanding the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, on this issue or any other issue. In respect of the specific matter to which the honourable member for Bruce referred , it is a matter which has caused concern to honourable members on both sides of the House. The views of the honourable member for Bruce are already on the record in the Waverley Gazette, an excellent newspaper which took the precaution of ringing me before it published what he said. That gave me the opportunity of correcting what he had said.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the decision by the ABC to defer the development at East Burwood has come a little bit late in the day. In fact, the honourable member for Murray, as the shadow Minister for Communications, has already raised this matter in the House in some detail on an adjournment debate. I responded to that speech by the honourable member and commended the views he put. I suggest that the honourable member for Bruce might take the time to have a look at those speeches, both from his side of the House and from this side of the House.

The present position is that the ABC has been requested, on the basis of all the representations made, to reconsider a decision which, and I agree with the expression of opinion in and outside this House, has come too late in the day, and that the development of stage 2 at East Burwood should proceed. That has been conveyed to the ABC and the ABC has been asked to give the Government a full report on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the Association of South East Asian Nations-sponsored resolution on Kampuchea at the 1983 United Nations General Assembly express support for the coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea, the CDGK? Are the Khmer Rouge forces of Pol Pot an integral part of that coalition? Did the fact that the Government did not co-sponsor the resolution, although it voted for it, reflect in part the Government's refusal to support in any way the genocidal forces of Pol Pot?
—Here comes Fred Astaire.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hello Ginger Rogers. It merely proves that Fred Astaire had no luck in his old age. The facts are substantially as included in the body of the question asked by the honourable member. However, I draw the attention of honourable members to the statement of foreign policy released earlier this week by the Opposition. It is a remarkable statement that shows that the scribe who cobbled it together, the honourable member for Warringah, has a sentimental attachment to old history because in it he says:

ANSWER.PARA: Through its treaty with the Democratic Republic of Vietnam, the Soviet Union is now able to extend its military power in the Pacific from air and naval bases in Vietnam.

That is an absolutely splendid statement from a hopeful Minister for Foreign Affairs except for one 'minor' fact: The Democratic Republic of Vietnam ceased to exist more than a decade ago. It is now the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. That is not a very good start for an aspiring Minister for Foreign Affairs. In the documentation released by the Opposition there is this bland statement:
Coalition support for ASEAN diplomacy on Cambodia . . .

There are no questions; no qualifications; no hesitation at all. In short, there is no policy and no independent judgment on the part of the Opposition. Whatever is done by others will be endorsed by them. We have a very close and friendly relationship with the ASEAN countries. It is productive and a great deal of exchange takes place on views which we share or we may share and on sorting out what may be differences. But the fact is we are determined to make our own judgments on policy. We will not allow others to determine what we are going to do. Yet this is clearly the implication of the statement of the Opposition.

In the statement before the United Nations late last year there were two assertions with which we had some difficulty. One referred to the increasing effectiveness of the coalition forces on the border between Thailand and Kampuchea. We have some reservations about that as a statement of fact. More than that, we have some concern that in diplomatic terms to identify and endorse that in the way in which the Opposition has may extend recognition to the Pol Pot elements of the coalition forces. We would not propose to be party to that. The Prime Minister has made that clear. I have made it clear. The Opposition's commitment in this way is extraordinary given the context of statements made earlier by the Leader of the Opposition when he was the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In December 1979 he said:
The Australian Government--
of course, I refer to the previous Government-
believed that to derecognise the Pol Pot forces would be interpreted as endorsing Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea.
That was the original version of the Opposition's policy. Ten months later in October 1980 the Leader of the Opposition was reported as follows:
The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Andrew Peacock, said today that Australia has taken a decision in effect to derecognise the Government of Democratic Kampuchea (the Pol Pot regime).

So he has now turned around and endorses Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea. This is not a worry. Facts were never terribly important to the people in the Opposition when they were in government. Mr Peacock went on:
. . . Australia cannot prolong its recognition of such a loathsome regime as that of Pol Pot.

Yet now the Opposition's statement extends de facto recognition by surrendering any independent exercise of judgment in the determination of what its foreign policy in government would be. I have another document here which I prize greatly. Copies of it are as scarce as dragon's teeth. It is a transcript of the question and answer sequence at the Press conference conducted by the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Warringah after they had released the Opposition's foreign policy. One realises why it is so scarce after one reads it. The following question was addressed to Mr Peacock:
. . . are you happy to fully endorse the ASEAN position which supports the Coalition Government or Coalition forces in Kampuchea, which include the Khmer Rouge?
Mr Peacock answered:
Yes it does include the Khmer Rouge . . . I give no specific endorsement to the Khmer Rouge.
The transcript continues:
Q. But ASEAN does?
Mr Peacock: Yes ASEAN does and I've always indicated that a differentiation so far as the Khmer Rouge is concerned.
The most splendid and memorable part of Mr Peacock's answer comes next:
I've met with elements of the Coalition down here and endorsed what they're doing. They've not of course been direct representatives of the Khmer Rouge or Pol Pot.

Thus the Leader of the Opposition was saying that it is all right for one to be a little bit away from those elements; it is all right if one stands, say, five feet from them. It is like being a little bit pregnant. That is totally unconvincing but this is the position of the Opposition. It just does not have any policy. How could the Opposition develop policies? How could it be realistic ? How could it be credibly and substantially informed on these matters? How could there be any reliability about them? Consider this: I have invited the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for Warringah, not once, but umpteen times, to take a briefing, presuming he has the appropriate security clearance-I believe he would have, or could get it if he did not-from the Joint Intelligence Organisation so that he would know something about the subjects he pretends to talk about. He says: 'Oh yes, that is very good. I would like to do that'. Then he does nothing. I suppose he is too busy watching colour television or whatever his predisposition is these days. I must say parenthetically that in terms of publicity he would make much more impact as a Foreign Minister than I could ever hope to do. Imagine Australia's best known but least successful importer of colour television sets as the Foreign Minister. They would have to have a diplomatic bag big enough to carry an elephant every time he came back into the country with his booty.

The Opposition has presented this pakapu ticket, and masqueraded it as foreign policy. The Leader of the Opposition vaingloriously tells us that he is the man to lead this country and asks us to trust him. Trust him to lead us where? It was revealed only a week ago that he is the man who secretly and deceitfully presided over Australian troops in the Phoenix operation in Vietnam, one of the most odious undertakings in the whole of that very odious war. He never told the Parliament of this country. Let honourable members recall that the Phoenix operation was where that grim terminology 'terminate with extreme prejudice' came from. Thirty thousand civilians were killed in the course of the Phoenix operation, allegedly because they were Vietcong sympathisers and supporters. No doubt many were, but the evidence incontestably is that many innocent civilians were killed. One will surely trust that the high standards of Australian troops, which we all respect, kept Australians clear of it, but why were they participating in this sort of odious, undesirable association when the Leader of the Opposition was Minister for the Army. Why did he get into this secret arrangement, deceitfully dissembling before the Australian public?

Members of the Opposition cannot make up their minds. They have no willingness to take reliable briefings on the facts. They have deceived and hoodwinked the Australian public in the past. Yet now they ask to be treated seriously. The Opposition is a shabby organisation and the public see it as such and will repudiate it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the answer of the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister representing the Attorney-General to my earlier question, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware that a former staff member is reported to have written a memorandum to the Department of Foreign Affairs saying that the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition had in fact been shown a copy of the Cabinet submission on the Middle East and that one of his present staffers approached the police to advise them accordingly? Did he deny having seen the admission, in a tape-recorded interview, and did he subsequently change his story?
—I would think the incident happened some time ago, not just prior to the last election.
—No, not immediately prior.

—But the first question was whether I had been interviewed. I want to make the point about 'just prior to the last election'. I did see a Federal Police officer. It arose on this basis: Questions had been asked in this House. I do not know what year, but it certainly was not last year.
—I only said 'prior to'.
—Well, how many years back do you want to go?
—You can go back as far as you like.

—I think it was in 1981 or 1982. Questions were asked in this House, not by me but by the then Opposition. The Opposition parties were in government. The police officer wanted to know how the Opposition knew so much about the matter. Certain questions had been asked at the time. I think I was accurate in saying to the police officer that I was overseas at the time the questions were asked. It seemed to be an element of surprise to him that I had not asked any questions. But it is true that, through subsequent questioning of him, I found out that a former staff officer of mine had reported to the police that he had seen the document in my office. That is true. The police officer asked me whether I could help him about it and I said that I could not and I was unable to. But the significant part of the question was that the government of the day thought there ought to be an investigation because of questions asked in this House. I am happy to be reminded of any interview that I had subsequently on television or anywhere else relating to this document. I am able to confirm that the document was sighted in my office.
—And you changed your evidence.

—I did not give any evidence. I did have an interview with the police. The interview went like this: 'Mr Bowen, can you help us with this document? It was reported that it was seen in your office'. I was not able to help the officer. I asked the officer why he had asked me. He said: 'Because of the questions in Hansard, Mr Bowen'. I said: 'I did not ask any'. He said: 'No, but the questions were obviously related to that document'. I said: 'You should ask the people who asked the questions'. I think he said that he had not been able to do that. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I commend the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence for the preparation of this report on the Horn of Africa. It documents many important matters concerning the recent use of aid in the countries of the Horn of Africa. The report has been referred by the Committee to the Jackson Committee to review the Australian Overseas Aid Program for its consideration of the issues raised in the broader context of Australia's global aid policy. The primary focus of the report concerns allegations about corruption, misuse and mismanagement of humanitarian aid from several donor sources in the Horn of Africa. In responding, I propose similarly to confine my remarks to these specific issues. Matters relating to broader policy questions, I believe, should be taken up in the context of consideration of the recommendations of the Jackson review.

SPEECH.PARA: Development assistance is an important part of Australia's bilateral relations with countries in the Horn of Africa, particularly Ethiopia and Somalia. Both these countries have low per capita income and are also net importers of food, and therefore there is a very important role to be played by aid in assisting the development process in these countries. However, I place very great importance on the efficient and effective use of the Australian taxpayer's money in the provision of overseas aid and claims that our aid is being misused need to be treated very seriously. I welcome the efforts of the Joint Committee to investigate such allegations in regard to the countries of the Horn of Africa and I accept its findings. I am pleased that the Committee was able to convey to the Jackson review its comments on these matters and also with respect to Australia's aid monitoring capacities in that region of Africa.

Food aid is the principal component of our aid to the Horn and I would like now to comment specifically on the Committee's findings on this type of aid. The Chairman of the Joint Committee, the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison), in presenting the Committee's report to the House on 1 March 1984, made reference to Australian food aid and drew attention to page 114 of the report which notes:

Australia's food aid contributions have increased signigicantly over the years. It is necessary on humanitarian grounds in view of the recent droughts and continuing refugee problem that relief aid be provided. Relief aid is justified where there is an urgent problem requiring attention, but its usefulness is only short-term.
The Chairman also drew attention to the Committee's findings, which said:

There is a danger in the long term provision of food aid only. Once established , unless there is potential or incentive for recipients of aid to produce their own food, aid becomes self-perpetuating and is very difficult to cut off.

I welcome and agree with this viewpoint, which I believe adds valuably and constructively to debate on this topic. I think it is worth noting a few points about Australian food aid and its use as a development tool. All recipients of Australian food aid are food deficit countries and most are also low income countries, with limited capacity to import food to feed their populations. Even under circumstances where there is a concerted effort by the country to eliminate the root causes of food insecurity, many of Australia's food aid recipients will have a continuing need for food aid for some time.

Australia, as a major food producer and exporter, will continue to receive requests to provide food aid to these countries and there will be a continuing need for Australia to respond, particularly to emergency situations. In those cases where Australian food aid is used in other than emergency feeding situations, we are endeavouring to improve its development impact. Our preference is that the food aid be used directly as food for work in development projects. Where the food is sold we require, wherever feasible, that it be sold at cost plus freight prices in order to decrease the disincentive effects of subsidised food sales on local food producers. The funds generated from the sale are then directed to development projects, preferably food security projects, in the recipient country.

As I have already noted, claims have been made about the misuse of aid from several donor sources in the Horn countries, namely: Misappropriation of food aid; food aid not reaching those in need; inadequate monitoring and the ineffectiveness of long term relief aid. In this regard honourable members may be interested to know the arrangements for this year's Australian food aid program to Ethiopia and Somalia. In the 1983-84 financial year Australia will provide Ethiopia with 16,000 tonnes of wheat. Some 11,600 tonnes of this wheat will be used in a food for work development project involving land reclamation and reaforestation. This project is an extension of a similar successful World Food Program project and aims to restore degraded land to productivity. The World Food Program has been contracted to monitor and supervise the use of this food and it is expected that the project will help to eliminate Ethiopia's chronic food shortage situation. The remaining 4,400 tonnes of wheat is to be used in projects more immediately associated with the current emergency. These projects will have developmental as well as purely relief components. It has been decided after consultation with the Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission that the food will go through the counterpart organisations of Australian non-government organisations operating in Ethiopia.

In addition to the 16,000 tonnes of wheat going directly to Ethiopia I have for the first time this year approved a food aid gift to three Australian non- government organisations for use by the Eritrean Relief Association in Eritrea. This assistance, which comprises 1,000 tonnes of wheat, 20 tonnes of high protein biscuits and 20 tonnes of whole milk powder, is provided on a humanitarian basis to assist those people suffering from drought and conflict in areas not controlled by the Government of Ethiopia. A cash contribution of $300, 000 has also been made through Australian non-government organisations for other projects of the Eritrean Relief Association to benefit disaster and drought- affected people.

In Somalia, Australia has been supporting an international effort to assist some 500,000 to 700,000 refugees resulting from the conflict between Ethiopia and Somalia. In 1983-84 we will provide 3,000 tonnes of flour, 3,000 tonnes of rice and 100 tonnes of high protein biscuits. These commodities have been requested by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and their use will be supervised by the World Food Program. Australia has encouraged UNHCR to use this food in supporting long term solutions to the resettlement of these refugees rather than relying on continuing relief support. We understand that the Government of Somalia has recently agreed to the resettlement of these refugees in Somalia, and are planning development projects for this purpose. In addition to this support for refugees I have also approved a further gift of 1, 000 tonnes of wheat to Somalia.

The honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), who spoke on the need for self-help projects when the Committee's report was tabled in the House, will be interested to know that this wheat will be sold in Somalia at cost plus freight prices, with the proceeds being directed to the Community Aid Abroad primary health care project to which he referred and which was recommended as worthy of support by the Committee. This project is funded by the Australian Government and will involve an expenditure of approximately $3m over 5 years.

In concluding, I would like again to welcome the Committee's report and the discussion it has encouraged concerning the effective utilisation of overseas aid resources in a part of the globe little known by the Australian community. I am particularly pleased that the Committee was able to complete the report in time for it to be referred to the Jackson review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) for his statement to the House. His approach of referring this matter to the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program is a sensible one. Allegations of misuse of aid should be properly reviewed, but this can be done only by a body endowed with the perspective, resources and judgment to look into it. The Jackson Committee is advantageously placed in this regard, and the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee has done a service to the Parliament in opening up the question.

SPEECH.PARA: The recurrent human crises on the Horn of Africa are the result of natural disaster and man-made catastrophe. The contribution made to human crises by the Soviet-inspired military upheaval is scarcely exceeded by the assaults of nature and the great drought. When these two destructive forces are joined together, they constitute one of the most tragic events in contemporary history. We too easily become accustomed to the pictures of human disaster which confront us almost daily on our television screens. We feel overpowered and almost paralysed by the enormity of the human suffering.

Organisations such as Oxfam, World Vision, Community Aid Abroad and similar organisations are pressing their view that a greater proportion of foreign aid should be given directly to the relief of the needy and destitute. Great as the work done by the international systems of emergency relief may be, unfortunately there still remain great gaps. This approach to meeting the here and now problems of human crises have to be balanced by the overriding necessity to prevent their compounding by a failure to take preventive and remedial infrastructure measures. Inevitably, infrastructure aid proposals run the gamut of destructive criticism. They are often long, drawn out and expensive. They are sometimes mistaken, but they are an essential constituent part of a responsible approach to aid.

I understand the difficulties any Minister faces in getting across the details of aid administration. I am sure that a balance has to be struck between bilateral humanitarian assistance action and multilateral action.
