The fact that international agencies will make mistakes and that there may be greater opportunities for corrupt misuse of aid does not remove the apparent necessity to use multilateral machinery to its maximum effectiveness. What the Jackson Committee has to say on this aspect could prove constructive and useful.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received letters from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) and the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 107, Mr Speaker has selected the matter which in his opinion is the most urgent and important, that is, that proposed by the Leader of the National Party, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The consequences for national security of the run-down in the Australian Defence Force particularly the Royal Australian Navy.
I call upon those members who approve the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, there is no more serious area of concern in the community at the moment than the general run-down in the Defence Force of this country and our inability to meet the task of that Defence Force as a result of decisions by this Government. Repeatedly in this House we have heard the apologia by the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) and other representatives of the Government as to why the Government is not really responsible; it is all a matter of the governments that went before it. That is just not good enough. Progressively, right across the area of defence expenditure, we have found that the Services are being prejudiced in a way that affects their ability to perform the task with which they are charged. It is an area which is of prime concern to all thinking Australians. While not one of us at the moment believes there is an imminent threat, the very actions of this Government, through its Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), have progressively alienated Australia from those with whom we need to be associated. They have distanced us from our Asian friends, removed us from contact with the great and powerful nation of America- and indeed with the traditional Western alliance-and have put the Australian nation in a position where it is more alone than it has ever been before. Tragically, it is only in circumstances of a major world war involving the super -powers that under this Government we could be confident of there being an ally by our side.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in those circumstances that it becomes even more important that we look at the structure and strength of each of the three armed Services, the function and operation of the Department of Defence, and whether this Government is allocating to the armed Services adequate resources to enable them to perform their tasks. Only a few weeks ago the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) highlighted in graphic and tragic detail the run-down in respect of the Australian Army for which this Minister and this Government have been responsible. We are all too sadly aware that in recent weeks there have been two crashes involving Mirage aircraft. We know there have been instructions from this Government, as a result of its Budget- pruning exercise, to reduce the number of hours of flight training. As a result of that reduction, flight training hours are now below the minimal level prescribed by the Chief of Air Staff; below the level of what we are told he has suggested to the Minister for Defence is necessary to maintain flying efficiency . I hope that the Minister today can assure the Parliament and the people of Australia that it was not as a result of the reduction of flying hours by his Government and his Department that these two accidents occurred. We know the very high quality and skill of members of the three armed Services. We know that it is not the fault of the men and women involved that this run-down has occurred. It is because over the last 12 months this Government and this Minister have bungled from one calamity to another.

We have raised this matter of public importance today because of the circumstances which arose last weekend at an Australian Naval Institute forum on sea power. The same sad story revealed by the matter of public importance concerning the Army is reflected in respect of the Royal Australian Navy. Of course, this Minister finds that he needs a catalyst to act. We all saw what happened with the Invincible when he so nearly alienated, totally, the relationship that we have with the United States of America in circumstances where our own fleet finds, so sadly, that its limitations are imposed by Government directives as to the amount of fuel it can use, steaming hours, and manpower restrictions about which I wish to speak in a moment.

So we had the Invincible incident. We have had a series of incidents where this Minister has found it necessary to be kicked in the backside before he is even prepared to respond. We had the same circumstances apply with respect to the new training lands. I am delighted to see that, as a result of the promulgation earlier this week, the Minister has at least got himself into a position where he recognises that there would be an impact in regions that would be affected by any sort of a takeover by the Services for military purposes. He has got himself into the position where he has acknowledged that there is an economic cost, and where there is an economic cost which will affect the people concerned he is prepared to declare that that area should not be proceeded with. Indeed, the statement was made, at long last, 12 months after the first notice of intention was proclaimed, that neither the New England nor the Bathurst areas would now be proceeded with for the range. We need to be specific. A number of areas are concerned and the Minister's statement this week, at long last, exposes to the people that the Government is prepared to have consultations with the people and will take into account the social and economic impact and, as there should not have been in the first place, acquisitions will not be processed in areas where there will be an adverse economic or social effect. Quite demonstrably, the criteria that I have been concerned about have now been met and presumably the Minister will now explain to the Parliament and to the people that those two areas will be withdrawn from further study as an artillery range.

The reason for this matter of public importance is that we see the Australian Defence Force as a total amalgam of three armed Services, the Navy, the Army and the Royal Australian Air Force. We believe that this Government has run down the Army and we have exposed it. We believe that the Navy is progressively being put in a position where, sadly, as the headline in the Sydney Morning Herald the other day stated, the naval deterrent is in doubt. We are told that the Air Force is having its flying hours reduced, and its ability to perform its functions circumscribed by decisions which are the product of this Government and no other.

First of all I want to look at that very excellent presentation by the Chief of Naval Staff who finds himself in an invidious position. If he stands up and speaks out as he should on behalf of those he commands and those he represents, he is called into the office of the Minister and told that he has been speaking in public. But in this area it is essential that those who hold senior executive responsibility are not told to keep quiet because this man and this Government have bungled. These are circumstances that go to the core of the preservation of the future security of every one of us. The threat that could so rapidly and easily develop was acknowledged by those who attended that Naval Institute seminar at the weekend. It is not that there is a threat now but that a threat could emerge. It is the same circumstance as so sadly happened in the Falkland Islands. Overnight, a circumstance the British were told would not happen did happen. The unexpected requires a state of preparedness. In his very excellent presentation, the Chief of Naval Staff identified Australia's principle national security interests as sovereignty, security of our overseas and coastal lines of communications, maintenance of good relations, reduction of tensions with other countries, particularly those in our region, and avoidance of global war. Sadly the third item has been prejudiced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs whose ineptitude in foreign affairs was so aptly demonstrated at Question Time today.

The comments by the Chief of Naval Staff were affirmed by Desmond Ball and Colonel Langtry of the Institute of Strategic Studies when they said it would be the height of foolishness if Australia were to adopt a military posture which did not give priority to holding and preferably destroying an invading force on the high seas or in the air before reaching Australia. So the necessity to build up a force and what is needed within that force was laid down by the Chief of Naval Staff. He pointed out the magnitude of the problem that faces Australia. He said that exports and imports were equivalent to about 35 per cent of gross domestic product. He pointed out that 207 million tonnes of cargo are carried in and out of Australia by sea each year; only 161,000 tonnes is carried by air. He pointed out that on an average day there are 195 merchant ships in our ports and about 175 in transit to or from Australia. He pointed out that shipping destined for Australia can be identified at least 4,000 nautical miles from our coast and on the Persian Gulf route at least 2,000 nautical miles away. Looking at the alternative of air transport, he pointed out that a Boeing 747, configured for cargo, requires almost two tonnes of fuel for each tonne of cargo carried. He identified the reason why we cannot rely on our present 95 per cent dependence on foreign shipping as a substitute for our own naval capability.

We come to the consequences of the shortfalls in the Services. He pointed out that we must have sufficient ships to operate around the coast, taking into account the extension into the 200 mile maritime zone, and the necessity of anti -submarine warfare helicopter support for our escorts. Sadly, this Government has pulled the plug from under our sailors. It has taken the teeth out of the Fleet Air Arm and left it with no bite. This Cabinet of bathtub admirals has steered the Navy into a position where it could not meet medium level contingencies, as, so sadly, the Chief of Naval Staff identified at the weekend. All this has happened under the guidance of a Minister with a rowboat mentality. Concerned with the cost cutting exercise in the three Services, the Opposition has identified the rundown in the Services. The Government has put us in a position, for the first time ever, where we must be significantly more able to defend ourselves and mount a level of self-sufficient defence than we ever have before.

What has happened? First of all, in the Royal Australian Navy, we have had a run-down which has led to the circumstance which the Chief of Naval Staff identified. I do not want to read his speech in detail because I have not time to do so. It is the decision on the Fleet Air Arm and the fixed wing capability, not the carrier decision-the Minister seems to fail to realise this-that has denied the present capability that this nation requires. It has taken away protection from the Bass Strait oil reserves. It has taken away an ability to mount the Tracker aircraft to survey our coastal approaches. It has destroyed the only self-sufficient aerial refuelling capability that this nation has, the A4C Skyhawk. The tragedy is that by removing those capabilities in both the A4s and the Trackers and saying, because of some prejudices that they have, that we cannot have a fixed wing Fleet Air Arm that we find ourselves not only without that capability but also unable to maintain an adequate anti-submarine warfare capability.

In my speech to the Naval Institute I identified the fact that we have eight Sea King helicopters without any combat unit able to support them. There is, through the merchants ships laid up, an alternative that could have been investigated. The Minister could have said: 'Look, we will bring some into service temporarily'. There are alternatives that he needs to proceed with as far as the overall ability of the fleet is concerned because at the moment the fleet has no organic anti-submarine warfare protection beyond the range of its ship-mounted sonars and they have a range of only about five or six nautical miles. Even conventional submarines can launch surface skimmer missiles with ranges of about 50 nautical miles. The Navy lacks any method of gaining long- range tactical intelligence from its own resources. Of course, without this intelligence, the fleet cannot exploit its new technology weapons like the harpoon. The Minister said: 'Oh, they can rely on the Orions'. The Orions are already overstressed. There are inadequate funding resources to provide crews. With their present limitations they cannot provide all the services, both military and civil, that are being demanded of them.

We find sadly that in relation to anti-submarine warfare capability the Minister has proceeded with a range of decisions that I find totally confusing. He failed to proceed with the expeditious acquisition of the light helicopters. I do not want to read through the statements but we were told that in January he announced that tenders would soon be called for the provision of new utility helicopters for the RAAF. As far as I can see, that means that the earlier announcement that he made in November last year, about acquiring helicopters for maritime operations, will be deferred until he has got a helicopter that is suitable for both Services. I am not sure whether he will spend the $18m allocated in this year's Budget or whether it will come out of the $50m which we are told will be available next year for capital purchases. In any event, we are told by the Department of Finance that the defence budget will be pruned by a further $600m in the next financial year.

Whatever the consequences, there has been a run-down in funds for new purchases , a run-down in fuel for the Navy, a run-down in flying time for the Air Force and a run-down in boots and every other form of equipment for the Army, but we find that the Minister does not come out and explain to the Parliament and the people just where he is heading. He does not take decisions which enable people to feel that at least they are being taken into his confidence. Indeed, he wrote to me on 4 April and explained that, because of various run-downs in the naval vote, postings were not proceeding; that he thought he might have fixed it all up now but, because of the pressure there has been on naval resources, a number of postings have had to be deferred. We were told by the Chief of Naval Staff that by 1987 the Navy will lose another 1,900 people.

All in all, the position is one of a sad indictment of the Minister and the Government. Defence is becoming a matter of concern in the community. The Minister should explain to this House where he is going and what he intends to do to correct the deficiencies. He needs to identify what he intends to do about our lack of anti-submarine warfare capability. He needs to address the shortfall that, sadly, the Chief of Naval Staff has identified. He needs to assure the people of Australia that we are not going to be put in a position under his Government that will leave us totally without protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are to believe the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) we would believe that it is possible to equip a defence force and change its entire structure in under a year. No current significant capability in the Royal Australian Navy has been acquired in under four years. The right honourable gentleman has a great deal of expertise in misrepresenting the truth and putting forward propositions in the nature of slogans which he knows he was not processing when he was the Minister for Defence and which he knows his Government did not support when it was in office but for which he believes he will win some short term shonky political points.
—You are the shonky political animal.
—Order! The right honourable gentleman will withdraw that remark.
—It was accurate.
—The right honourable gentleman will withdraw it.
—On your insistence, Madam Deputy Speaker.

—I think that we should understand certain facts. The right honourable gentleman was the Minister for Defence at the end of 1981-82, a year in which the defence vote was reduced by 1.9 per cent in real terms. In addition , funds to the extent of $180m, held in reserve for payments of late accounts in the United States, were added to the appropriations, with the result that in subsequent years money had to be found in order to meet the requirements--
—Because of the Invincible purchase. You know that.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party was heard by the House with courtesy and without interruption. I ask him to extend the same courtesy to the Minister for Defence.

—The funds had to be added to the defence vote and subsequently had to be met from current accounts rather than from funds put aside for that purpose. In fact, in the last three years of the previous Government, the real vote on defence was static; it did not rise. Members of the Opposition speak about the Fleet Air Arm and their concern about the Royal Australian Navy. Let us look at the facts concerning the way they actually treated the Navy when they were in office.
—A jolly sight better than you did.
—We have been in office for a year, my friend.
—I was Minister for about nine months, my friend.
—But the right honourable member was a member of the previous Government. I know that he repudiates his own Government--
—I invite the Minister to ignore the interjections. I invite the Leader of the National Party to take the advice of the Chair.

—I think that we ought to understand exactly what we are about in this House. We have a shonky Opposition which has decided to exploit the defence forces of this country, to demean the defence forces of this country, with some of the most disreputable statements I have ever heard in a defence debate in this Parliament.
—Why don't you answer some of them?
—I will tell you one thing: None of the things you said in your speech the other day has stood up; none of them is true. Your own colleagues are ashamed of you.
—Order! The Minister will address the Chair.

—On 8 April an announcement was made that Australia's fixed wing aircraft capabilities would be discontinued. The announcement was made in this House by the then Minister for Defence, Sir James Killen. HMAS Melbourne was tied up in 1982. No capability, either in existence or planned, would have enabled the Tracker aircraft or the Skyhawks to go to sea from that time. Their life of type is such that had a decision been taken to acquire a new carrier, capable of carrying fixed wing aircraft they would have been out of service before that carrier came into service. But the previous Government had no intention of maintaining a fixed wing capacity within the Royal Australian Navy. That was clearly stated by the then Minister for Defence and the then Prime Minister. The purchase of HMS Invincible was based on the premise that it would be an anti-submarine warfare carrier only and would be equipped only with helicopters.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Prime Minister stated categorically-the Leader of the National Party can repudiate him if he wishes; he has repudiated everyone else in his Government-that there was no intention to acquire a fixed wing capability for the Invincible. The facts are that the approaching obsolescence of the Melbourne was well known before she was tied up. It was well known to the Government and it was stated in the 1976 White Paper that that obsolescence would have to be addressed as a matter of urgency and a decision taken on whether to replace the carrier. It was also announced at that time that certain funds would be devoted to the defence forces of this country in order to overcome the backlog in capital equipment items-a backlog which still exists. In the four years after that announcement the deficit, on the promises made by the previous Government, was over $1.5 billion. The previous Government did not meet any of its promises. During the whole period in which it was in office the average increase in the defence vote was less than 2.5 per cent. The increase under this Government was in excess of 4 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.
—The right honourable member says that the figures of the Department of Finance are rubbish. He depends on a newspaper report.
—It is wrong, is it?
—It is incorrect. The right honourable member has chosen to use incorrect figures in a debate, just as his colleague chose to use gossip rather than facts.
—I raise a point of order. The Minister has said twice that information used in previous debates by me in this House was incorrect.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The honourable gentleman was the man who raised the subject of boots . No unit commander has been able to identify the problem which he raised. Also no unit commander has indicated that he raised the matter with him.
—In view of what the Minister has just said, I raise a point of order. The information that I produced in this House was given to me-
—Order! There is no point of order. If the honourable gentleman thinks that he has been misrepresented he will have an opportunity at the end of the debate to make a personal explanation.

—We also had in that debate the grandiose statement that the rifles which the Operational Deployment Force has are 20 years old. That is true. When we came into office they were 19 years old and the previous Minister planned to replace them in 1988. That was the timetable for replacement. So what is the charge? Is it that we are going to keep to his timetable and that his timetable was incompetent? Is that the charge the honourable member is making-that we are keeping to his timetable and that he had neglected defence? That would seem to be the position according to his statements.
—You prematurely retired them.
—What-the rifles? Wake up to yourself, George!
—The Minister will ignore the interjections and speak through the Chair.
—You are a man of high principle, aren't you?
—The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I resent the fact that I was called by a name that is not mine and I ask the honourable gentlemen to withdraw it.
—The Minister will withdraw and the right honourable gentleman will cease interjecting.

—I do not mind being called by my father's name but other people apparently object. We now have the right honourable gentleman suggesting that we have retired the rifles from the Australian Army. It is time that the defence debate revolved around the defence of Australia. It is time that the former Government acknowledged its policies, acknowledged its proposals and acknowledged where it was going on defence. It should stop this hypocrisy and misrepresentation that it was going to do this and it was going to do that.
—We did it and you know it.

—The honourable member did not do it and he knows it. The fact is that there is a bunching of capital equipment problems, because of the procrastination of the previous Government, which is causing serious problems within the defence vote and within the nation's economy. The previous Government did not make a decision on the aircraft carrier when it was supposed to be made. It put if off, put it off and put it off and eventually tied up the Melbourne without a decision having been made.
—We were going to buy the Invincible.
—It tied up the Melbourne without a decision having been made.
—We bought the Invincible. Do not mislead this House.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party continually flouts the instructions of the Chair. If he continues to do so the Chair will deal with him. I call the Minister.

—When the British Government offered to dispose of the Invincible at a bargain basement price, the previous Government jumped in after having previously rejected that design of carrier as unsuitable for the Royal Australian Navy. It did not actually buy the Invincible and it never intended to use the Invincible as a conventional aircraft carrier or for fixed wing aircraft . That is on the record. It waited and waited and waited. It tied up the Melbourne and thus made irrelevant the fixed wing aircraft which could only operate from that carrier. It tied Melbourne up before it made a decision on what it would do about fixed wing air power for the Royal Australian Navy. The FFGs were in service for over a year and the then Government had not even commenced to address the need for a helicopter to operate from those ships.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now faced with a situation, because of the incompetence, the delays and the failure of the previous Government to make decisions, in which it is quite possible that, in order to obtain an adequate platform, alterations will have to be made to the ships after they are built. This will be because the previous Government did not decide on and did not give consideration to the types of helicopters it would put on the ships before or during their construction. It procrastinated as it always procrastinated.

We heard a complaint the other day about the numbers of people available for the introduction of new artillery in the Australian Army. When we came into office it was vastly undermanned. We have increased substantially the number of people available in those areas. It should also be pointed out to honourable gentlemen opposite that, as with all their defence decisions, those guns are coming into operation three years after they were timetabled, because of their procrastination. The previous Minister for Defence made no decisions. He used his verbal capabilities to disguise his inability to make real decisions.

The other point about which at least some people in the Opposition are embarrassed, is whether the Opposition supports the need for training areas in New South Wales. We saw a lot of crocodile tears about the inability of people at Holsworthy to train properly. We even had an allegation that sections of the armoured regiments were denied the right to train together.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—That was true. That happened for two years before we came into office. We removed that restriction.
—That is not true.
—You were the Minister Assisting when the direction was given.
—The Minister will speak through the Chair.

—The former Minister Assisting was in that office when he refused for two years to allow the armoured regiment to exercise as a unit. We took away that restriction. I give due credit to the former Minister Assisting, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman). He was present when the need for exercise ranges was put in February 1982 to the Premier of New South Wales. It is my understanding that both he and the then Minister, Mr Killen, strongly put the case for these ranges. It was a decision of the then Government. It was a decision which was duly processed and it is a decision about which the incoming Minister, Mr Sinclair, was fully informed. But, with the prospect of an election in 1983, he ran away from his responsibilities as the Defence Minister because his own electorate was involved. He might tell this House now, especially as he has all the documentation, whether he declared to the then Prime Minister, as he did in this House this week, a personal interest in this-
—Yes, I did, as I did here in the House.
—Well, we have an interesting situation.
—You know that.

—That was two days ago. It is interesting that an area which personally involves the former Minister is one of the areas involved in a decison which, he acknowledged on Tamworth radio, he decided to hush up until after the election. We have in this Parliament the most shonky Opposition in the history of this country, prepared to go to any lengths to do any damage-
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 March we had a debate in this place on the Australian Army. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and I have over 40 specific charges. I will not deny that some of the charges that we made did result from the Administration that went before this one. But I am afraid that, having made that admission, by far the vast number of those 40 charges have their root cause in the things that this Government is doing. We listed problems in a wide number of areas including unit strengths, recruiting cutbacks, training restrictions, ammunition shortages, equipment deficiencies, accommodation defects, the Government's assault on the Army Reserve and cutbacks in conditions of service.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) has responded to only four of those charges and he was wrong on every count. Today he alleged that the previous Government had said that it would get rid of fixed wing aircraft. That is simply not true. In the defence statement on the Invincible, we said that there would be no fixed wing aircraft at that stage. But it specifically left open the option for COVL aircraft. I think it is disgraceful-he has done it again today- that the Minister for Defence has responded to these specific charges in a threadbare, ignorant and deceitful way. If this feeble deception and ignorance is not enough, now he is resorting to censorship.

On a number of occasions, including in this Parliament, I have drawn attention to the scandalous living conditions of soldiers at Ingleburn in New South Wales. I must say that I give the Minister credit for having now fixed that situation and for having allowed them to move into East Hills hostel. Well done on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long was that situation current? Was that a one-year program?

—It has been on this Government's books since October last year. I was challenged by the Willesee television team to prove my charges. They invited me to accompany them to Ingleburn to investigate that position.
—That is a lie. You set it up with them.

—Permission was refused to let the team or me visit or film the barracks in question. If the Minister wants to call me a liar, I will have a separate debate with him on that issue straight after this. He is telling lies and he knows it. Again, I applied to the Minister to visit the Fleet Air Arm station at Nowra. I wished to see at first hand what was happening there as a result of the Government's scrapping of naval fixed wing air support. The Minister has refused permission to let me go. We are now moving on from a no boots administration to a jack boots regime. It is humbug when it is initiated by a government which believes in open government.

SPEECH.PARA: But let me focus on the Navy and the decisions that have been taken by this Administration. The hasty decision to scrap the Fleet Air Arm represents another blow to our defence capability. It is also a stupid decision, not properly thought out, with wide ramifications in other crucial defence areas. The Minister wants to sweep the problem under the carpet but he cannot hide the truth. It has become clear that the Government's ill-conceived policy will have the following effects: It will expose our vital oil supplies in Bass Strait to catastrophic accident or attack; leave the Royal Australian Navy fleet without adequate air support; create serious gaps in our anti-submarine warfare measures ; lead to deficiencies in meeting fleet training requirements; be very expensive and wasteful of money; and reduce the capability of our aviation defence industry.

By the end of June this year, the Navy fixed wing squadrons of A4 Skyhawks and S2G Trackers will have disappeared. The process of selling them off will have begun. The most immediate and dangerous consequence of this decision is how it may affect surveillance of our Bass Strait oil fields, surveillance which is necessary to give early warning of, say, terrorist attack or wayward merchant vessels off course in the Bass Strait area. This critical national task was once done by Navy Tracker aircraft. On many recorded occasions they intercepted ships , on automatic pilot, set on a collision course with the oil fields. In December last year, Navy patrolling was stopped and the information I have is that the radar and communications which have been installed are inadequate and simply do not do the job. The Government has laid our vital oil fields, from which the bulk of our oil requirements flow, open to terrorist attack or accident.

Equally dangerous are the consequences for naval operations and Australia's defence capability. In war the Royal Australian Air Force is supposed to give the support that these aircraft now provide-fighter cover, distant strike ability, airborne early warning and anti-submarine defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Impossible.

—But it has become evident that these are very shaky additional roles for an already heavily committed RAAF. Now the essential roles of our 75 F18 aircraft will include not only our nation's air defence but also maritime and ground support to the Navy and Army as well. Given the fundamental complexity and breadth of these roles, the RAAF will be stretched to meet the task or, as my colleague says, it will find it impossible.

SPEECH.PARA: The RAAF's limitations become worse when the difficulties of undeveloped or inadequate forward bases, the serious prohibitions on mobility of support, maintenance and repair facilities and the inadequate or untrained support and transport systems are taken into account. The Hawke Government's decision to sell off the Fleet Air Arm will leave the Navy very vulnerable at sea. It will make the Navy's strategic role of protecting our trade routes and providing a credible deterrent very difficult. The proof of the pudding is now apparent in the RAAF's inability to meet the fleet's training and support requirements. Information available to the Opposition shows that the RAAF has supported only approximately 60 per cent of the fleet's requirements. It could be 50 per cent or lower. The other 40 per cent or more is still provided by the fixed wing aircraft of the Navy. When the Fleet Air Arm is sold off in June the RAAF will have to provide 100 per cent of all the requirements. On the evidence to date, it is highly unlikely that it will be able to do so. If it manages to respond to the Navy's requirements it will have to be at the expense of other essential tasks.

But it is not just a matter of the RAAF's difficulties in doing the job for the Navy. What it is trying to do is costing the taxpayers more money and is wasting the precious defence dollars that the Minister for Defence has talked about today. The Government claims that by getting rid of the Navy fixed wing aviation it will save $20m. But our information is that the Government will incur an additional cost of at least $10m. Fleet training requirements used to be met almost entirely by the Skyhawks and Trackers based at Nowra. Due to the location of exercise areas off Jervis Bay in New South Wales much of the substituted RAAF support is expensive or inadequate. What are the facts? The Mirage aircraft is at least twice as expensive to run as the Skyhawk. An hour is usually needed in the exercise area to work up the gunnery and radar training with aircraft. This can be provided by one Skyhawk sortie out of Nowra but, because of range and fuel limitations, it takes two or three sorties of Mirages or Macchis out of Williamtown.

Mirage and Macchi aircraft need to carry heavy fuel drop tanks which limit manoeuvrability and hence effectiveness. RAAF aircraft at Williamtown that become unserviceable just prior to nominated departure times cannot be replaced quickly because of long transit times and other commitments leaving ships on station wasting valuable steaming time already restricted by the Government. Time lost by aircraft not being on station as scheduled cannot be made up by increased time at sea because of these restrictions. So the story goes on but time does not allow me to demonstrate all the results. However, we know about the $10m extra expenditure. There is also the question of our anti-submarine warfare Sea King helicopters. Whilst they can and do make a contribution to fleet training from their base at Nowra, crew experience and training is being severely limited by not being able to be deployed at sea.

Another spin off of the decision is its effect on our defence industry capability. Because of the decision, Hawker de Havilland which is responsible for the maintenance of Navy Tracker aircraft has been forced to axe approximately 100 positions. It has also stopped taking on any apprentice airframe fitters. This means that almost certainly there will be shortages of airframe fitters in the next five to 10 years. At a time when Ministers in the Government are trumpeting about the need to have self-reliance in our defence industries they are reducing a very critical defence industry. All these problems have to be added to the points that the Leader of the National Party ( Mr Sinclair) made, the effects of decisions on reducing steaming times, naval strength and the starvation of the naval Reserve.

The final irony of the Government's self- imposed defence muddle was the Minister's reported comments in Malaysia during his recent tour. The Age of 26 April 1984 reported the Minister as acknowledging the threat of increased Soviet build up in our region yet the same Minister is hell bent on weakening the capacity and reliability of our Navy and Army. Australia was once one of the leading naval nations of our region. It has now dropped from the position of the most powerful regional navy 15 years ago to about the sixth most powerful. The Navy is unable to provide vital tactical reconnaisance, air defence and air strike at sea. In fact, it no longer can provide a credible deterrent or even a defensive force in our region. At the very time when the Minister for Defence is warning our South East Asian neighbours of the threat from the Soviet build up in the region and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) is braying to the world of the weaknesses of the ANZUS alliance the Government is hell bent on the criminal dismantling of Australia's naval strength.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For once-I hope for the last time-can we get very clear who the culprits were for putting the last nail in the coffin of the fixed wing element of the Royal Australian Navy? I recall a statement made in this House. This is not the first time I have referred to this statement. It appears I have to refer to it time and again to get across to honourable gentlemen opposite the real facts. In a statement made by the then Minister for Defence, a Liberal Party Minister, on 29 April 1982, we find:

SPEECH.PARA: The current commitments and the future of Navy's existing fixed-wing aircraft are being examined by a defence working party as a consequence of a government decision that these aircraft are to be paid off as soon as practicable to provide early savings in expenditure. It is expected that there will also be consequent manpower savings.
I repeat:
. . . these aircraft are to be paid off as soon as practicable. . .
That was the last nail in the coffin of the fixed wing element of the Navy. I do not want to have to come back to this House time and again to locate the responsibility for that decision.

There has been some reference today also to propositions about Navy activity. Again I point out-I will have to go very slowly so that it sinks in to honourable gentlemen opposite-that in the last four years of the Fraser Government operating expenditure for the Navy decreased. I am very happy now- although I regret that I have to do so-to give figures of the operating expenditure for the Navy. In 1979-80-these are December 1982 figures-operating expenditure for the Navy was $314m. In 1980-81 it had dropped to $309m. In 1981- 82 it had dropped further to $283m. In 1982-83 it had dropped to $276m. In fact, there was a total decline over that period of 12 per cent in the Navy's operating expenditure. Do honourable gentlemen opposite admit that under this Government, and contained in the Budget of this Government for the first time in four years, there has been an increase in the Navy's operating expenditure? The increase this year is over 2 1/2 per cent. That compares with a decrease of 12 per cent over the last four years of the Government of which honourable members opposite were a part.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a decrease in their capability.

—I shall take up the proposition that decreases in capability have occurred. Reference was made to the decrease in capability of operating expenditure. Let me quote again from the statement that was made back in 1982, and we are talking about the operating costs not only of the Navy but also of the other parts of the armed services. The then Liberal Minister for Defence said:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be reductions in programmed expenditure for operating costs. This will be achieved by continuing economies already introduced in this financial year. It will mean restraint in the level of some training activities and the cancellation of others. Other areas affected include travel, equipment repair and general administrative expenses;

I am quoting from the decision which was taken not very long ago by the Government of the day which is now represented by the Opposition. That Government talked about reducing operating costs. The then Liberal Party Minister for Defence went on to say:

Planned fuel and other stockpiling levels will be reduced and service activities, including Navy's steaming time, Army's utilisation of its armoured vehicles, and service flying hours, will be restrained. Each of the Mirage squadrons may have to specialise to some extent in either the air-to-air or air- to-ground role. This would demand less training time and weapons usage than at present, when all pilots train in both specialist roles.

Less than two years ago the Government, now the Opposition, made those catastrophic cuts in the preparedness of the Australian armed forces. We have sought since we came to Government to raise the standards and to provide more funds for operating costs. We did this immediately in the case of the Navy. We have sought, through other measures, to upgrade the preparedness of the defence forces of this country, which fell into such grave disrepute under the administration of the gentlemen who now sit opposite.

A whole series of other changes were made in the expenditure pattern for the Australian defence forces, as indicated in that catastrophic statement of 1982. It will take this Government a great deal of time and a great deal of effort to recover from those disastrous decisions that were made in 1982 by the Government , which is now represented by the Opposition. The then Minister, talking about the strength of the Navy, said:
The Government will not at this stage proceed with the acquisition of an additional five Fremantle class patrol boats and the second underway replenishment ship;
In regard to the Air Force, he said:

The long-serving Canberra aircraft, which are currently used in the aerial photographic survey role and other RAAF support tasks, will be paid off. Until a new aircraft is acquired, any requirement for these capabilities will be met by other means such as chartered aircraft;

They were setting up a sort of Pizza Hut franchise. They could not provide our forces with permanent assets so they had to seek to lease them. This was the defence policy that was run by the gentlemen who sit opposite. The then Minister also said in regard to the Navy:

The provision for expenditure over the next five years on follow-on destroyers will be reduced. The level of annual expenditure will be given detailed consideration along with the planned reforms at the Williamstown Dockyard;
Reference was made to anti-submarine warfare:
Planned expenditure for additional ASW helicopters has been deferred and program expenditure on other RAN and RAAF helicopters has been reduced.
Further, in regard to the Air Force, he said:
There will be a reduction in the level of refurbishment of the Mirage;
And again:
Many of the lower priority facilities and infrastructure developments have been slowed down or delayed.

We have this litany of decisions to cut and defer the necessary assets of the armed forces of Australia. These decisions were made by the honourable gentlemen who sit opposite. They were the guilty men. They were the men who cut into Australia's defence preparedness. They were the men who cut back Australia's security position by a whole series of decisions covering the Army, the Navy and the Air Force. They made sure that these decisions were going to live on. They made sure that the grave difficulties of any future Government in trying to organise the scheduling of future payments would be impossible to meet. They did this by the simple procedure of rescheduling debts, of not paying on time bills that were coming in for purchases that were taking place. So the honourable gentlemen who sit opposite now sought when in government to destroy-in fact, they nearly achieved this-the very basis of planning of the Australian defence forces. They are the guilty men.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) during a speech made a little while ago accused me, in his words, of peddling gossip in information I had used in debates in the last few weeks. The implication, of course, was that what I had said was at least inaccurate and possibly untrue. I should like to tell the Minister and the House that all the information I and my colleague, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman), have used has come from senior serving officers. I would be more than happy to tell the Minister in the privacy of his office exactly where I got the information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I too would like to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) on a number of occasions has misrepresented the situation which involved the visit by the Willesee television team and me to the Holsworthy Army camp in the Ingleburn area on 12 April. He misrepresented the situation in a letter he wrote which appeared in the Bulletin magazine last week. He misrepresented it in a Press statement which went out under his name, or under the heading of the Department of Defence. He misrepresented the situation today when he accused me of telling lies. Therefore , I would like to explain the facts of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I received an invitation from Mr Steven Rice of the Willesee television program to visit Holsworthy and Ingleburn Army camps to substantiate charges made in Parliament during defence debates. Mr Rice indicated that permission had been received from Army authorities for the team to make the visit. My secretary telephoned the office of the Minister for Defence and spoke to a Mr Michael Brown to obtain permission to go. My secretary explained the reason for the visit. Mr Brown asked that the request be put in writing. A telex was subsequently sent. I have a copy of it here. The important point was that the object was to meet an invitation by Willesee to substantiate my charges in Parliament. The Minister's office replied by telegram on 11 April 1984 saying that it would not be appropriate.

Upon receiving the telegram I telephoned the Minister's private secretary, Mr Brown, and explained that this put me in an impossible position. I told him that Willesee was to go and film the area with emphasis on my allegations, yet I was deprived of the chance to go also. I added that Willesee had informed me that the Minister would be there and I had made it very clear to the Willesee team that my visit had to be kept quite separate from the Minister's. I stressed to Mr Brown that I had informed the team that it would be quite irregular and improper for some sort of confrontation to be organised between myself and the Minister.

Finally, I informed Mr Brown that if the team still planned to go to Holsworthy on that day I felt I had no other course of action but to accompany it but would avoid any confrontation with the Minister. I asked that this information be passed to the Minister. There was no further reaction from the Minister or his office. On 12 April I travelled to Sydney and with the Willesee team went to Holsworthy and Ingleburn Camp. At the entrance to the camp the sentry was informed as to who was in the vehicle. We were allowed to enter and were directed to the parade ground outside the brigade headquarters.

On arrival at the parade ground I found that there was to be a demonstration and display for a fairly large Press contingent. Until that time I was not aware that any other Press had been invited to Holsworthy other than the Willesee team . In accordance with what I had told the Minister's office, I decided it would be best to leave the area until the Minister had left. I went to another unit in the brigade area where I had coffee and waited. After it had become clear that the Minister had left I returned to the parade ground and was interviewed by the Willesee team. I had then sought to take the Willesee team to the barracks area which I had condemned as being in appalling condition but I was prevented by military personnel, obviously on instructions from the Minister. The television team and myself were directed to leave the area, which we immediately did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been personally misrepresented.
—The Minister may proceed.

—The honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) has claimed that I acted improperly in refusing him permission to enter the Holsworthy establishment at a time when I was making an official inspection of that area. The request which came to me was for participation in a television program, and it was intended that a confrontation situation should take place at Holsworthy. I acknowledge that the honourable gentleman indicated that he was not prepared to take part in such a procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: It is, and has been, the practice for honourable members to be allowed permission to enter military establishments with the approval of the Minister and subject to its being convenient to the commanding officer of the base concerned. It is true that the Minister, if he so desired, could override the commanding officer, but that would be inappropri- ate. It is not, and has not been in the past, the practice of this or previous governments to give permission to persons to enter military establishments for the purpose of political stunts. That is what we are talking about. I should point out that--

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to the Minister that he not debate his case. He should just put the facts before the House.

—I point out that I have given permission to many members of the Opposition individually to enter the Holsworthy establishment, though I think it would be appropriate if, on occasions, they could visit together and save some of the commanding officer's time. Nevertheless I will continue to give that permission. I will not, however, act in a way which creates embarrassment for the people running those establishments by involving them or their establishments in the day to day politicking in which we engage. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that during the previous election campaign the former Minister refused me permission to enter HMAS Albatross. I have no problems about an honourable member visiting any military establishment providing he is not doing so for a political purpose, to involve the base in political activities.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the Committee's reports on proposals for variations of the plan of lay-out of the City of Canberra and its environs-(1) 81A Series, and (2) 82nd Series-1st Report, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The first report I have just tabled on the 81A series of variations to the city plan covers only one item and relates to the proposed development of a hotel-convention centre and office space by White Industries Ltd. The Committee approves the variation but it is most concerned about the traffic problems and lack of car parking facilities in Civic which will result from this and other future developments. To overcome the traffic problems, the Committee recommends that the traffic lights proposed by the National Capital Development Commission be established before the first stage of the White Industries development is completed and that traffic lights also be provided at the intersection of Akuna and Bunda streets in the same time scale.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the significant additional demand for car parking facilities in Civic which will be generated by the White Industries development and other proposed developments the Committee recommends that the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of Territories and Local Government address themselves urgently to accommodate the additional demand by implementing a range of measures. The Committee was also concerned that it was approving this variation while a number of major aspects of the White Industries development were still unclear. Accordingly it is requested that it be briefed on the development when the project arrangements have been finalised.

The other report I have just tabled covers three items from the 82nd series of variations to the city plan and recommends the approval of work valued at $8.15m . Variation 15 is concerned with changes to roadways in Chisholm to provide a shopping centre at Chisholm in accordance with the revised strategy for local retail centres in Tuggeranong, which include the development of a town centre. The release in May 1984 of a 4,000 square metre group centre at Erindale and the proposed group centre at Chisholm are the first steps in the implementation of this strategy. The building of a 4,000 square metre shopping centre at Erindale is a radical change from a previous proposal by the NCDC for an 18,000 square metre commercial centre at Erindale.

This was examined by the Committee and reported on to the Parliament in the 79th series of variations in August 1983. The Committee was told then by the NCDC that it would be at least 10 years before the necessary pre-conditions existed which would enable the construction of a town centre to commence. Because of the severe shortage of retail space in the Tuggeranong area the Committee agreed to the Erindale proposal although it had some misgivings about approving it. The Committee has now been told, only six months later, that there have been substantial changes affecting the Erindale centre proposal and that the town centre will now be built.

In the light of evidence given in the 79th series the Committee is surprised and disturbed that it was not formally advised of the major changes to a proposal it had agreed to only recently and on which it had reported its findings to the Parliament. The Committee believes that in order to determine whether Parliament as a whole should be advised of such changes the Committee should be formally briefed of any major changes to recent proposals on which it has reported to the Parliament. The Committee can only reiterate its concerns expressed in the 79th series report about the ad hoc nature of planning decisions in Tuggeranong and the delay in the provision of retail facilities. It can only be hoped that the decisions which have been taken now about the retail structure for Tuggeranong will provide a firm basis for planning and will ensure that retail facilities are established quickly and as required. The Committee therefore approves the variation to provide access for the Chisholm group centre and urges that the site be released for public auction as soon as possible.

Variation 2 provides an addition to the city plan of roads to enable an area in Hawker to be developed for housing. Objectors to the proposal were concerned about the T-junction which would be constructed opposite their properties to provide access to the development. In response to representations I made to the NCDC as the local member on behalf of some objectors to the proposal it was stated that:
. . . if the Joint Committee does not support the Commission's proposed access to Murranji Street the subdivision could be modified slightly to delete it.

When clarification was sought of this statement the NCDC claimed that the statement was incorrect and should not have been included in the letter. It claimed that access to the subdivision as proposed in the variation could not be modified as had been stated in the letter. The Committee recommends that further consideration of this variation be deferred until the NCDC explain fully why incorrect information was included in its letter, and whether in fact the variation can be modified to delete the proposed access from Murranji Street. When this information is provided the Committee will reconsider the matter. The Committee approves variation 15, which is concerned with the development of 544 residential blocks at Lyneham.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I willingly rise in support of the comments of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry), the Chairman of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, in relation to the National Capital Development Commission. Throughout the two reports that have been tabled there are some quite alarming matters which ought to be brought to the attention of the Parliament. In my view the reports highlight very much the difficulties that exist in terms of the relationship between the Committee and the National Capital Development Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal firstly with the eighty-first plan of variations-the 81A series- that is, those proposals relating to the review of the convention centre in Civic. The Chairman of the Committee has drawn attention to the problems of parking and design. The report of the Committee has emphasised the lack of community involvement in this important project. We have now reached the point where the revised plans by White Industries Ltd for office buildings and an international hotel and convention centre are proceeding, but they are now likely to proceed without being referred back to the Committee for its comment before commencement of that project.

The Committee had this project before it because of a minor road variation concerning Nangari Street and, not wanting to hold up this important development , the Committee has approved of the road variation in its report. Quite frankly, the Committee was in an impossible position. The White Industries development is important to Canberra and is a project that needs to be facilitated, but already it has been delayed too long. That delay was occasioned by, I think, the Government's pique that the project was planned and arranged by the former Liberal-National Party Government and as well by the determination of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to have a casino included in it. After all that delay, I think it would have been unreasonable for the Committee to hold up this project even though I anticipate and I think the Committee anticipates that there will be significant changes in the design.

The report of the Committee emphasises the dissatisfaction of its members with the fact that, having approved of all the road designs of a particular development, the development can undergo rather significant changes without reference back to the Committee unless the change affects another road design. The members are more likely to read about the proposed changes of design in newspapers than to receive detailed briefings unrelated to modification and variation of Canberra's roads. The fact is that we are now seeing significant detail about the building design-new models and new arrangements-of that project in the newspapers of Canberra. The Committee is unlikely to be briefed about them except in the terms in which it was on the last occasion. Of course, it was told then that that was not a final design.

I think it needs to be understood that significant changes have been made in the design. We were told formerly that there were to be soft curves and it was to be a very pleasant building integrated into parkland. Now we are told that there are to be very significant changes. I regard it as quite extraordinary that I had to read about the significant dimensional changes for the city in a newspaper article in the Canberra Times to be briefed on it. It is extraordinary that the White Industries development, cited as a grand and daring scheme and one of the largest private enterprise architectural projects in Australia, can be prepared and dealt with in such a closet fashion. It may well be that the buildings that are planned by White Industries will have a classic design, as suggested in the newspaper, with civic order and that they will be essentially horizontal with greater architectural merit. It may well be that Constitution Avenue needs to have a certain civic dignity in the buildings placed along it and that the framing of the edge of the expansion of Civic is an important architectural exercise. But surely the public, as well as the Committee, should have been able to comment on any new proposals which replace the well received curves and sweeps of the original design. The Committee has drawn attention to the need for it to be involved in major planning questions, not only in relation to road designs but also when important decisions are being taken, and I think that is important.

That is not the case at the moment. I think it is a very poor state of affairs that very important reports-the White Industries review in relation to the NCDC, the Committee's own report on planning and the work of the Administrative Review Council-have not been taken into account and responded to fully by the Government to indicate the way in which the Committee is going to be given a role in these very important matters.

The other report tabled by the honourable member for Fraser relates to the very important plans for extending retail facilities in the Tuggeranong Valley. These were contained in the eighty-second series of variations. Some other matters were also covered in the report, relating to facilitating land development. The Committee has approved of the plans in relation to Lyneham and deferred the proposals for Hawker.

The Committee looked particularly at the facilities for retail shopping in Chisholm in what is called a group centre. In that context the Committee also discussed the planning for the Tuggeranong Valley generally in relation to retail matters. The Committee has emphasised in its report the rather ad hoc way in which planning has been proceeding in the Tuggeranong Valley. It is, quite frankly, a sorry saga of changes and revision to the retail strategy in the valley that is revealed by this report. It was not so long ago that the Committee was asked to report on the proposed Erindale shopping centre. Plans were produced firstly for a centre of something of the order of 6,000 square metres. That later rose to something of the order of 18,000 square metres. The Committee approved of a development for 18,000 square metres and presented a report to the Parliament in August 1983.

Some members of the Committee had reservations about that, and I was one of them. Senator Reid, the honourable member for Gippsland, Mr McGauran and I presented a dissenting report. We asked that the developments in the Tuggeranong Valley be staged and that further consideration be given to the development of the Tuggeranong town centre site. The members of the Committee who dissented were roundly condemned by the Commissioner of the NCDC, Mr Tony Powell, in a rather scathing letter critical of the staged development concept that he wrote to the Chairman of the Committee. That letter was sent in September 1983. One of the reports which has been tabled quotes at length from the letter outlining the reasons why the Commissioner said that the development should take place at Erindale. The Commissioner said that the suggestion of staging the development was unacceptable and that there was no prospect of the Commission coming to the view that the Tuggeranong town centre should be developed at any time within the next 10 years, and for that reason to meet immediate shopping needs the Erindale Centre should proceed to be built to an enourmous size. In the way in which planning seems to happen in the Tuggeranong Valley there was another immaculate conception six months later when we were told that the Erindale Centre was to be reduced in size from 18,000 square metres as proposed to something of the order of 4,000 square metres. We were told that that development was to commence on the town centre site and that the development was to be put into the hands of a body called the Canberra Commercial Development Authority. It is extraordinary that within such a short period changes of that order could take place. The Committee is quite restrained in using language such as that planning is ad hoc. It is a disgraceful situation that a committee of the Parliament can be treated in such a way. It is tantamount to treating the Parliament in that way.

Evidence to the Committee in relation to the Tuggeranong town centre site appears to be that the development is being pressed because of a conviction in the mind of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority that a proposal to make it a much larger size will work. This Authority is not a private enterprise body; it is a government statutory authority. The Authority's judgment that a scheme of this size will work is not supported by private enterprise in the Australian Capital Territory.

It was clear in the evidence given to the Committee that the National Capital Development Commission did not want its professional reputation tarnished by accepting responsibility for the nature of the decisions that had taken place in this instance. It did not want to put its reputation on the line. It made it very clear that it was relying on the judgment of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority. I am concerned that the development of the town centre site in Tuggeranong is to be placed in the hands of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority. It is a discredited body. This has been revealed in many reports tabled in the Parliament, which have been left largely unanswered. I have had a question on the Notice Paper for some time now relating to the performance of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority. I asked that question of the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) some five months ago and it has been left unanswered. I think it ought to be noted that the question I asked on 7 December was in the following terms:
(1) Did the Canberra Commercial Development Authority enter into a sub-lease on 27 April 1983 with Myer NSW Ltd for a term commencing on 16 October 1978.

(2) Did that sub-lease contain a clause (3) (a) (i) which expressly provides that a minimum annual rental should be paid by equal monthly instalments in advance from the date of commencement of the lease, and on each month thereafter .
(3) Did Myer NSW Ltd (a) fail to pay rent for 11 months and (b) make the first instalment payment of rent on 25 September 1979.
(4) Did the sub-lease unlike other sub-leases entered into by the CCDA not contain a provision providing a penalty for late payment of rent.
(5) Why did the lease not contain a penalty provision when other leases did contain such a provision.
(6) How many sub-leases in the Belconnen Centre do not have such a clause imposing a penalty for late payment.
(7) What action was taken by the CCDA to recover (a) rent, (b) marketing fund contributions and (c) outgoings, when in arrears.

(8) Did the agreement for sub-lease, referred to in the sub-lease, and entered into by the CCDA and Myer NSW Ltd, and not on the public record, in relation to payment of rent, varying the sub-lease rental provisions as contained in the registered sub-leases.
(9) Did any other document between the parties, and not on the public record--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. As there is no reference whatsoever to the Canberra Commercial Development Authority in either of these reports, this opportunity should not be used to have an inquisition into the Authority. It is quite irrelevant to these reports.
— I believe there is some relevance in the point of order. I ask the shadow Minister for Territories and Local Government to bear that in mind.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I wanted at least to draw honourable members ' attention to the importance of this question. I will terminate reference to that question. I realise that it was of some length, but the last part disclosed that something in the order of $1m was involved; I think that was the point. It does go to the commerical competence of this organisation, and that question remains unanswered.
—It is not relevant, either.

—I hope that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) and the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Howe) will take up with their colleague the reason why a question involving $1m of public moneys and the commercial competence of an organisation like the Canberra Commercial Development Authority can be left unanswered. Surely important questions about the commercial competence of a government statutory authority about to undertake a multi- million dollar development cannot be left unanswered for that amount of time? The fact is that the CCDA is the organisation which the Minister has announced will undertake this development which has been the subject of quite considerable criticism in the Committee report and which relates to the planning question to which I have referred. At the same time that the Minister announced that this body will undertake the development of the project in the Tuggeranong Valley he has indicated that he will launch an inquiry into the financial viability of the CCDA to undertake the development.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been criticism from the honourable member for Fraser's constituents, from North Canberra interests, that the diversion of funds from the Belconnen centre operated by the CCDA may be necessary to ensure the viability of the Tuggeranong development. I would like to know what it is about the CCDA that has prompted the Minister in the first place to have a secret financial study undertaken. Surely the Minister's decision was based upon some report-possibly from the Treasury. It may have been the Department of Finance-and that report has brought about this investigation. I think the Minister for Territories and Local Government has the responsibility to come clean with the Canberra community and the Parliament to ensure that all information available to him about the viability and the conduct of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority is made public and that the future and proper retailing development in the Tuggeranong Valley is handled in a way which one can describe as an honest and an open approach to decision-making.

This report of a Committee of the Parliament reveals in the clearest terms that in relation to planning in the Tuggeranong Valley the Authority has been anything but honest and anything but open. The Committee's report reveals that there have been changes and about-turns, and that special interests-I put to honourable members that the CCDA is one of them-have been influencing planning in that valley way beyond any other proper interest. I think it is important that there be a much more honest and open approach in relation to these matters, that decisions not be made in a closet way, and that important inquiries such as the financial study I referred to not be undertaken in secret, without the Minister issuing Press releases that would at least make clear what he is in fact doing.

These reports are very important. One might not think so when they are brought in and characterised as proposals for variations of plans for the lay-out of Canberra and its environs, but they relate to the very heart of Canberra, to the way in which the city is to be planned and to its future. I think it is important that the Parliament continue to take an interest in scrutinising these matters in the closest possible way and that honourable members will join with me in seeking to have a far more satisfactory relationship develop between the Parliament, its Committee on the Australian Capital Territory and the National Capital Development Commission so that we can have a real say in the way in which planning takes place in this city.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill is not the most exciting piece of legislation ever to come before this chamber. However, it is a piece of legislation which plays an important part in Australian life, and it is legislation which ought to be explained in terms which the lay public can understand. It has been said that every profession is a conspiracy against the lay public, and the legal profession is no different. In the case of this Bill we can strip away a bit of the legal jargon which is usually used in the explanation of such Bills in order to explain to the people of Australia just what an important piece of legislation it is.

SPEECH.PARA: The Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill is a Bill about how Acts of Parliament are to be interpreted by judges. As everyone knows, however clearly one expresses oneself, however plain one's words, it sometimes happens that in a particular context those words can be interpreted in more than one way. Everyone , especially members of this House, has had the experience at some time or another of having words quoted out of context or of having some quite plain and simple remark totally misunderstood because the person hearing the remark started the conversation with a completely different set of beliefs and information from those of the person speaking. As an example of how these ambiguities and absurdities can creep into otherwise apparently simple statements, generations of school children have been vexed by the proposition that Charles I walked and talked half an hour after his head was cut off, only to have their teachers triumphantly explain to them that if only they had put in a semicolon after 'talked' the proposition would have made sense. Similarly, there is a story, which may or may not be true, that before the battle of Pydna the Greeks consulted the oracle at Delphi as to whether the Greeks or the Romans would win. I notice that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones ) has started to take an interest in my remarks. He will correct me if I am wrong, but I think the battle of Pydna was in 168AD. It is said that on that occasion the oracle replied: 'The Greeks the Romans shall overthrow'. The Greeks put the comma in the wrong place and went into battle quite confident that they would win. They did not. The Delphic oracle, however, could not lose. Since unlike modern judiciary or modern public servants it did not have to make written reports, it could always claim that the comma was in a different place from the place it was understood to have been in by the Greeks.

When such gremlins, such ambiguities or absurdities, enter into a case before the courts, quite serious damage can be done. This damage might concern the life or liberty of a citizen or it might concern large sums of money running into hundreds of thousands or even millions of dollars. One recent instance of the latter was the case of the South Australian Commissioner for Prices and Consumer Affairs and Charles Moore Australia Limited. That case arose as a sequel to a hot political dispute in South Australia. It involved a dispute between the two Houses of Parliament in that State. Legislation had been introduced into the lower House to impose credit controls over a wide range of organisations. The Legislative Council, the upper House, wanted to remove from the range of the legislation such large stores as Myer and David Jones. As often happens in these cases, the dispute was resolved to the satisfaction of the upper House and an amendment was introduced to give effect to the agreement which had been reached. However, when the issue came before the High Court it refused to look at extrinsic material such as the nature of the agreement which had been reached between the upper and lower Houses and ended up giving an interpretation to the Act which was the opposite of what Parliament had intended. That is not how the court would have interpreted it if it had, in accordance with the provisions which will be legislated for in this Bill, looked at the second reading speech of the Minister or other parliamentary material.

It all happened because of a presumption the courts made that Acts of Parliament should be interpreted according to certain principles of statutory interpretation, which in that particular case excluded looking at the intention of the Parliament. The courts have a number of aids which they habitually use in statutory interpretation. As I said before, every profession is a conspiracy against the lay public, and the legal profession's main tool of obscurantism is jargon. It carries this to a fine pitch by couching most of its jargon in Latin, so many of the aids to statutory interpretation are in fact expressed in Latin maxims which go by such names as ejusdem generis, noscitur a sociis and generalia specialibus non derogant.

TALK.START.PARA: —De minimius non curat lex is not to be forgotten.

—I do not know whether the Hansard writer is able to take the Latin just quoted by the Minister for Science and Technology but I am sure it can be fixed up in the long run.
