The maxims I just quoted involve such exercises as looking at the word to be interpreted in the context of the words surrounding it in the Act-that is, staying within the context of the Act-or looking at a particular word in the context of a list of words of the same category in which it appears in the Act, still staying within the Act and not going outside it to look at external materials. Another legal maxim used, which I think has a certain air of irony about it, is ut res magis valeat quam pereat, which means roughly that the courts should interpret statutes so that they make sense. These sorts of aids to statutory interpretation are undoubtedly useful to the courts, but when they are relied on, as they were in the South Australian case, to exclude a look at the extrinsic material, in particular the widely known and understood agreement between the two Houses of Parliament in South Australia, they can lead to the court applying an interpretation to a statute which is the exact opposite of what the Parliament intended. It hardly needs to be said that, given that the Parliament is elected by the people to express their mandate, such a result can lead to a subversion of democracy. Of course in this case only the wishes of the upper House were subverted. There are plenty of worse subversions of democracy than that. However, the principle still applies.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention another case, this time one which involved the liberty of the subject . This was Sillery's case, a highly publicised case in 1980 which followed an attempt by a person to hijack a Trans Australia Airlines flight carrying 41 passengers between Coolangatta and Brisbane. The gentleman concerned had with him a loaded sawn-off shotgun and with this he attempted to terrorise the flight crew. As a result, the aeroplane had to follow a flight path which had not been authorised, and eventually it managed to land down wind in the wrong direction. No harm was done to anybody but the lives of the people in the plane, as well as those of many of my fellow citizens of Brisbane who lived beneath the flight's path, including a number of my constituents, were imperilled. What happened in that case? Section 8, sub-section (3), of the relevant Act said:
Punishment for an offence against this section is imprisonment for life.

The problem for the courts arose because in all this sort of legislation such punishments are treated as maximum punishments. However, for some reason this particular statute did not say that it was a maximum penalty. While the behaviour of the gentleman in question did not exactly evoke sympathy from either the public or the courts, nevertheless the trial judge in Sillery's case seemed to think that there were mitigating circumstances which called for less than life imprisonment. However, in interpreting the statute that court and an appeal court in Queensland felt that they were bound by the provision, which they took to be mandatory, of life imprisonment. The fact was that Parliament had not intended the provision of life imprisonment to be mandatory. It was obvious from the second reading speech of the Ministers who had the carriage of the Bill in the House of Representatives and in the Senate that it was intended to be a maximum penalty, not a mandatory penalty. They said so explicity in both the House of Representatives and the Senate.

The High Court of Australia pointed out in this case that since the provision appeared to apply to trivial as well as serious offences, there was enough ambiguity for the Court to have a look at extrinisic material such as the intention of the Parliament. The High Court, in particular Mr Justice Murphy, who was a trail blazer in this area of the law, was prepared to look at the debates, in particular the second reading speeches of the Ministers who had the carriage of the Bill in each House. As a result, the matter was referred back to Queensland for re-sentencing and the provision of life imprisonment was not taken to be mandatory.

This was a case where the liberty of a citizen was at risk simply because the lower courts were relying on a rule of statutory interpretation which excluded reference to extrinsic materials in the circumstances of the case before them. Obviously the liberty of citizens should not be subject to arbitrary restrictions the legislature never intended to impose just because it is judicial practice not to look at parliamentary proceedings. Neither should commercial transactions which Parliament intends to regulate in a certain way be regulated in precisely the opposite way just because it is not judicial practice to take into account information available to everyone familiar with the area. This Bill permits judges to depart from the judicial practices which might lead to such results. For that reason I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill which seeks to amend the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. Many of the amendments contained in the proposed legislation are technical in nature. There seems to me to be little point in my going into those in great detail. However, there are two matters to which I want to refer in this debate. The first matter was dealt with at some length by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells), who has just resumed his seat, and that is the use of extrinsic material in aiding the interpretation of an Act of the Parliament. I want secondly to touch briefly on the changes contained in the Bill which relate to references to the male and female gender.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the provision which will permit courts to make reference, in interpreting statutes, to extrinsic material other that the Act of the Parliament is a reasonable provision. Under clause 7 of the Bill the courts will be permitted to use this material to confirm the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of the particular piece of legislation or in cases where the meaning of a provision in the legislation is obscure or where the ordinary meaning appears, on an ordinary interpretation of the Act, to be manifestly absurd or unreasonable. Among the sorts of material that the courts can look to to assist in the interpretation of the meaning of legislation are documents that are printed by the Commonwealth Government Printer, reports of royal commissions, the Law Reform Commission and of similar bodies, reports of committees of the Parliament, any treaty or international agreement that might be referred to in an Act, explanatory memorandums relating to the Bill, the speech by the Minister responsible for the carriage of the legislation but not speeches made by other members, any document declared by the Act to be a relevant document for the purposes of the section and also relevant material in the Journals of the Senate and Votes and Proceedings of the House of Representatives or official records of debates in the Parliament or either House of the Parliament. That is contrary to what I said earlier. It really means that matters referred to in debate by members other than the Minister can be referred to by the court.

I want to make a number of points about this. It is really an admission of future failure on the part of the Parliament to suggest that we will approve of legislation which might have meanings which are not very clear or are obscure or any ordinary reading of them. So, it is an admission that we may not be perfect. I think that is a reasonable kind of admission. One of the unfortunate facts of life is that we have so much legislation coming through the Parliament. Parliament is like a sausage machine churning out Bill after Bill after Bill. Branches of departments want to be seen to be doing something and the best way to be seen to be doing something is to produce legislation. Sometimes we place too much value on legislation; we think it is the answer to all of our problems. There are occasions when perhaps the Parliament would be doing a service to the community if we did not produce a particular piece of legislation. I will not go into any examples of that but perhaps individiual members could think of some. It concerns me that by producing so much legislation and so many regulations and statutes we are making life so complex for people. In that sense we are taking away freedom from individuals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every time we approve legislation.

—That is probably right. Every time the Parliament passes legislation there are provisions within it which, to some extent, restrict the freedom of some individuals. Obviously, sometimes we give rights to people but, usually, when we give rights to some people we take rights away from others. It is unfortunate that we have so much legislation. This places such a burden on the parliamentary draftsmen. At times I feel sorry for the parliamentary draftsmen because of the pressure of work placed on them. If one has been a Minister one can see the pressure that they work under to produce legislation at very short notice. Cabinet committees meet and ask for certain changes to be made to Bills to be presented that day in the House. There is enormous pressure upon those responsible for producing legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the new provisions, which would allow courts to look beyond the legislation to decide what the meaning and the intention of the Parliament really was, will not lead to sloppy drafting. I think there is that danger in this kind of provision. The draftsman might say: 'All right, I am not sure what I should be saying here but I will put these words in. Anyway, the courts can look to other material'. So the words of the statute may not be as impotant as perhaps they used to be. I hope that sort of attitude is not adopted by those who carry the responsibility. It would certainly be most unfortunate if that sort of approach occurred.
The other point to which I wish to refer is the question of gender. I think that clause 11 is an absurd provision. It is headed 'Rules as to gender and number'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it say?
—It states:

SPEECH.PARA: In any Act, unless the contrary intention appears-
(a) words importing a gender include every other gender; and
(b) words in the singular number include the plural and words in the plural number include the singular.

I am not so concerned about paragraph (b). However I am concerned about paragraph (a). The point was made by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) earlier in this debate that this kind of provision is wasting the time of the Parliament. We have the absurd situation of these radical feminists, who I suspect are behind this measure, being so uptight about the use of the English language in these sorts of ways. The honourable member for North Sydney mentioned the cowboy and cowgirl situation. The cowgirl will have to become a cowperson. However, the problem there is that the cow is the female gender of the species. The cowgirl would have to become a beef person or something like that. I detest the word 'spokesperson'. I think it is a dreadful word.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a mandate?

—Mandate is another problem. What should the word 'human' be? Should we say 'huperson'? Human seems wrong; it must seem wrong to the feminists. I think that these sorts of provisions can lead to absurdities. At the moment, the Acts Interpretation Act provides that the word 'he' includes the word 'she'. So when one refers to 'he' that includes 'he and 'she'. Now we will be able to use 'he' and 'he' will include 'she', or use 'she' and 'she' will include 'he'. It seems to me that this is doubling the sexism aspect. It is not taking away the sexism aspect. At the moment we just use 'he' and that automatically includes 'she'. Now we will be able to use 'he', which includes 'she', or 'she' which includes ' he'. Can honourable members see the point I am making? That doubles the amount of sexism contained in our legislation. In the future the draftsmen will say: ' Which word will I use? Will I use ''he'' or ''she''?'. I am sure that Senator Ryan will want to use the word 'she', which will include 'he'. This is getting to an absolutely ridiculous stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot understand why there is a need for this kind of provision. The radical feminists are all uptight about it at the moment. I think that it is an admission of their sexual inadequacies or something else that they have to take this sort of action. In some respects they seem to want to diminish the differences between the sexes. On other occasions they want to emphasise the difference between the sexes. In this case they want to emphasise the difference . They want to use 'he' sometimes and 'she' sometimes to emphasise that we have the two genders. At other times they do not want to see any difference between the sexes; they want a unisex society. A lot of nonsense is spoken in this regard. It is about time we woke up to what is going on. It is ridiculous when we get to the stage that people are feeling so insecure and so inadequate about their sex and what their sex stands for that they get all uptight about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —When it comes to sex, are you adequate?

—I am pleased to announced that my sixth child is due at any time. I think that I have proved my adequacy. That is a matter of which I am proud. If the honourable member wishes to make a personal explanation, he can do so later. I believe most of the other provisions of the legislation with which we are dealing are reasonable. I do not object to the other provisions. I think the provision whereby the courts can use extrinsic material will assist them in the interpretation of statutes, although some danger is involved. I hope that the Government will reconsider clause 11 of this legislation. I hope that the Government will have another look at it. I believe that it is absurd. I agree with the honourable member for North Sydney that we are wasting the time of this Parliament on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill seeks to amend the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to facilitate, inter alia, the giving of effect to the intention of Parliament when Acts of parliament have to be interpreted. It will provide the courts with greater scope in understanding the intentions of parliament when interpreting the law and will encourage resort to extrinsic materials to make clear that intention. The Bill contains 18 new provisions for insertion in the Act. Some of those amendments will be substitutes for existing provisions. I intend to confine my comments largely to those parts of the Bill relating to the provision for the use of extrinsic material as an aid to statutory interpretation. Because my colleague the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells), in his excellent speech, adequately listed a number of precedents showing the absurdity that can result when courts are unable to pursue Parliament's real intention, I shall not comment on those precedents.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is about statutory interpretation. Interpreting the law often involves making the law. To the extent that judicial interpretation is about exercising judicial power, it is the exercise of power by appointed officials potentially acting inconsistently with the will of the people as articulated by their elected representatives. Thus it is absolutely crucial that the Parliament takes appropriate steps to ensure, so far as is practicable, that the judiciary interprets the law in a way that is consistent with the real intent of the legislation. For example, tax avoidance litigation is perhaps the most obvious manifestation of the courts seeming to be out of touch with what the Parliament intended when passing particular legislation. The thrust of this legislation is not new. The literalist approach of the Barwick High Court was only one factor in the pioneering of section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act which was enacted by the present Opposition. That section provided:

In the interpretation of a provision of an Act, a construction that would promote the purpose or object underlying the Act (whether that purpose or object is expressly stated in the Act or not) shall be preferred to a construction that would not promote that purpose or object.

That Act was passed by the present Opposition. It was supported by Senator Durack and the present Opposition parties. A further section of the Act went to the matter of extrinsic materials. It set out to prevent the use of extrinsic materials in terms of statutory interpretation. It is important to make the point that when this matter was considered in the other place the then Attorney- General, Senator Durack, implied very strongly that at some stage in the future provision would be made for legislation providing for the use of extrinsic material. Before discussing the contents of the provisions relating to the use of extrinsic materials, I pay tribute to my colleague the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi). On 2 April 1981, he addressed the following question to the then Treasurer, Mr Howard:

Will the Treasurer now consider an appropriate amendment to oblige Australian courts to alter their canons on the construction or their interpretation of taxation laws so that such laws are applied in accordance with the intent of this Parliament?

Subsequently, the legislation to which I have just referred was enacted. The honourable member's important suggestion resulted in pioneering legislation. I think that it is incumbent upon this House to pay tribute to his pioneering work . A number of criticisms have been made of the legislation. One of the important catalysts for the criticism was an editorial in the 2 April 1984 issue of the Sydney Morning Herald. That editorial implied superficiality in terms of the legislative provisions. The editorial also stated:

The question is whether greater fidelity to Parliament's will is achieved by directing the courts to seek the purpose of legislation and widening their categories of documents they can call in aid in this search.

As most honourable members would be aware, that is clearly an erroneous interpretation of the legislation. There is nothing in the legislation that makes it mandatory for judges to seek out the categories of information that this legislation makes available to them. It is an option that they may exercise if they so wish, but it is not mandatory. To that extent the Sydney Morning Herald editorial was erroneous.

What is this proposed new section about? Proposed new section 15AB (1) and (2) provides for the use of extrinsic material in the interpretation of legislation. It provides for the consideration of material not forming part of the Act but which is capable of assisting the ascertainment of the meaning of a provision of the Act. As I have indicated, it is not mandatory; that is, the amendment provides that reference to extrinsic material may be made. The provision in no way contemplates the use of extrinsic material to overturn the ordinary meaning of a provision arrived at by taking into account the purpose or the object underlying the Act unless there is an obscurity or something that is manifestly absurd or unreasonable. Of course, that provision addresses the very issues raised by my colleague the honourable member for Petrie when he listed a number of precedents where quite clearly the administration of the laws in this land were prejudiced by judges being unable to go to extrinsic material.

The provisions in the Bill do not restrict consideration to only documents referred to in the second reading speech of the responsible Minister. I notice that the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) subsequently clarified that aspect in his contribution. To the extent that the Sydney Morning Herald editorial implied superficiality, it is important to make the following comments : The legislation is the result of extensive consultations and discussions that began in 1982. There has been full opportunity for debate, discussion and consideration of all points of view including, of course, a major symposium on statutory interpretation conducted by the Attorney-General's Department and attended by many distinguished Australian and overseas guests.

The method by which courts interpret statutes is very much a matter for parliamentary concern subject to possible constitutional limitations on Parliament's power to give directions to judges. The use of extrinsic material will better protect the courts from criticism but their decisions are inconsistent with the intention of Parliament as expressed by Ministers in debate. It is also worth adding a couple of names from those who attended the symposium to which I referred. The opening address was, of course, given by Senator Peter Durack, then Attorney-General. The learned Lord Wilberforce, well known in judicial circles, addressed the symposium, as did Senator Gareth Evans, Sir Maurice Byers, QC, Dr Gavan Griffith, QC, Mr Justice Lionel Murphy and so on . The list of registered participants reads like an honour roll for those involved in these matters. So the argument of superficiality simply cannot be accepted.

A specific restriction to material referred to by a Minister in his second reading speech would involve restricting access by judges to relevant reports. There is no such restriction in the existing law. It has long been established that the courts can look at relevant reports that preceded the enactment of legislation. The Bill does not open up the flood gates upon the material which a judge could, in his discretion, take into account.

Proposed new section 15AB (1) proposes limitations on the way in which extrinisic materials should be used. The provisions make it clear that extrinsic materials can be looked at to confirm the ordinary meaning of an Act. Extrinsic material would be used to overturn the ordinary meaning of a provision only where there is an ambiguity or obscurity or something that is manifestly absurd or unreasonable. It is an established practice of judges. No legal limits are placed on the categories of materials which judges can look at if they think that they are relevant and can be used consistently with proposed new section 15AB (1). To this extent the reaching of a satisfactory outcome in the use of extrinsic materials would depend on the good sense of both judges and the Parliament. In the longer term they will need to combine to produce a situation in which the range of materials and the way in which they are used is reasonably defined and confined. Proposed new section 15AB meets these requirements in a way that respects the independence of the judiciary. In addition, under proposed new section 15AB (3) the courts are specifically directed to consider the desirablility of persons being able to rely on the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of the provision taking into account its context in the Act and the purpose or object underlying the Act. The legislation also directs the courts to avoid prolonging legal or other proceedings without compensating advantage.

I will conclude by making a couple of brief comments with respect to matters raised by the honourable member for Braddon. He adverted to the gender provisions of the Act. I simply refer him to a report tabled in this House yesterday by the Institute of Family Studies. A reading of that report may indicate to the honourable member that society is changing. Some of the findings of that report indicate quite massive shifts in public opinion on a whole range of attitudes that people on the other side of the House tend to assume remain constant. One of the implied findings of that report in this context is that people may be taking different attitudes to things like the use of non-sexist statutory provisions.

The honourable member also adverted to the potential for sloppy drafting by parliamentary draftsmen. That is an absurd proposition to put. Who in this House would seriously imply that the highly capable draftspersons in this country would not discharge their duties adequately simply because judges may have access to material other than the actual legislation? That is not something that I take seriously.

There is one other aspect of the Act that I should comment on before concluding my comments. It is often said that someone was not born yesterday. The reality is that under our system of common law-this is High Court dicta-people are at law in a sense born yesterday. Under the ordinary meaning of a birth date, if someone turns 21 on 1 July one would assume that he turns 21 immediately 1 July commences. But under our system of common law that is not the case. He would turn 21 the day before he has his birthday. So in fact the old saying about not being born yesterday applies to most things except the way common law interprets that. Certainly that change must be commended. I am surprised that the Opposition in its desperation did not find something to complain about with proposed new section 25E of the Act. I have covered most of the criticisms that have been made of the provisions. I thank the House for its indulgence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated, the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill is designed to update and modernise the legal system and in particular to make statutory interpretation simpler, more efficient and relevant to the present day. All members who have contributed in this debate have referred to proposed new section 15AB, the provision to permit courts to have access to a wider range of extrinsic aids to interpret the provisions of an Act. In relation to that provision, there has been bipartisan support, as in fact there has been for the Act. The honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) dealt in some detail and very adequately with some of the criticisms of that proposed new section but I think it is worth reiterating very briefly that the proposed new section provides that if any material not forming part of the Act is capable of assisting in the ascertainment of the meaning of the provision of the Act, consideration may be given to that material . This provision has been favourably received by leading jurists and legal bodies since it was introduced in the other place on 8 March.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note that in this provision, as has already been indicated by the honourable member for Maribyrnong, the word used in proposed new section 15AB is 'may' and not 'shall'. That is to say, reference to such materials is not to be compulsory but is to be left to the discretion and the judgment of the courts. As indicated, it is pleasing that there is bipartisan support for the Bill and I would merely like now to conclude by thanking all those members who have contributed to the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duffy) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: WEIGHTS AND MEASURES (NATIONAL STANDARDS) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking today on the Weights and Measures ( National Standards) Amendment Bill I represent the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), the Opposition spokesman on science and technology, who is currently overseas on business in connection with his shadow portfolio. We are talking about amendments to weights and measures legislation. In other words, we are talking about metrication. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill describes the Bill and its purpose. It is to create a hierarchy of standards of physical quantities consistent with both modern and international practice and to clarify the functions and powers of the National Standards Commission in the light of modern technology, existing and in the future. Under section 51 (xv.) of the Constitution the Commonwealth has power to make laws in respect of weights and measures. As a result it established the National Standards Commission in 1948 and the principal Act under which the Commission operates is the Weights and Measures (National Standards) Act 1960.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Standards Commission is responsible for establishing and co- ordinating the use in Australia of a uniform system of units and standards of measurement of physical quantities and for approving the pattern of measuring instruments for use in trade to ensure accuracy and reliability in service. I will say more about that aspect later. In this era of rapid technological change the States have looked to the Commission to play an increasing role in matters such as the promotion of uniform principles in State legislation relating to trade measurements and the use of units of measurement in the packaging of goods . Trade measuring devices presented for pattern approval have increased in complexity and have often integrated with other devices such as computers.

The Bill proposes and its purpose is to give legal effect to the increasingly important role undertaken by the Commission in the new age of technology. The Metric Conversion Board was established under the Metric Conversion Act in 1970 as a transitional body to promote, help and guide conversion from the imperial to the metric system of measurement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not have put it better myself.

—It is interesting that the Minister of the future says that he could not put it better than I. I am grateful for that compliment. Conversion was substantially completed by 1980 and appointments to the Board expired in 1981. The remaining conversion activities relate, we are told, to industries reliant on long life equipment, such as heavy engineering, and those industries influenced by international agreement such as aviation. I will say more of that later and put my views on how it should be administered. The Bill provides for the transfer to the National Standards Commission of responsibility for these residual metric conversion activities and for the repeal of the Metric Conversion Act 1970.

SPEECH.PARA: The functions of the National Standards Commission are set out in proposed new section 18. Under proposed new section 18 (1) (e) one of the functions of the Commission is to examine and approve patterns of instruments to which I referred a moment ago. The proposed new sub-section gives the National Standards Commission the duty of approving new measuring devices. It is interesting that we have just debated the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill because the functions of the Commission are to examine and approve patterns of instruments. The plain English is really measuring devices. The pattern of an instrument, as I have said, is the design of a measuring device and it is sent to the NSC for approval. Once approval has been granted production begins and the States carry out inspections to test the accuracy of the measuring device once produced.

The NSC keeps Australian primary standards of measurement which are the most accurate standard for a particular measure. Reference standards of measurement are kept by major private or public companies to calibrate their measuring devices and are verified against Australian secondary standards. Reference standards are less accurate than State primary standards which in turn are less accurate than Australian secondary standards which are less accurate than Australian primary standards. I hope the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) is listening. There are 32 Australian primary standards and these are the legal measurements for weights, length, electricity, time, frequency, et cetera. Regulations are produced under the Act for each standard with detailed information and designation. Legal units of measure are reviewed and the list is revised at intervals. For instance, the present list will be changed, I understand, on 1 January 1985 when a number of units will be withdrawn. I hope that when they are withdrawn what is occurring in practice in the market place will be taken into account. The Bill amends the Act to allow for contracts signed in legal units of measure to remain valid if the legal units of measure are subsequently withdrawn from the list of legal units. It should be noted that contracts can be signed in any units of measure provided there is no legal challenge. If there is a challenge the case cannot be heard until those units are changed according to legal conversion factors.

One interesting aspect is that the standards of most measuring devices have to be aproved. However, there is no legal requirement for speedometers installed in motor vehicles to be approved. It is not illegal to use non-legal units of measurement or non-approved measuring devices for personal use, but trade instruments, such as petrol bowsers, butcher's scales, et cetera have to be approved by the National Standards Commission and measured in legal units before they can be used in commercial transactions. The petrol bowser, for instance, through which petrol is sold, must have its measuring device and design approved by the National Standards Commission and its operation to measure petrol in litres inspected by State authorities to ensure that correct quantities of petrol are dispensed. Gas, water and electricity supplied by public utilities are measured by approved devices under this legislation. Those devices are checked at intervals by reference standards kept by the relevant utility.

It is interesting to note that whilst gas, water and electricity are covered and their measuring devices have to be approved-people who own homes and carry on business pay rates according to the meters that are used to measure the amount of gas, water and electricity they use-the telephone is not covered by any standards. Perhaps this explains some of the problems that my constituents and those of other members have when something goes wrong with the Telecom Australia meter and they get phone bills they do not understand for calls they have not made. The devices used to meter telephone calls are not approved by the National Standards Commission. There have been calls from time to time for control of telephone metering by an independent authority but to date no action has been taken anywhere in the world, I understand. I would welcome the comments of the Minister and his views on this point. The metering of telephone calls does not seem to be standardised and no measuring device is proposed by Telecom.

Not all industries in Australia have completed the conversion to metric measurement. Some which are covered by international agreement will not convert in the short to medium term. I ask the Minister to ensure that in the administration of this amending Act and the mother Act there is practical understanding in relation to interpretation and that those charged with the responsibility of ensuring that the standards are adhered to take into account what is happening in the market place and the convenience of the people of Australia, of customers of businesses, and of businesses themselves. It is important that they understand that legal imperial units of measure are still kept and may in fact be kept for many years or even for decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forever.

—Or forever, as the honourable member for Moreton says. There is a generation gap in our society. Many Australians will always use measurements, such as feet and inches, which they understand and with which they are at home. I know that this legislation does not cover what happens in the home. However, I think those administering the legislation have to realise that large segments of society understand and still think in terms of imperial units of measures.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that, for instance, the aviation industry-there would not be a more modern industry-still utilises feet to measure altitude and will continue to do so because it is covered by an international agreement. As a result, the foot is kept as a legal unit, and no doubt the honourable member for Moreton is happy about that. In shipping, speed is legally measured in knots and distances are measured in nautical miles. Inches are still legal units since United States -built engineering equipment is imperial and requires threads of screws and diameter and length of bolts to be measured in inches. This must be clearly understood by those administering the legislation.

In December 1978 the import of non-metric measuring devices was halted to help metric conversion. That may have been an overreaction. An example of banned devices was rulers with dual metric and imperial markings. These bans, however, were lifted in 1981, and the honourable member for Moreton will be pleased because I think he had something to do with that. I congratulate the honourable member for that. While metric devices are still required for trade uses, no ban has ever been in force on the private use of imperial devices, nor should it be. In January 1984 the Minister for Science and Technology, who is at the table, stated that metrication of Australia had reached its final stage, and a recent conference of State and territorial Ministers agreed to delete the remaining imperial and outdated metric units from the use of Commonwealth legal units. I will not quote what the Minister said on that occasion. It is interesting that in July 1981 a Press report claimed that complete metric conversion of the building industry was being held back because house builders and home handymen were still able to obtain imported imperial measure items and a local manufacturer of nuts, bolts and fasteners was considering reconverting to imperial measure to compete against imports. This is the type of problem that those administering the legislation have to understand clearly.

International standards for metric units are amended occasionally to provide for increased accuracy of measurements. The original definition of the metre-I know the Minister has a great interest in this-born of the French Revolution, was one ten-millionth of the distance from the North Pole to the Equator. This definition was later found to be wrong and in 1889 the true metre became the distance between two scratches on a platinum-iridium metre bar, housed in a vault beneath the International Bureau of Weights and Measures in Sevres. In 1960, the metre was defined as equal to 1,650,763.73 wavelengths of orange light emitted by the gas krypton 86. Late last year the standard was altered again so the metre would be the distance travelled by light in a vacuum in 1/299,792, 458th second. It is interesting in relation to the definition of a metre that on 15 December 1983 the Minister made the following announcement:
The metre is the length of the path travelled by light in vacuum during a time interval of 1/299,792 of a second.

I know that the Minister is very good at answering $64 questions on quiz shows. Some people listening to this debate may have seen the 60 Minute program which showed film of the Minister answering questions in quiz shows-I think on the Bob Dyer Pick-a-Box program show and on an old 3DB radio program. Anyway, the Minister has a reputation, and a successful one at that, for answering questions . However, on the same day he made his statement the Minister realised that he had made a multi-million mistake. He is good at answering $64 questions but his mistake was of the order of 299 million because the new definition of the metre is the one I mentioned previously. The correct definition is that a metre is the length of the path travelled by light in vacuum during a time interval of 1/299, 792,458th of a second.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have to compete with the Minister.
—I am not trying to compete with the Minister. However, it is not often that a man as good at answering quiz shows as he is makes an error, even though a momentary one, of the order of 300 million.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been fewer changes to the standard of the kilogram and it is one of the few standards still physically realised. The kilogram was originally supposed to represent the mass of a cubic decimetre of water at the temperature of its maximum density. Subsequent work showed that the cube used for the determination of the kilogram in 1977, known as the Kilogramme des Archives, had a volume of 1.000028 cubic decimetres, thereby making it too heavy. I hope the honourable member for Moreton is paying close attention to this. At the Convention du Metre held in Paris in May 1875 it was decided to make a new international kilogram which would be an exact copy of the Kilogramme des Archives. The new standard, known as the International Prototype Kilogramme, was established in 1889 and copies of it were sent to the various bodies responsible for weights and measures throughout the world. The kilogram, as the honourable member for Moreton and, I am sure, the Minister know, is still one of the few physical measures. The standard is physical rather than a mathematical invention .

In concluding my remarks, I repeat that I hope the administration of this legislation is sensible, that there will not be overregulation, and that there will not be excessive use of authority, as I think there has been in the past. The honourable member for Moreton will no doubt point this out in the House today, as he has previously. I think that at times those administering the legislation have been overenthusiastic because they wanted to see metrication take place. There needs to be a clear recognition of the fact that there will be a dual system of measurement in many, if not most, of the homes of Australia and , in many businesses for decades to come. I hope, as I said previously in the debate, that those who administer the legislation and create regulations under it will recognise the real problems that business large and small might face in relation to its administration. The Opposition will not be objecting to this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Weights and Measures (National Standards) Amendment Bill 1984 seeks to amend the Weights and Measures (National Standards) Act 1960 and repeal the Metric Conversion Act 1970. I begin with a quote from Swift:

SPEECH.PARA: Order governs the world. The Devil is the author of confusion.

I am sure that to many people the subject of standards is an area which at first hearing appears dull and uninteresting. However, I can assure the House that it is far from that, and I hope I shall be able to give the correct picture. Standards have been with us since the beginning of time. I go back to the first chapter of the first book, the Bible. The first time a standard was mentioned was in verse 10:
And God called the dry land Earth; and the gathering together of the waters he called Seas: and God saw that it was good.
Verse 31 reads:
And God saw everything that he had made, and, behold, it was very good. And the evening and the morning were the sixth day.

The standards of good and very good were established. Standardisation was not invented by man. It is a principle borrowed from nature. In nature standardisation or organic structure among individuals within a species, of organic processes, of biological functions, makes possible the continuation of life. In human affairs, standardisation of language within a community, of law and of custom, make possible the cohesion and continuity of society.

The acceptance by man of some form of standardisation in his daily activities must have begun with the earliest development of community life. The need for communication through commonly understood signals brought about the evolution of language. The sharing of work experiences, such as hunting, must have led man also to adopt a measure of standardisation in techniques and in the manufacture of weapons and tools. As the practice of exchanging goods and services grew up, the necessity for agreed standards of measurement and value became imperative. The International Organisation for Standardization has defined a standard as:

An activity giving solutions for repetitive application to problems essentially in the spheres of science, technology and economics, aimed at the achievement of the optium degree of order in a given context. Generally, the activity consists of the process of formulating, issuing and implementing standards.

The general aims of standardisation are: Overall economy; simplification-in the general sense mitigating the complexity of modern life-improvement in technical communications; interchangeability-including both ordinary dimensional interchangeability and functional changeability-and safety. Those aims are those pursued since the inception of national standardisation within Australia in 1922 . Standards affect us from birth to death. We have standards in Australia on items ranging from the condom to the coffin.

I draw the attention of the House to some standards which I feel are very interesting and will start us thinking about the importance of this seemingly mundane topic. All these items have an Australian standard: Safety requirements for prams and pushers; classification and labelling of children's night clothes for fire hazard; child restraints for passenger cars and derivatives; size coding schemes for school and college wear; methods for sampling milk and milk products, toothbrushes; household synthetic detergents; codes of practice for recording and measuring work injury experience; codes of practice for construction in the timber framing industry; and a code of practice for the application of ergonomics to factory and office work. These are very few of the thousands of standards that affect our very fabric of life.

Most of us think of standards as something to do with measurement and weight. We do not realise the great importance of standards and their impact on the lives of each of every one of us. One has only to look around this House to see some of the standards in this place. There are standards in the sizes of paper, paper clips, microphones, pencils, seating arrangements, printing, speaking, dress, procedure, and time. I would like to be able to include behaviour in that . However, that varies with the personalities concerned. All around us standardisation is occurring at a very rapid pace.

In Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83 the Standards Association of Australia was granted $2,583,000 to assist with the running of this very important body and with the dissemination of knowledge on standards. The Standards Association of Australia has a certification marking scheme which gives the consumer an independent assurance that the manufacturer's goods comply with a particular Australian standard. This mark is registered by the Standards Association of Australia which allows it to be used only by manufacturers who can consistently manufacture their products to meet the requirements of the standard. Frequent checks are made at the manufacturer's works without warning. In addition, products are selected from time to time and tested. Only then can they receive the standards seal.

Recently the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety was told that a popular motor-cycle helmet was so dangerous that it could be fatal in some circumstances. At this very moment the Committee is examining this problem. It will be making an announcement in relation to this matter very soon.

Many attempts have been made overseas to quantify the economic benefits of standardisation. The results have rarely been convincing. In Australia the estimated saving runs into thousands of millions of dollars. Australia has many areas which would benefit from standardisation. Such areas include uniform road rules, uniform building regulations, Australia-wide driving licences, and standard education and text books. I recall that just a few years ago New South Wales and Victoria had two different rail gauges. That was indeed a ridiculous situation.

Australia is already using many world standards. As communications between countries get faster and the transfer of ideas becomes quicker that there is a need for global standardisation in many areas becomes apparent. Standards have been imporant in the past; they will become more important in future. One of the great assets of humankind is its individuality. I trust that there will never be standardisation of humans. If there is one advantage that humans have over other species it is their individuality. This precious gift needs to be nurtured and protected at all costs. Our individuality is at present being attacked in the fields of cloning and in vitro fertilisation, cold storage and the like. This is an area that I feel we must protect at all costs. We must protect our individuality which, I trust, will never be standardised. I commend this very important Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My speaking to the Weights and Measures ( National Standards) Amendment Bill will not surprise anyone in the House. If I were to suggest at the outset that I will confine my comments to the section relating to metric conversion it also would surprise nobody. I recall an episode some years ago aboard an airplane flying direct from Canberra to Brisbane. The then Minister, the predecessor of the present Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), was also on board that flight. The plane was filled mainly with politicians of all political persuasions and their staff. I was invited to the cockpit of that plane. I said to the captain, whom I knew: 'When do you start your landing procedures?' He said: 'Very shortly'. I said: 'Would you mind if I took the public address system and made a couple of announcements? ' He said: 'No, definitely not'. So I took the microphone and said: 'Ladies and gentlemen, this is the cockpit speaking'-I could not say that I was the captain or anything like that-'We are flying at 30,000 feet. We will shortly descend to about 20,000 feet. We will be landing in Brisbane at 9 a.m. The temperature in Brisbane is 72 degrees Fahrenheit. If passengers are wondering why we still use imperial measurements on aeroplanes, it is because we have found over the years that nobody aboard our planes really understands much of that metric stuff'. I went back to the passenger section and found other members of parliament rolling about in laughter but the then Minister was sitting there with a stiff upper lip , as he probably does in times of adversity due to his military training. He looked at me and said: 'Nothing is going to stop it. Nothing will turn it back. Metrics are here to stay'. I suppose in a way he was right, but everyone on board that plane understood the humour of it all. There are some people in this country who are so totally committed to the metrication of Australia that one could be forgiven for thinking it was a new form of Christianity or some other religion.

SPEECH.PARA: In the late 1960s, a committee of the Senate was set up to look at metric conversion in this country. The Minister for Science and Technology would be well aware of that. That committee comprised senators of varying ages. Quite frankly it was most surprising to hear their recommendation that Australia go metric. One of the ironies was that the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, at that time was the Minister for Education and he was the person who introduced the metrication Bill into this chamber. Like all Australians, I was not worried about it for the first few years. But that which became apparent as time went by was that there were a lot of people out there with iron fists ready to smash down upon anybody who dared to maintain or resort to the use of the old imperial system. That was when I went to war.

Those on this side of the House who were here in years gone by can testify to the many occasions that I stood up in the party room and gave various Ministers heaps over the heavy-handed approach that was adopted to introduce metrication. I will never forget the day Malcolm Fraser, as Prime Minister, turned to the then Minister for Science and Technology and said: 'For heaven's sake, listen to what Cameron is saying. I do not understand a lot of it. It is something that I regret having done. I want him to ease off. I never want the subject to be brought back into the party room again'. The then Minister-the then honourable member for Leichhardt, David Thomson, who I hope is listening now-obediently went off and made a number of changes. I remember when the Metric Conversion Board, with its heavy fist, banned the production of any measuring instruments other than those which were calibrated metrically. I also remember the raid on an importer in Melbourne who had the audacity to import 30 dozen rulers that had imperial measurements on them. These rulers were seized by a Customs official. The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who was then the Minister responsible for Customs matters, has just come into the House with a smile on his face, recalling and recoiling from the embarrassment that it caused him as I got to work. But then a lot of people started to wake up around that time and the Government eased off.

I remember contacting the manufacturers of tape measures in Australia and they said: 'The volume of sales has fallen dramatically. People will not buy the purely metric tapes, except those in the building industry who have been forced into it'. I remember saying to one of them: 'I am going to fight for the introduction of a choice'. I do not mind metrication, I am not against it, but my view has always been that people should have the opportunity of buying something calibrated both in metric measurement and in imperial measurement. There are millions of older Australians out there who not only have no desire to become acquainted with metrication but also, frankly, do not have the time or the interest to be swept along with something which was introduced by Napoleon to bamboozle the English.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have upset the Minister.

—I have never upset Barry Jones. I have a great deal of respect for him. I remember this manufacturer saying: 'I agree with you completely, but I have got rid of all my old dyes. If you cause this to happen it will create great problems'. I said: 'Get ready for great problems because I am going to win this one', which I did.

SPEECH.PARA: In this Bill the Minister is placing the issue of the continuation of metrication in this country into the hands of a commission. I have always been wary of boards and commissions because they are out of the reach of politicians. I would much prefer the matter to be placed directly in the Minister's portfolio so that, if one or several of his officers gets carried away, we can aim directly at the man responsible, who would be the Minister. But these obscure boards and commissions seem to be laws unto themselves and they can do what they like.

I like the words which the Minister used in his second reading speech in describing how the Metric Conversion Board was established under the Metric Conversion Act 1970. It was to be a body 'to promote, help and guide conversion from the imperial'. The way they approached this matter was almost how a Gestapo youth group would have approached it. I remember three inspectors raiding a retail and hardware store at Stone's Corner in Brisbane-I am not going to mention the name of Samios Pty Ltd! The owner had had a brass ruler on the table of his shop since his father's days-for 50 years. It was an old three-foot rule which people used for measuring wire and other things. The inspectors gave him 48 hours notice to get it out of the shop. That is the heavy-handed way they approached things.

I hope that those who will be members of the commission will read the speeches which have accompanied the introduction of this legislation so they will know how so many people around here feel about this subject. The message to them is to go gently, gently. If retaining the old system is not going to ruin the country and if the older generation is not going to interfere with science, let people use both systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lost generation.

—A lost generation! Maybe it is the one that is coming up. I also remember the time a Christmas present arrived for me at Parliament House. It was a T-shirt from people in the then Minister's Department which had written on it 'For unmetricated politicians', as if I were some odd-ball in the place. I believe that at that time I reflected the views of millions of Australians. I still have that T-shirt at home, even though these days I am somewhat limited as to where I can wear it.
—What size was it?

—I am not quite sure. The chest measurement was in centimetres and that really had me beaten from the word go. I have another interesting anecdote. I do not wish to take up too much time, but recently I built a home in Brisbane and I was concerned about having to do it in metric specifications but the law made me do it that way. When I started I really did not understand the metric system that much. But I would compete against any person in this Parliament today in terms of understanding it because I was forced to learn, and that is the difference. Most people do not want to learn, so leave them alone. I used to get lectures from people in the building industry about having to update . They had also been pushed into it and they thought they knew everything about metrication, but I have seen a number of mistakes being made in the building industry by those who think they know everything-even those who originally came from Europe many years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference in the Australian system of metrication and the European system is almost beyond belief. We have a queer system whereby we deal in millimetres, while Europe deals in centimetres. If something is 10 feet long, we talk about approximately 3,000 millimetres. We have gone from 10 to 3,000. I just hope that the Minister at the table will take on board the suggestion that the metric system might be a more comfortable one for this country if we were to do what we were told would be done in terms of becoming standardised with the rest of the world and if we were to examine what the rest of the world does.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is the house?

—The house is finished. One thing I am confused about is how many squares it measures, because I was told the area in metric measurement and I have never been able to come to grips with that. I think the Minister is not really responsible for this, because I remember that when he was in opposition he used to agree with me sometimes. We were told in this Parliament how Great Britain was metricating and how the United States was about to go metric. This was the propaganda that was being pedalled by the metric maniacs to try to convince us that Australia was the odd man out. Margaret Thatcher, with the agreement of the British Labour Party, has walked away from it. The United States of America has thumbed its nose to the rest of the world. These are some of the realities: Great Britain is still a major supplier of material to Australia and so is the United States of America. Therefore as desirable as it is that we standardise and have one system, we have to recognise that parts of the world with which we have close links still have not converted and may never convert to the metric system.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting also, Madam Deputy Speaker, that if you were to go to a shop today to buy a carpet, you have to be told in accordance with the law that the carpet measures 3 point something metres. I am well equipped to deal with metrics, but I cannot do this sudden conversion. It would be the equivalent of 12 feet, because carpet is still made in 12-foot wide loom. When measured we are told it is something like 3.666 or 3,666 millimetres wide, whereas the comment ' It is 12 foot wide', would satisfy everybody. That is one of the side products of the conversion we have gone through. Finally, I want to leave the message that I never ever really want to talk about this subject again in the Parliament .

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am quite sure that the Leader of the Opposition, who just said, 'Hear, hear', reflects the views of many other people. For years I stood almost as a lone soul in this Parliament, saying: 'Just lay off'. That victory was won. My victory advice was: 'Go easy. For heaven's sake, do not start pushing kilopascals down people's throats. If they want to pump up their tyres, let them do so in pounds per square inch. Do not force all the garages to throw out their old gauges, like the old Metric Conversion Board was trying to do when it was endeavouring to achieve a world record in conversion'. I said: 'Just be reasonable; acknowledge that we have an age group which spreads across two systems, and allow the older people in this country to live out their days without having to be confused by a heavy-handed bureaucracy'. This bureaucracy was trying to instil what was so aptly defined earlier as 'promotion, assistance and guidance'. This was done with a very heavy hand.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased that I am back here to speak on this legislation. It may well be that the Minister thought: 'Cameron will not be gone long now that he has lost the seat of Fadden. I will hold up the legislation until he returns'. I make one final reflection on the newspaper industry. I notice that as always, members of the Press are not in the Gallery. How they ever report this Parliament properly is beyond me. The facts are that they are one group which really applied the heavy hand. The Press decided that people would not be allowed to use any measurement except metric measurement in advertisements. I remember the classic case of a Minister of the National Party who had also been beating the drum for metric conversion. When he came to sell his property in Victoria he very sneakily advertised it in acres and gave the size of the house in squares. There he was, pushing down our throats and the throats of the rest of the people of Australia how important it was to become metric, yet he knew that for sale purposes no one would really understand the ad if the area of the land was described in hectares and the house in square metres.

I would never accuse a Minister from this side of the House for ever having displayed the remotest signs of hypocrisy, but some may have said that that was a double standard. That would probably be a fair comment. It all boils down to the method applied by the Metric Conversion Board. The Board would get industries together and say: 'Now, you have to do this'. Industries would fight like mad and say no. Other industries would go to the Metric Conversion Board and be told that a certain industry had agreed to do what the Board had requested. It was a type of coercion, which if used in any other part of this country would cause people to be marched off to prison. But the Board got away with it and it got away with the legislation. I hope the Minister's plans for the National Standards Commission will not mean that we will have another remote body that will do what it likes to do and will disregard the public. I say to the Minister that many people do not get emotional about the subject but they have some feelings about it and they want to be left in peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak in support of the Weights and Measures (National Standards) Amendment Bill 1984. In so doing, there are three aspects to which I would like to address my remarks. First, I will make some comments concerning some of the clauses in the Bill in order to provide a little more elaboration. Some of the comments of previous speakers have required that that be done. Secondly, I will look at the significance of measurements and I will look, thirdly, at the importance of measurements in the wider aspect of science and technology and at movements taking place in that important area in Australia at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) earlier in his remarks gave a fairly comprehensive rendition of the comments and the statements in the explanatory memorandum. I do not want to dwell on those again or on the purpose of this Bill, but I think it is important to look at certain of the clauses. Clause 5 deals with interpretations of measures. The memorandum states:

This Clause amends the terminology of the hierarchy of standards of measurement to accord with current weights and measures practice, and transfers the existing definition of ''metric system of measurement'' from the Metric Conversion Act 1970. It also clarifies the definition of ''instrument'' and ''pattern'' in relation to an instrument for use in trade and it also includes a definition of ''unit of measurement'' which will facilitate the prescription of certain terms, such as the decibel, which are employed as units of measurement.
The explanatory memorandum deals with clause 12, which is a significant clause which looks at the verification of measurements. The memorandum states:

The amendments introduce the new terminology of Australian standards of measurement to the Commission's verification procedures. Verification is the act of establishing the validity and accuracy of a measurement of a physical quantity by means of, by reference to, by comparison with or by derivation from a specified standard of measurement.

Clause 13 looks at the conversion factors. The proposed amendment provides for the use of prescribed conversion factors similarly to convert from a measurement that is not in terms of an Australian legal unit. That of course allows for the accurate and valid conversion from quantities expressed in units other than Australian legal units to quantities expressed in Australian legal units. That is obviously important.

Clauses 18 and 19 are significant in that they address a number of comments made by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron). He expressed suspicion about the powers of certain commissions within our community and he expressed suspicion and concern at the power of the National Standards Commission referred to in the Bill. Clause 18 specifically defines the membership of the Commission and clause 19 defines the functions and powers of the Commission. It is a fact that the previous Act did not clearly enunciate the functions and powers of the Commission and that these had to be derived from various sections throughout the existing Act. The amendments in this Bill before the House consolidate and set out clearly the functions and powers of the Commission. I hope that those two aspects of the legislation do allay some of the concerns of the honourable member for Moreton.

Clause 25 concerns itself with the patents of instruments. It is important to note that in an era of rapid technological change, weighing and measuring devices are becoming increasingly complex and may be electronically integrated with other devices such as computers. It might therefore be necessary at times for patent approval of an instrument to be given subject to the retention of a sample of the instrument or part of the instrument. That will provide some assurance that the instrument so approved is representative of all similar instruments in the market place.

That is a brief description of the important clauses in this legislation. The Bill before the House does bring to attention the whole significance of measurement, particularly within our contemporary society. It is clear that as the rate of technological development has increased over recent decades, and of course the rate of that development has increased proportionately, there has been a growing sophistication throughout the world, not just in Australia, of measurement units and measurement devices and techniques. Many of the standards which were satisfactory in the past, be it a decade ago or two or three centuries ago, are no longer relevant to an increasingly sophisticated society, particularly in scientific terms, and many items of machinery or definitions of measurement must be increasingly sensitive to that increased and heightened rate of technological change. An example of this is the metre, which was mentioned by the honourable member for Higgins in his remarks on this Bill. That is one of the most common examples of the need for the ability to redefine a unit of measurement as technological change has increased. I was interested to read today an article in the New Scientist of 27 October last year concerning a change in the measurement of the metre. The article is headed 'Time to remeasure the metre', and the lead-in states:

Last week, by international agreement, the metre was deposed: It is now no more than a fraction of a second. From the time physicists found they could measure the speed of light more accurately than they could measure the metre itself, its days were numbered.

I do not want to go into that in great depth, but a metre is now defined as the length of the path of light travelled in a vacuum during a time interval of 1/ 299,792,458 of a second. The speed of light is a universal constant of nature, and we know what that measurement is. That measurement assumes that the speed of light is constant. History would have it-indeed, I think some of Einstein's work would have it-that the speed of light is constant. This rather interesting article points out that perhaps there will be variations in the speed of light on a cosmic time scale, but I am sure that that is unlikely to affect any of us here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the life of the first Hawke Government.

—I thank the Minister. I was thinking of many Hawke governments in the future, but I doubt that any cosmic effect will take place during that time. There are a number of aspects of measurement. I have mentioned how the increasing rate of technological development has required that there be more precise definition of measurement. I think many of us might recall the humourous story of the question posed many years ago by the university lecturer who asked his students how to measure the height of a building using a barometer. The answer that the lecturer was seeking was that one calculates the difference in the barometric pressure between the ground floor of the building and the top floor, following which a reasonably accurate measurement of the height of the building can be made. Many of the students took a more lateral view of how to measure the height of the building using a barometer. One of the students suggested that the barometer could be dropped over the edge of the building and, using a stop watch, time how long it took to hit the ground. Knowing the speed at which that item would fall-the gravitational velocity and acceleration-the height of the building could be calculated. Another perhaps more perspicacious student suggested that he should go out to a shop and buy a length of string of, say, 200 feet or 400 feet long, tie the barometer to the string and dangle it over the edge, and then bring it back up to find the length of string used. Others suggested more complicated methods, such as swinging the barometer in an arc and measuring the pendulum, and then doing calculations on that basis. Perhaps the most original method of calculating the height of the building was to take the barometer to the person driving the lift and put the proposition to that person that if he would tell the student the height of the building, the student would give him a brand new barometer. So there were lots of ways in which that measurement could have been taken.
—Lateral thinking.

—It is a good example of lateral thinking. I want to give one other example of the way in which measurement has changed and of increasing sophistication. I refer to the measurements at petrol pumps, and previous speakers in this debate have alluded to such measurements. The measurement devices in the automatic pumps which pump petrol from below the ground in increasing quantities have become increasingly sophisticated. The new measurement devices which theoretically will give us an accurate readout of the number of litres of petrol or distillate that have gone into our cars are very finely tuned mechanisms. In fact, they are very sensitive to all sorts of radio and air wave frequencies. For instance, it has been suggested that the frequency on which police radios operate will cause disturbances to the measurement devices within petrol pumps. In many demonstrable cases petrol retailers in good faith, managing their equipment to the best of their ability, have thought that the pumps had been doing the job required but customers have paid for 40, 50 or 60 litres of petrol only to find that 15 or 20 litres have gone into the car. There have been altercations between the consumers and the retailer and both have protested that they have been correct. The problem, if it can be called a problem, lies with the increasing sophistication of the equipment which, unbeknown to the ordinary people in our society, is a high technology piece of equipment and is affected by things that cannot normally be seen or heard. It is affected by radio waves, but the people involved do not know that because their education has not encompassed that development.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention briefly a few other matters on the importance of science and technology. It has been said many times in this House that a strong national capability in science and technology is essential to Australia if we are to have a strong industry, a strong society, and increased job opportunities in the future. Clearly this question of measurement and adapting to change comes into that. I was concerned by some of the comments made tonight. They were humourous remarks in a sense but they also indicated an unwillingness to adapt to technological change. The comments of the honourable member for Moreton concerning metrication raised the very real issue of community involvement in and understanding of technological change. This Government has introduced a large number of initiatives in the area of technological change. Many of them have been strictly economic but, importantly, we have also taken initiatives aimed at heightening the understanding and involvement of the community in technology. The honourable member for Moreton mentioned the comments he made from the cockpit of a plane, and that he had said it was cruising at 30,000 feet and that it would be 72 degrees Farenheit when they got in to Brisbane. Apparently he said that because the people on board could not understand what 22 degrees Celsius and 10,000 metres were. Those comments were humourous in the way he expressed them but they did raise the issue in a simplistic way of community involvement and understanding in technology. Our very impressive Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) has taken a number of initiatives to ensure that community understanding and involvement in technology is fostered. Last year, in September, the Minister called the National Technology Conference to help establish some new directions in the area of technology. As a consequence of that conference the Minister recently released a discussion paper called 'National technology strategy: Discussion draft'. The Minister said:

My main objective at the Conference was to achieve a 'shock of recognition' among the participants-a sharp and growing awareness of the range and speed of the technological revolution, of where Australia stood in comparison with other nations with mature economies and the extent to which we needed to reconsider the appropriateness of conventional economic wisdom. Other objectives were to promote dialogue between those concerned with technology issues-industry, unions , public service, the research sector; and to draw the attention of the media to the central role of technology in economic development.

The Conference also served to focus the growing interest of State Governments in technology. All States now have Ministers with a responsibility for technology and a Commonwealth/State Working Party on Technology has been formed.
That is what the Minister indicated. I emphasise that because it involves community understanding.

In conclusion, I think that is one of the most important challenges facing us in the whole technological debate. It is important that we continue to encourage industry progress in the technological area. It is equally important that all members of the community are kept up to date, informed and, importantly, educated about technological change and where it will lead in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the honourable members for Higgins (Mr Shipton), Flinders (Mr Chynoweth), Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron)-we now must get used to thinking of him as the honourable member for Moreton after his having been the honourable member for Griffith and Fadden previously-and Bendigo (Mr Brumby) for their contributions. I will take up the points briefly that were raised in this debate by the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Higgins. He asked who checks the accuracy of the calibration of metered telephone calls. Of course, that involves use of the word 'meter' in a different kind of way. He asked where the legal responsibility lay? I am sorry to say that, because it seems to be after COB, as they say, in the Public Service, I have not been able to get an answer about that, but I suspect it will be entirely within the responsibility of Telecom Australia. However, this raises the point that it certainly does not appear to be covered by this legislation. There is, I understand, no Australian legal unit of time. Certainly it is not covered by this Weights and Measures (National Standards) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill deals with weights and measures. That is, it deals with measurements of physical quantities appropriate to things like petrol delivery but not appropriate to things like time delivery on the telephone. That is very important. I will find out what I can about it and notify the honourable member. Now that we have made that transition to the definition of the meter measured in lengths of time rather than of a physical commodity we need to know precisely who checks the validity of such and such a proportion of a second.

The honourable member for Higgins was also correct in drawing attention to the embarrassment over my first Press release that went out on 15 December 1983 on the length of the metre. It was wrong. We left out the final figures, 458. It should have been 1/299,792,458. He has got his mathematics wrong too. The error was of three orders of magnitude; it was a thousand-fold wrong. I think he suggested it was in the order of 300 times wrong. Talking among friends, I think we can talk generally about it being 1/300,000,000 of a second because it is astonishingly that close to that figure.

I now take up the comments of the now absent honourable member for Moreton. In part I am sympathetic to a couple of his propositions. It is no secret that when metrication was introduced there was not a great deal of community understanding . I think that metrication exacerbated the fear that many people have of the unknown. They felt compelled to work to a system that they were not sympathetic with. This points up the difficulties for this country though; if our initial knee-jerk reaction to any kind of change is fear and a sense that we will not understand then it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy-we do not understand.
