Essentially, if we consider the comparative simplicity of metrication with an increase by ten with each unit of measurement, no one would ever go back to a system where we begin with sub-units having a ratio to the inch of 16 to 1, then the ratio of inches to feet of 12 to 1, the next ratio being 3 feet to 1 yard, the next ratio being 22 yards to 1 chain and the next unit up being 80 chains to one mile. Nobody in his right mind would sit down and say that this series of ratios should be the basis of a measuring system. It is true that in the traditional world of the medieval period, it made some sense to measure literally by the length of a thumb, by the length of a foot or by the length of a stride. However, as we move increasingly into a world of precision it is a different matter.

I thank the other honourable members who spoke. The honourable member for Bendigo gave a very scholarly and accurate account about what is happening. The problem of calibration in petrol pumps is serious. I think the order of variation that he mentioned is somewhat excessive but, certainly with large consumers, there may be a serious variation caused by those signals on police radios.

I thank the honourable member for Flinders for his very thoughtful remarks, as they invariably are. I certainly agree with him that as we move towards greater precision and a machine dependence in the physical world, it is essential that we assert our own individuality and do not fit into a rigid precise mould. I thank the House for its support of this measure.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) read a third time.

Debate resumed from 4 April, on motion by Mr John Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that a debate on a subject such as the bounty on two-stroke and four-stroke engines following the suspension of the sitting for dinner, will draw attention to the House. The Opposition does not oppose the Bounty (Two-Stroke Engines) Bill 1984 but will be moving an amendment at the Committee stage. The legislation was brought about by the Industries Assistance Commission report on lawnmowers, certain engines and parts. The result of that study, the history of which is quite interesting, indicates that the ability in Australia to manufacture engines profitably has been reduced significantly since the last time there was an IAC report on the subject when James N. Kirby Pty Ltd , Norton Villier Australia Pty Ltd, Simpson Pope Ltd, Toowoomba Foundry Pty Ltd, Victa Ltd and Rover Scott Bonnar Ltd were involved in this area. Today there is essentially only one producer of engines of the two-stroke type and that is Victa Australia, which is a subsidiary of the Sunbeam Corporation Ltd. That situation brought about the IAC inquiry. As a result of that inquiry, the Commission recommended that the current 35 per cent tariff be reduced to 25 per cent, 20 per cent and 15 per cent over two years. That recommendation has not been accepted by the Government, which has opted to stay at the 25 per cent level plus a bounty. The bounty will be $6 a unit, which is roughly equivalent to 10 per cent. In other words, for two years the bounty, plus the tariff protection, will remain at the former level of 35 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of the production of these small engines in Australia has not been a happy one. Victa has produced a small two-stroke engine of a new series which it claims is in line with modern technology and with which it claims it can achieve significant market penetration. History has shown that the two-stroke engine has not gone much beyond lawnmower usage and into other areas in which I believe some of the producers may have hoped. The Government, by its actions, has allowed Victa to use every opportunity it has to develop an export market or to develop a market outside lawnmowers for this form of engine.

The producers of lawnmowers which were subject to the IAC report have been a varied lot-Sunbeam, through the Victa organisation, Rover Scott Bonnar, the Cox company and the Greenfield organisation in Brisbane. They reported that there has not been any substantial growth in the area of lawnmower sales. Roughly 300, 000 units a year have been sold for a number of years. The companies are projecting a total production of 349,000 in the current year. The merger of Scott Bonnar with the Rover organisation resulted in the use by that organisation of the fully imported Briggs and Stratton four-stroke engine. I know that the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) is an avid lawn cutter and has a great interest in two-stroke and four- stroke engines.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is an expert.
—I am sure he is. The honourable member for Dundas would know about that.
—He lives in my electorate. He wins the local prize for the best garden in the street.

—Is that right? He probably gives a ham to everybody who can beat him. As a result of the merger of Scott Bonnar with Rover, those producers of mowers managed to put together their production and substantially reduce the range of products from 74 to 29. The company would have been rewarded in some way for its attempts at economies of scale in that area. Other producers, such as the Greenfield operation and Cox, both of which are Brisbane producers, while relatively small in their area, do produce very competitive machinery. No doubt they contribute to the very high dominance of Australian products in the Australian lawnmowing area. I think that about 80 or 90 per cent of all mowers sold in Australia are locally made. Import penetration is remarkably low. That has to point to the fact that the mowers we produce are of a high quality. Because of that I believe that in years to come the level of government support probably will not be necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the biggest areas of growth in this area has been that of the electric lawnmower. While I can probably recommend its use to certain people, it has a high risk factor. I have no doubt that some people like living with risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still push a Pope.

—Many people do. The honourable member for Higgins probably has a small garden. He is probably pushing his mower along a concrete path which has been painted green. In view of what has happened in the lawnmower area, I am sure that the retention of the 25 per cent bounty will be well received by the producers. Having visited the Rover Scott Bonnar plant in Brisbane and being the owner of a Greenfield mower, I know of the enormous benefit which they bring to the user. They are well appreciated. I am sure that they thoroughly deserve the 25 per cent tariff granted by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, the annual market for lawnmowers of 330,000-odd units has really never grown. The market has remained stagnant over a number of years. That is an interesting point. I suspect it means that we need rationalisation and an understanding of small business in Australia. It is a case study in no small way of how an area which was catered for by small business has been penetrated-in the case of Victa by an overseas corporation and in the case of Rover Scott Bonnar by an Australian company. Those companies moved into this area and concentrated their markets and essentially dominate this area. The Opposition does not oppose the action taken by the Government, but will be moving an amendment at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -It is good to see that the Opposition will be supporting the Bounty (Two-Stroke Engines) Bill. I might add as a preamble that it is important that the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) is leading for the Government in this debate, because he has won a couple of gardening competitions. This debate is obviously of great personal relevance to him. I note that the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) , who has just spoken, referred to that. That is very good to know. My good colleague the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) will be making some remarks about the importance of research and development. I will not trespass too much on her territory because we are looking forward to hearing her remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is important to talk about this matter because, in many respect, the two-stroke engine has been one area in which Australia did show considerable initiative and enthusiasm and did, in fact, develop a market that previously had not been developed. The previous speaker referred to that and I believe it is important that we in this place try to show some support, not only in terms of this legislation but also some enthusiasm for people out there who are willing to take the risk and to manufacture. The previous speaker indicated that the Government is looking at a 25 per cent level of protection plus a bounty. In effect, we have taken only part of the Industries Assistance Commission recommendation. The proposed bounty of $6 per engine roughly equates to a 10 per cent duty and it will effectively maintain the existing level of assistance for the next two years.

I also add that in taking this decision the Government is mindful of its desire to encourage industries which are willing to undertake research and development activities and to modernise their operations to improve their long term viability. That is very important. This Government has a very strong commitment to that sort of position and this Bill is associated with that.

In an industry in which we believe there is a future, there is a firm which we believe has a future. The firm is called the Sarich Orbital Engine Co. It is involved in the production of two-stroke motors. The Sarich company, by happy coincidence, happens to be located in the Federal electorate of Stirling in Western Australia and I am sure that many people in Australia would be aware of the great endeavours of Ralph Sarich and the great initiative he has shown. He is one of the remarkable Australians who I know the Minister at the table often speaks about. He speaks about Paul Hogan and we can also speak about Ralph Sarich because he is a remarkable Austrailan. Ralph has undertaken some great enterprise. In fact, he is succeeding in one of the hardest industries of the world, the auto industry. He has, in my view and I believe in the view of the Australian community, made quite a major contribution. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has been very sound in its support for the Sarich Orbital Engine Co.

I would like to bring up to date where we are with this two-stroke production because it is very relevant to this Bill. The Sarich company has a major program with a leading auto manufacturer in the United States of America. I am sure that honourable members will respect the fact that I do not refer to the names of companies because they are matters of corporate negotiation and it would be quite wrong to indicate which names apply to which companies. I am sure people will understand. But I must say that the Sarich company in its briefing of me has been very full in its comments. The program is looking towards the production of a two-stroke auto engine. This is quite relevant in light of what the previous speaker said.

It is true that the lawnmower market has in some sense begun to change in terms of its structure but I believe that here is a part of the market that we can advance. I will explain why. In current testing the Sarich auto engine demonstrates a fuel economy advantage of 26 per cent compared with a renowned four cylinder world car engine. That is quite remarkable. A 26 per cent better fuel economy is achieved by this Sarich two-stroke engine compared with a renowned world car engine. It is quite remarkable. It is being produced in Australia. It is being produced in the suburb of Balcatta in the electorate of Stirling. I give all praise to that company. It is remarkable.

I add that the world car engine that I referred to has taken a decade to develop; so here we have the Sarich Orbital Engine Co. developing a motor in Australia with far fewer resources than were behind the world car producers and it has been able to achieve a 26 per cent better fuel economy performance. In terms of its development, the two-cycle engine has overcome significant problems . I am sure people listening to this debate will think of two-stroke engines very much as they do of lawnmower engines-noisy, smokey, smelly and very uneconomical. In effect, what the Sarich Orbital Engine Co. has been able to do is to overcome these problems, which is quite remarkable.

I have already referred to the fuel economy problems and the fact that this engine has a 26 per cent better performance than a renowned world car engine. It has overcome smoke problems. When looking at it running at the factory, it is really a very clean operation. It does not emit smoke the way my lawnmower emits smoke. That problem with my lawnmower has something to do with the maintenance and with the operator. Certainly, the Sarich engine performs very well.

Thirdly, I refer to the severe instability of a two-stroke engine in city running conditions. Those honourable members who are familiar with the running of some two-stroke engines in city conditions will recognise that they are very unstable as well as being smoky. They tend to run very roughly. People would be aware of certain Japanese brand motor vehicles, and certainly motor cycles, in which those two-stroke engines run very roughly. But the Sarich engine is able to perform in a very stable way which is quite a major change.

With regard to emission problems, currently the Sarich company is undertaking a study with a United States company to reduce emission to the United States standards. Of course, in Australia in cities such as Perth it is not such a major problem but certainly in the United States it is a major problem. The previous speaker referred to exports and, if this company is to get into an export market, and if one of those markets is the United States, quite obviously we must meet some of those United States conditions in terms of emission. The Sarich company is working on that and I am very encouraged by its progress.

An absolutely remarkable area is marine application. The two-stroke engine in marine running has shown a 30 to 40 per cent improvement in fuel economy measured against a leading Japanese engine. I am not in the business of naming Japanese engines; in fact, I have been asked not to because in a sense that would be making disparaging comments. But what has happened is that the Sarich engine in marine running conditions has been able to get a 30 to 40 per cent better fuel economy than a leading Japanese engine. Many people would know of Japanese engines being used on boats all around Australia every weekend. Incidentally, the reason for the 30 to 40 per cent spread of performance is varying load factors. In terms of performance that is quite remarkable. Again I say: This two-stroke engine has been developed in Australia.

So that everyone is quite clear in this debate, this engine is fitted with the fuel injection system developed by Ralph Sarich and his team. It uses combustion techniques which were developed when the original Sarich orbital engine was developed. So in effect what we have is the fuel injection system and the combustion system of the original Sarich system being married for its marine application. It is very interesting to note that the Sarich Orbital Engine Co. has recently signed an agreement-this gets back to our earlier debate about the need to have Australian companies performing and extending their boundaries-with a major world marine manufacturer for the development and application of the two -stroke marine engine utilising the fuel injection system developed by Sarich and a Sarich designed cylinder head. This twelve month program is currently under way and is showing a great deal of performance. As I have indicated already, there is reason for a great deal of confidence about this.

What is achieved when the fuel injection system is married to the cylinder head arrangement that the Sarich Orbital Engine Co. has developed is in effect a short motor. It is anticipated that this short motor will be able to be applied in quite a number of settings. Not only can it be applied to the marine application to which I have already referred and where I have indicated it is showing a 30 to 40 per cent better fuel economy performance as a two-stroke engine, but also it is thought that this engine could be applied in light aircraft, ultra-light aircraft and as an installed short motor in other vehicles .

I am sure people listening to this debate will recognise that what I am talking about is a major example of Australian innovation and research and something of which we can be very proud. It is certainly the intention of this Bill, with its tariff protection of 25 per cent and bounty of $6, to provide some degree of protection for people in Australia. It does apply to lawnmower engines but I want to add that I believe this area of the market to which I am referring, which in effect is not only the auto market but also the marine manufacture market as well as that of ultra-light and light aircraft, does show a degree of promise.

Looking at a comparative situation, the Sarich two cycle engine, compared with the world car engine to which I have already referred, is lighter, cheaper and more economical. Let us bear in mind that the world car engine took 10 years to develop and was backed by a very powerful corporation. Here we have an Australian developed engine that is performing at a better rate in terms of fuel economy, is cheaper to produce and is lighter.

I will give some statistics which I believe amplify the situation. The Sarich engine is a 1.2 litre engine and is compared with a world car 1.6 litre engine. We are comparing those two. The Sarich engine produces 1.5 kilowats per kilogram in weight whereas the world car engine produces 0.55 kilowatts per kilogram. In effect, the Sarich engine has a 3 to 1 better ratio in terms of power to weight than the world care engine. That is an astounding performance. Obviously, with a smaller powerful engine one can do something in terms of car design. There is much more space left in the engine compartment to do things with. That gives the car designer much more to work with with respect to overall motor vehicle design . That is quite important.

Cost estimates from Detroit of the manufacture of the Sarich engine that has been developed in co-operation with BHP suggest that it would be $200 to $300 cheaper than a conventional four-stroke engine. It will be easier to manufacture than a conventional engine and, as I have indicated, the fuel economy is there. Interestingly, the Sarich two-stroke engine is better in terms of fuel economy than the published figures on the VW Golf diesel. That is important to recognise . The VW Golf diesel is held up within the market as being a great performer in terms of economy. People who have them indicate that that is true. But the Sarich two-stroke engine with the fuel injection system to which I have referred is a better performer in terms of fuel economy than the VW Golf diesel.

Let us look at some developments in train. These are interesting because we are looking at Australian industry getting moving, getting on its feet and getting markets. The Sarich company has recently received proposals from Europe, the United Kingdom and Asia for development of the automobile concept and the fuel injection system. As I indicated earlier, I will not mention the particular companies because they are matters of corporate negotiation and it would be wrong in this place to do that. But approaches have come from Europe, the United Kingdom and Asia to look at the development of this engine. That offers great promise to Australia. Further, the Sarich company has received a proposal from a company in the United Kingdom seeking a joint venture arrangement.

The Orbital Engine Co. has submitted a four-cylinder world car to Detroit for testing of the fuel injection system. It has taken a world car engine and put on its fuel injection system. It has submitted it for testing in Detroit. That testing is already under way with one company. We understand that it is showing good results. The Sarich company is also shortly to add its fuel unjection system to the six-cylinder motor of another Australian manufacturer. Obviously, people could conclude to which other manufacturer's motor the fuel injection system is being added. It will be tested by that corporation as well. Two corporations are currently testing the fuel injection system of the Sarich company on their own operations to see how effective it is. It is good to think that these ventures are being made by Australian business with in the context of Australian operations.

The marine masters of the art in the world have submitted an engine to the Sarich Orbital Engine Co. and have received from it an engine which, after the Orbital Engine Co. has worked on it, performs better than the engine they have been able to develop. An engine is being produced in Western Australia in the electorate of Stirling-I do not want to be parochial about it-which, in fact, is standing up to world standards. That is a great achievement. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) visited the plant recently. I was fortunate enough to be there. The people there are all being employed in a good operation. The standards in the factory are remarkably high. There is great cohesiveness. It is a wonderful investment as well as social capital because people are doing a great job of work. There is every reason why people in this place should be proud of it.

Two conclusions are evident, I believe, from what I have said. What is needed from government is a favourable climate in which assistance is provided to manufacturers utilising advanced manufacturing techniques. I am sure that Ralp Sarich, if he were here, would say that he does not believe in a highly protected industry. However, he believes that companies in the development stage -one thinks back to companies developing engines such as the Victa engine-need nurturing. The classic economic term is that it is infant industry argument for tariff protection. We need to provide some degree of support in the early stage of development. I think I would be quoting Ralph Sarich fairly if I said that after two or three years, provided the company was using advanced manufacturing techniques, the tariff could taper away. By then, the company should be in a position to cope with the market.

The Industries Assistance Commission recommendation on two-stroke engines envisages a reduction in tariff. Certainly, I do not think that the Orbital Engine Co. would be uncomfortable with this recommendation. Many people ask what has happened to the Sarich orbital engine. I have indicated the current position of the fuel injection system and the two-stroke engine. Effectively, BHP has said that, if there are proper marketable business proposals, it is interested in the development of a manufacturing operation. We must ensure that that manufacturing takes place in Australia and that we get the employment and the benefit of the investment. My second conclusion in this debate is that it is evident that Australia must provide a climate of enthusiasm for Australian manufacture. It is very important. We have to be proud of Australian manufactures and Australians who get in and to their jobs. If honourable members were to visit the factory they would be proud too. It is a great operation. We must be proud of Australian manufacturers.

The interesting thing that comes out of the tariff argument is that, if we have very high tariffs, manufacturers are often discouraged from being innovative and inventive in the way that Ralph Sarich is. They say: 'We will buy our research and development from overseas. We will not do what Ralph Sarich has done. We will not develop a fuel injection system. We will not develop a two-stroke engine. We will simply buy it in and manufacture under licence'. Guess who misses out again. Australia misses out again. Not only do we have a more expensive motor vehicle but also we have bought the brains and the production from overseas; and we are not manufacturing. I believe that a responsibility of this Government to Australia is to ensure that we provide that enthusiasm, that support, and companies such as the Sarich company are given a degree of support so that there is an incentive for them to undertake research and development and then move into the manufacturing stage. We then have further production, further jobs and the people who are willing to have a go are getting the sort of reward we believe they should get. Australia is a great place. It has done some great things historically. The bold, innovative, determined style that people like Ralph Sarich have is something we must support.

In conclusion, it is a pleasure to support this Bill. Although it sounds at first to be a rather unusual small, unimportant Bill, if people were to visit the Sarich Orbital Engine Co. plant at Balcatta in the electorate of Stirling they would be proud of it. I am proud of it. It also indicates that we in this place have a major job to do, that is, to get behind Australian industry. It is trying to do a good job. We have a responsibility to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Mrs H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow the remarks of my colleague the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on the Bounty (Two-Stroke Engines) Bill by saying how much I agree with him. I go further and say that I am afraid that in this country we have been suffering for some years from a kind of technological cringe. We have ignored the innovative and creative work of Australian inventors and we have-all of us-a sad and sorry list of Australian inventions, adaptations and creations which have got to a certain stage of development and because there has been little or no interest in risk taking from either industry or the Government those creative developments have either gone down the drain or overseas where they are nicely profit-making for other countries and are producing employment and industrial upturn in places other than the place where they were first invented. I think that says something to all of us. We cannot afford to do that any longer, and I think this Bill is important because it is a message to the people that this Government is interested in Australian creativity.

SPEECH.PARA: I support this Bill, knowing that the bounty concerned is designed to assist already established manufacturers who were producing engines at the time of the Government's announcement. It is a very important part of the package of industry assistance established by the Government following consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission report of July 1983 entitled 'Lawnmowers, certain engines and parts'. As our economic environment continues to show signs of healthy progress and the period of recession begins to succumb gradually to a brighter and encouraging future, this Government is taking the initiative at every opportunity to stand by our industrial producers.

I think the important aspect of this legislation is that it really demonstrates our Government's commitment to the support of Australian creative thinking and backing for the development of Australian inventiveness. It is that backing for development which is so essential. The fact is that the visit last year to the multitude of small manufacturing industries in my electorate by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) was the first time a government Minister had taken sufficient interest to actually visit the work place and find out for himself what the needs of those industries are. It was also the first time that many people in industry had seen their local member of parliament. I think that this is an example of why there has been a real loss of confidence in Australian manufacturing industry, particularly in the smaller industries which are the mainstay of our employment.

I have very great faith in the capacity of Australians to be creative, forward looking and self-reliant. I do not think they lie down and wait for somebody to pick them up and stand them on their feet. I think Australians generally have shown time and time again that they want to stand on their own feet, that they want to compete, they want to get out there and have a go. They need what anybody else needs when they are developing something which is new; they need support and backing. They do not necessarily need lots of money, but they certainly need to know that the Government is interested in and supportive of their endeavours. Flying flags is one thing but doing something positive is an entirely different thing. I know that, given real backing by an economically responsible government, Australian manufacturing industry will demonstrate again its capacity to compete successfully in local and world markets.

Incidentally, I think it is interesting that we do not do many of the things that we used to do and demonstrated quite clearly our capacity to do when we had to. I will mention just one example of that, and that is the fact that we no longer make optical glass. We did not make optical glass in this country before the Second World War. We had to develop and make it during that period. We made the finest optical glass in the world. However, we no longer make it, and the question is: 'Why?'. The answer is too drearily apparent, and that is that we were not prepared as a country to support our own industry. We were much more prepared to say: 'Let us do it cheaper'.

In supporting this Bill, I extend as a member of the Government encouragement to industries which are willing to undertake innovative and stimulating research and development programs designed to update and improve their operations in order to gain first class credibility in their long term standing. The competitive spirit is to be nurtured by the realisation that success on the industrial front thrives on this formula. It is a climate that should be recommended and encouraged as it enhances Australian industrial clout both at home and abroad. It is all very well to talk about wages, but, by golly, we can do anything we like here as well as we want to. It is not a matter of crying wages or anything else. It is a matter of being confident and sensible.

The past decade has seen the contraction of the engine manufacturing industry, excluding motor vehicle engines, despite high level assistance through duties on competitive imports. So that was not the way to go, was it? It would seem that one of the main reasons for this outcome is that the fairly small and fragmented nature of the Australian market precludes local manufacturers from the benefits of the more cost effective and large scale production of overseas producers. However, there is a further disturbing reason and that is the inability of at least part of the industry to keep pace with technological advancement in the design and construction of engines. That really is the nub of the problem. Unless we can assist in that forward looking development and design we condemn industries to going further backwards.

Five main engine manufacturers were producing for Australian industry. There are now very many less than that because the James N Kirby Ltd and Simpson Pope have ceased production. Victa Ltd constitutes practically the entire engine manufacturing industry, producing a single engine two-stroke model for use mainly in its lawnmowers. Victa also produces, in small numbers, an industrial version of the engine. In 1983 Victa commenced production of a new engine, the series 80, to replace the present model in order to improve its competitive position and to reduce its dependence on lawnmower production and its seasonality. The new engine incorporates the latest available two-stroke technology, decreases cost production, and will suit not only lawnmowers but also other industrial applications. In August of this year we shall be looking at full production of the new engine.

This creative industrial forethought of the sort we think we should be encouraging will be complemented by the Government bounty rate of $6 an engine. These bounty payments are going to be limited to a maximum of $1.2m per annum, but this seems a very small amount of money for the sorts of things that we need to do. In other words, we expect a fairly good and an economically decent result from that amount of money. Engines with a maximum power output of up to 4.5 kilowatts and with an Australian content of not less than 55 per cent will be eligible for the bounty if during the two-year bounty period they are sold for use in Australia or are used in Australia by the manufacturer. Because Australian production of engines other than motor car engines has diminished very rapidly in recent years, today sees Victa as very much the sole Australian manufacturer. Clearly, we want to remedy this state of affairs, and in order to set the wheels in train the Government has introduced this engine bounty Bill as an incentive to the ingenuity of our local manufacturing industry.

The general rate of duty of 35 per cent on engine imports was considered by the IAC to provide effective assistance in excess of that accorded to the manufacturing industry generally and tended to penalise the relatively lightly assisted engine using industrial sector. The recommendation that that 35 per cent duty be reduced to 25 per cent immediately, with a further phasing down to 15 per cent over two years, brought about a conclusion in the report that the rate of duty of 15 per cent would provide Victa with a rate of return of the order achieved by the manufacturing industry generally and would be sufficient to maintain local engine production. It is the belief of the IAC that Victa has a natural advantage by virtue of the fact that the Australian market is dominated by mowers fitted with two-stroke engines. However, having carefully considered the IAC report, the Government felt the reduction in assistance as recommended could endanger the continued production of small petrol engines. A decision was made immediately to reduce the long term duty rate from 35 per cent to 25 per cent and that the bounty, which is roughly equivalent to the 10 per cent duty, should be paid to existing manufacturers over the next two years.

It was taken into account that Victa had made a very considerable investment in its development of the series 80 engine. It was felt that the bounty assistance would allow Victa to adjust to the lower level of assistance and to have the opportunity to develop new markets for the engine so that its commercial attractiveness could be adequately tested and recoupment of development costs compensated. Again, assistance that goes on and on is, as we all know, counter- productive. Assistance that compensates for development and allows for market testing and says 'Yes, we believe in your ability to do things well and we will give you the time you need in order to be competitive', is the kind of assistance that I think Australian manufacturing industry is looking for. It is a darn pity that it did not have it a long time ago.

Ensuring that assistance for engine production is not to be undermined by imported lawnmowers incorporating engines, the Government decided that duty on lawnmowers would remain at 25 per cent and not be reduced to 15 per cent, as recommended by the IAC. On the other hand the Government has accepted the IAC proposal that engines made outside Australia be dutiable at minimum rates. In four years time the assistance accorded to lawnmowers and engines will be put to the IAC for further review. Through this bounty Bill the Government is once again showing its determination to support our local manufacturing industries. In my electorate, which has a very large number of small manufacturing industries, the assistance already received in the way of advice and support from the Department of Industry and Commerce, members of which the Minister has made available to assist those industries, has been extremely important. It has given the people involved in those industries the confidence to go on with what they are doing.

In my electorate a number of manufacturers manufacture articles which were first developed by family members. They were the first in Australia to develop them. There are a number of very highly creative people who are not frightened by downturns in markets. They take them into consideration. They are able to diversify their operations and go out and find new markets. They need and appreciate the assistance which the Minister for Industry and Commerce has made freely available to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a good Minister.

—He is an excellent Minister. The fact that he has shown such a personal interest in the problems of these manufacturers has been an enormous boost to their confidence. They feel that they can go ahead in their development areas with some confidence that they will receive the understanding and the consideration that they need very much for their continuing production.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased with the way in which the industries in my electorate are going ahead and looking with some confidence to the future. I am certain that the care with which the Minister has made the services of his Department available and the fact that they know that their local member is extremely interested in their progress and is concerned for their well-being has had something to do with the way in which they are facing the future.

On current trends the Australian economy is looking decidedly cheerful. It is with a responsible optimism that the Government continues to maintain wholehearted respect and support for the progressive ingenuity in Australia's industrial sector. We want to encourage creativity of thought in our industries because that results practically in a high standard of performance. Putting theory into practice at the industrial level will create jobs for many thousands of Australians. This, of course, is one of the major themes of Government bounty legislation. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up the debate on the Bounty (Two-Stroke Engines) Bill I first note the fact that the Opposition supports this measure, as stated by the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). I add that he was probably the most courteous and efficient of the Ministers in the previous Government until his rather unfortunate removal from the Ministry, for reasons that were not of his own making. I note with some appreciation that the shadow Minister supports the Government's move to prop up this rather important industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted with some pleasure the comments of the honourable member for Stirling ( Mr Ronald Edwards), one of our better new members. He spoke of the parallel between Sarich and Hogan. In their own ways they are rather unique Australians- Ralph Sarich in the engineering field and Paul Hogan in the field of culture. I guess there is some parallel between Sarich and the founder of Victa mowers which happens to be a recipient of this bounty. I knew Mr Richardson as a child. I well remember Mr Richardson starting his factory in an old shed at Mortlake quite near where I lived. He started from very modest beginnings and built the business up into what was an Australian success story, Victa Mowers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what happens under Liberal governments.
—I did not happen to be under a Liberal government. It was under a Labor government.
—I have very great doubts about that.

—I assure the honourable member that it was in 1946 when I was in the intermediate year at a school. I point out for the benefit of the unwise shadow Minister at the table that that was when Mr Richardson founded his venture, a venture which found great success in the intervening years. It was during the time of the previous Liberal administration that the business foundered rather badly. Just for the honourable member's elucidation, I point out that we are now providing a bounty of $6 a motor to enable this company to get back on its feet.

SPEECH.PARA: It is rather significant that the honourable member for Stirling mentioned Ralph Sarich and spoke of his bold, innovative and determined style. In the context of the 1980s, his story parallels that of the Richardson story in the late 1940s when Mr Richardson also showed bold, innovative and determined style to shock the world with the production of his first two-stroke motor. Now, in a latter and more sophisticated fashion, Ralph Sarich is developing a motor which in its own way is extraordinarily sophisticated. I note with some satisfaction that the representatives of General Motor's Holdens Ltd are sitting in the Gallery. They heard the honourable member for Stirling talking about the motor's application to the motor market, which GMH is now promoting.

I guess that this debate has been fairly symptomatic of the attitude of this Government. The honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) spoke about this Government's determination to improve the capacity of Australian manufacturing industry to survive. In some way that is the succinct difference between the attitude this Government has adopted to the problems of industry and that of the previous Government. Our attitude should have been adopted by our predecessors during their seven years of mismanagement. The fact is that we have been able to develop an economic environment in which manufacturing industry can look forward to some future. It had been ground into the earth through the mismanagement of the previous Government. We are providing an opportunity for small business, manufacturing industry in particular, to engage in forward planning. We are encouraging small operators, in this case with a bounty and in many other cases with similar incentives.

More important is the industrial peace which has existed under this Government over the previous 12 months. I think that should be an eye-opener to all who take a dispassionate look at the economic environment in Australia. Under the Labor Government, for 12 months we have had less industrial trouble because of our attempts to destroy the confrontationist style of the previous Government and restore some form of industrial harmony and peace. Added to that is the reduction of the consumer price index to a reasonable standard and the sustaining of the prices and incomes accord.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about the strikes that are ruining Australia?

—The Opposition applauds the bounty we are offering in this Bill- not necessarily this cackling fool at the table, but at least the shadow Minister who knows something about the subject. He was gracious enough-
—Australia is on strike.

—I wish the honourable member for Boothby would put his mouth on strike and put his mind back to work. I note with some satisfaction that the official spokesman for the Opposition, the very competent member for Ryan, has been gracious enough to accept that this measure is one which will be welcomed, particularly by industry. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

(2) Clauses 15, page 8, after sub-clause (1) insert the following sub-clauses:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government , of course, opposes the amendments circulated in the name of the honourable member for Ryan, Mr Moore, which he seemed to move without a great deal of enthusiasm, I might add. As a former distinguished Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, which at the time embraced the Bureau of Customs, I am not surprised that he did not move the amendments with a great deal of enthusiasm because, as such, he will know that the right of officers to enter premises and search for documents to see that the public purse is protected is of paramount importance. The proposition that a warrant should be obtained granting officers a right of entry to commercial premises is, in our opinion, inappropriate for compliance auditing of bounty payments.

SPEECH.PARA: This question has been raised and considered on a number of occasions by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. On all occasions Ministers have responded to the Committee's comments by explaining that the provisions empowering officers with a right of entry without warrant are essential to the equitable and sound administration of any sort of bounty scheme. In fact, that Committee has obviously acknowledged the view that it is not unreasonable for persons who are paid moneys out of the public purse to expect a degree of auditing by investigators to establish that such payments have been correctly made. In its second report, dated 18 May 1983, the Committee stated:

To the extent that such investigation is confined to matters of compliance auditing, the Committee does not see the need to alert the Senate to the possibility of any serious infringement of rights or fundamental liberties.

The Committee went on to say that, while generally accepting the desirability of compliance auditing, the Committee will continue to draw the attention of the Senate to other provisions that come within its terms of reference. The Government's attitude to this question has not changed, and any suggestion by the Opposition that warrants be required for bounty inquiries will continue to be opposed by this Government, with its very keen perception of the taxpayers' right to see that their moneys are protected.

It is worth mentioning that the powers of officers as proposed by the Bounty ( Two-Stroke Engines) Bill 1984 are no more extensive than similar powers contained in the Income Tax Assessment Act. For the Opposition to be suggesting this sort of amendment is parallel to suggesting that taxation officers should not be able to investigate people's accounts without the need for a warrant. I know that the Opposition is pretty good at protecting tax evaders, but I would not have thought it would have gone to that extent. It is in exactly the same spirit that we reject the proposition that before an officer inspects people's tax affairs he should need a warrant, and it is in exactly that sense that we refuse these amendments.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr John Brown)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 30 March, on the following paper presented by Mr Young:
Coastal Surveillance-Ministerial Statement, 30 March 1984.
and on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing this question I would have thought that the Minister who is to assume responsibility for the administration of the new order of things in relation to coastal surveillance would have been here to take this debate. However, the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley), who has been responsible for preparing the review of Australia's peacetime coastal surveillance, is to take the debate. I suppose that is something of a second best.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is one thing to be said immediately about the review and the decision the Government has made, it is a very simple statement indeed, and it is this: Under the changes proposed by the Government there is to be significantly less coastal surveillance than before the changes were made. This is an inescapable fact from the material provided in relation to these changes. For instance, the number of flying hours per year-the rate at which the first two months will be flown-is to be reduced from 20,200 to 14,600. This is a reduction in flying time of something approaching 30 per cent. How the Government can say to the public and to the Parliament that there is an improvement in the rationalisation that is being conducted by reducing the surveillance of Australia's coastline by 30 per cent is something that we will expect it to explain in far more detail than it has done so far.

The Special Minister of State (Mr Young) is, on his own words, no great man for secrecy. He has spoken to this House quite freely on matters other than national security-in fact, about matters concerned in this statement. Before I refer to the remarks that he made recently on Nationwide, let me refer to the statement in the report which predicates the reduction in coastal surveillance. The report states:

In line with this assessment contract aerial surveillance arrangements will be rationalised to provide significant cost savings and minimise the predictability flights over the north Australian coastline and the Great Barrier Reef. Aircraft charter contracts with two companies which expire on April 30 will not be renewed.

This week the program Nationwide dealt with this question from the point of view of the interests of those who run the charters and the interests of the State of Queensland in particular. One of the criticisms of the change from the Nomad aircraft to the Shrike aircraft which is the result of the change in the acceptance of tenders in this matter is that the Shrike aircraft has a radar instrumentation which allows it to view, I think, 38 kilometres laterally, not all round. That is in stark contrast to the old Nomad aircraft, which has a 360- degree radar for something of the order of 120 kilometres.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on the height.

—It may depend on the height. I want to deal particularly with the public statements of the Special Minister of State, especially those he made on Nationwide, when it was put to him that the reduction in radar range was of great significance. The Minister responded to this question:

SPEECH.PARA: But is it as good, Mr Young?
The Minister said:
Well, it takes more flying time, to do it as effectively as what the other system of radar may have done.

The Minister has said it takes more flying time to be as effective, with the changed circumstances, as it was under the old circumstances. What is the change in flying hours? There is a reduction of 30 per cent. The Minister has said publicly that a plane needs more flying hours to do the same job with this less effective radar. I started my remarks with that essential point. The Minister is trying to fudge the issue. He is saying that it is just as good if the plane flies more hours, but in another statement he says that it is flying less hours. He cannot deny those statements. So the reduction in flying hours from 20,200 a year to 14,600 represents a far greater reduction in capacity than those hours indicate, because the effectiveness of the radar is far less than the radar on the planes that are being displaced. One can be sure that under the new arrangements there must be something like half capacity in radar surveillance of our coast. There is another illogical reference in the report. It states:
The Health Department has considered that surveillance was excessive to its needs and the Government has declared that it intends to put less emphasis on health and more on drugs.
That may be a wise decision. In another part of the report, recommendation three states:
The present system is focused on fisheries and quarantine surveillance because these are the interests that are largely brought into being.

Again, this is a contradictory reference to the reasons for the changes being made. I refer again to the Nationwide program in which the Minister, among others, was involved. I have already explained the statements of utmost contradiction that the Minister has made. Those statements tend to raise one's questioning and doubts about the whole change which is being made, when one hears the Minister introduce the subject in the fashion to which I referred. There is no doubt that the Government has seen the task as being one of an overwhelming nature as, I suppose, have all governments. It is an enormous area which has to come under surveillance. The report states:

Customs, to be totally effective, would require a screen to be maintained at a distance from the coastline to provide sufficient warning of all approaches to allow reception of those vessels or aircraft when they land in Australia.

Obviously, this is totally impracticable in respect of intruding aircraft and surface vessels, given the resources required and the volume of aircraft and shipping movements. The report goes on to say:
Information from coastal surveillance is passed to Customs but the present program, with its emphasis on routine visual search of the littoral, provides Customs with very little useful information.

Obviously, the task is great indeed. What has been established is a presence in the face of those who may intrude, unwittingly or by design. In relation to Customs, immigration, quarantine or fisheries, Australia has, over the years in various actions that have been taken, developed a presence which hopefully is a deterrent to those who transgress our laws in these areas. It is really a matter as to whether it is an effective presence. That is obviously what the report is about.

Before I leave the matter of the choice of equipment and aircraft, it is interesting to reflect on the past views of senior members of the Government. A statement was made by the present Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), not long ago on 2 October 1978, when the last major changes were made. The now Minister for Foreign Affairs who was then the Leader of the Opposition was so insistent that at the time he claimed, I believe, that the contracts were rewritten so that the Nomad aircraft became a mandatory choice. It had to be an Australian manufactured aircraft. There was only one that would meet any of the significant requirements. So the Nomad was selected really because of the work of the then Leader of the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think so.
—The reports are here. I can read them. The Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is inconceivable that plans for Australian coastal surveillance should use any other aircraft but the Australian Nomad.

He speaks on this subject in paragraph after paragraph. It is rather instructive now that, having achieved that aim, it is this Government, of which the Foreign Minister is a senior part, which is adopting a system which places the Nomads entirely on the scrap heap, as far as Australian surveillance is concerned. So having forced the issue to make sure the Nomads would be accepted in 1978, he is now part of a government that utterly discards them now.

TALK.START.PARA: —But your Government stopped production of them.

—We do have a mixed bag of Ministers here. They all have something to do with this subject. We have big bear, the Minister for Aviation ( Mr Beazley); middle bear, the Special Minister of State; and little bear, the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris). What a mixed bag of people to be concerned with this subject! I remind the Ministers of another statement by a member of the then Opposition. In 1981-82 the then honourable member for St George said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe and the Australian Labor Party believes that the Government should immediately terminate the current program and place the responsibility for coastal surveillance where it rightly belongs on the defence forces of this country.

So we have a very scattered set of views from the days when the Government was in Opposition. Time runs out very quickly when speaking on these issues. The Government is justifying its move on economic grounds. It is on very slender ground indeed when it is spending something like $20m a year on coastal surveillance and can throw $8m to $10m to public funding of parties in elections . It then considers that it must cut significantly the surveillance of Australia 's coast, to save nothing. It will shuffle the cards and put more resources on the ground to allow more protection.

Let me say in that regard that it is a good move on the part of the Government. The Government has integrated the operations with the State governments and State instrumentalities to set up regional units with those who are involved, whether they be State or Federal and regardless of their place. It will bring them together for a cohesive gathering of information. This must be an advance and one would be silly to say otherwise. But it does represent some expenditure and a shuffling of the cards because I understand the same amount of money is predicated to be spent. The economy is coming from the action arm, the arm of surveillance. Whether it be out to sea or, on our littoral areas. That is where the money is coming from to provide the desirable buildup on the ground. One cannot therefore expect observers of this process to say that it is all marvellous because the Government has made one good move. That good move is made at the expense of the whole program being set up, which is surveillance of the littoral, the Australian fishing zone or other areas of interest. I said that the Government can throw an unwarranted $10m into the electoral system and not blink an eyelid. It can expand the Public Service by 10 per cent at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars a year and that does not matter, but if we need another $5m or $6m to improve Australia's security in relation to quarantine, immigration, health and drugs it comes down to economic persuasion. Economics are involved when we look at those important areas but not when we look at the expansion of the Public Service or the funding of political parties. That does not matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have 6,000 miles of coastline.

—As the honourable member for McPherson says, we have 6,000 miles of coastline. In fact, if we take the littoral, the Australian coastline is probably over 30,000 kilometres in length. One could go on for a long time. We know that the Government cannot escape the responsibility of significantly reducing what it says it is improving. It has failed to enumerate many of the forward looking measures in technology which ultimately must take over, such as satellites and perhaps airships. Who knows? These things are not mentioned in relation to more comprehensive surveillance for longer periods. This report simply does not address itself to the facts. The Government has decided to look at next year's Budget and to cut a miserly few million, in the sense of its responsibilities, by shuffling air surveillance to ground areas of action and leaving Australia more naked to its neighbours in so doing.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aviation and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time I have followed Goldilocks in a debate, but I am sure she has been sleeping in her own bed. A number of points were made by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) that will be taken up by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) when he speaks. A great deal of the allegedly factual data he gave is challengeable. One notable thing he did say was that this is the last time this House will debate coastal surveillance when the primary speakers for either the Government or the Opposition will assume that coastal surveillance in this country is the littoral search associated with civil contracts. One thing that became evident to me as I did this Review of Australia's Peacetime Coastal Surveillance and Protection Arrangements for the Government, along with a number of senior public servants, was that coastal surveillance was much broader than that, and that to meet the problems associated particularly with areas of civil coastal surveillance that were not being covered by littoral search, a very different orientation in the way in which coastal surveillance was conducted, a new emphasis on enforcement rather than just staring at things, would be a much more important aspect of a coastal surveillance regime than it had been to that point. To an extent the civil contracts associated with littoral search had to carry, in the public mind, too much of the load. Functions that those contracts simply could not perform were attributed to them and inadequacies were found in relation to those functions. In the course of the survey we found that some of the attacks made on the effectiveness of civil contracts for littoral search were justified criticisms of coastal surveillance as such but they sought to impose too much on that particlar activity. That activity needed to be seen to some considerable extent in its proper perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I look a little more at the substance of these matters I would like to express my personal thanks to John Rowland, a Deputy Secretary in the Department of Transport; Pat Barrett, an officer of the Department of Finance; and Alan Wrigley, the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Defence, who assisted me in this inquiry. I thank also Alan Thompson from the Department of Defence and staffers Syd Hickman and Maurie Sherry, who undertook a considerable amount of organisational activity.

We were obliged to deal with a number of misconceptions when we set about attempting to devise an appropriate regime for the future of civil coastal surveillance. The first of those misconceptions was the argument being presented , and substantially, put particularly in some of the northern parts of the country, that the organisation of coastal surveillance for civilian purposes ought properly to reside with the Department of Defence. There is no doubt that Department of Defence assets play a considerable role in coastal surveillance for civil purposes and will probably play an increasing role. Very considerable defence assets are involved. The 20 P3C and P3B Orions associated with the Royal Australian Air Force-the RAAF does conduct the bulk of the surveillance of fishing; it is not caried out under civil littoral contracts, as was indicated by the honourable member for Boothby-will continue to perform those functions. Interception and some surveillance activity will continue to be performed by the Fremantle class patrol boats. Submarines provide assistance in some aspects of civil coastal surveillance. To an extent, other defence personnel are placed around the country.

Future defence assets are likely also to play a significant role in civil coastal surveillance. They include, if we get them, airborne early warning and control aircraft, surface ship and submarine towed surveillance, using acoustic arrays and, when it comes on stream of course, Jindalee over-the-horizon radar. All these assets will play a significant role in coastal surveillance. Despite the fact that they will play that role, we needed to address the questioning of whether or not the Department of Defence of itself ought to be the body that conducts coastal surveillance, given its already very high profile. I suggest the combination of those assets already indicates an asset base and activity that dwarfs the civil littoral contracts, but it is something which many people did not appropriately associate with coastal surveillance as it existed at that point. We decided for several reasons that we ought not, however, to proceed with the Defence Department as the principal authority for civil coastal surveillance. The first of those reasons was the cost and the appropriate role of defence assets. Defence assets primarily ought to be judged by the defence purposes they serve, and these are not necessarily going to be in the first instance assets that are the most useful for civil surveillance purposes. In the second instance, the Defence Department, understandably, would have considerable concern, and there would be considerable concern in this country, if it were to pursue its role in coastal surveillance to the extent that it involved in any way a necessity to place hands upon Australian civilians. The defence forces do not have that same concern about protecting our littoral regime against foreign intrusion, but there is that concern in relation to dealing with Australian nationals.

In addition, defence assets are, of their nature, extremely expensive. Were we to use the Orions, for example, for the tasks currently performed by civil aerial littoral contracts, we would be using an asset that is dramatically more expensive for not a great deal of additional achievement. That in itself was another reason for not seeing the Defence Force as an appropriate body to carry out this surveillance. A common misconception in the public mind is that the United States Coastguard is a part of the United States Navy. The uniforms are similar and some of the Coastguard vessels carry very obvious armaments, but it is associated with the US Department of Transport, not the US Department of Defense.

So having set aside the option of involving the defence forces as the controlling rather than the assisting body in the area of coastal surveillance, we addressed other alternatives. We identified several major problems in the system. The first was that interception and enforcement were poorly co-ordinated and inadequate. The second was that the system was over-centralised but offered no coherent career structure for any of the persons involved in it. There was a lack of essential interdepartmental co-operation in many areas which we thought, and several royal commissions thought, ought to play an increasing role in civil coastal surveillance, most notably in regard to the problem of narcotics smuggling.

In the light of those criticisms, we cast about for an appropriate authority to play such a co-ordinating role. Clearly, if it is going to go across the border and have that interception and enforcement capability as well as simply being able to look at things, then there are really only two services to which that applied and they are the Australian Federal Police and the Bureau of Customs. We determined that, overall, the AFP, while deeply involved with Customs and having its trust in a number of areas, already co-operating with it in anti-narcotics operations-although it is involved as an enforcement agency with virtually all Federal departments-probably more than Customs is effectively positioned to be able to assume a co-ordinating role.

That was one of the many criticisms that I found. I found it, too, amongst those involved in the civil contracts for coastal surveillance. Things were sighted and virtually no interception was undertaken. We found that the processes of interception and the processes of reporting the results of interception were extremely haphazard, to say the very least. There was clear evidence of a requirement for far more effective co-ordinated responses and co- ordinated organisation.

Those of us who were involved in the inquiry did not consider that we necessarily had all the answers to the civil requirement. We identified a number of areas of weakness which we did not think we would have time to get ourselves involved in assessing. We thought it would be useful for the subsequent controlling department to examine those areas. Most notable, for example, was the requirement for night time surveillance. There was one evident weakness in our littoral surveillance. On occasions, with the assets available, the aerial littoral search picked up people who were unintentionally and not maliciously entering Australian territorial or economic zone waters. However, any person who sought to deliberately evade it, particularly to deliberately evade it by air, would not, because of the patterns of the patrols, necessarily find that an extremely difficult thing to do. That could occur at night. It could also occur during the day time when the planes were not around. Honourable members should remember that those planes pass over a fixed point at very considerable speed and are unlikely, necessarily, to pick up any person who is attempting to conceal his or her activity. We believe that there is a requirement for that problem to be addressed.

It must be said, I think, that for it to be addressed effectively-like so many other aspects relating to our general defence forces as opposed to purely our civil requirements-we await the effective implementation of the Jindalee radar system and then air and ground activities associated with it. In the absence of that we believe that more work can be done in determining the right sort of equipment for the coastal surveillance unit to use.

In relation to aerial civil contracts we believe that there is a requirement to pursue the policies of the previous Government. Essentially, in relation to the operation of those contracts, the user should pay. The civil contracts were revised by the previous Government, and by this Government from time to time, in accordance with those principles. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs found that the Nomad search that was done out to sea for refugee boats was no longer justified and the previous Government cut out that activity. We did not, in the report, conclude anything in particular about the existing civil contracts. However, when the report was tabled and the interdepartmental committee reported, it was discovered that the Department of Health had reported a lesser requirement. As honourable gentlemen know-though the former speaker, the honourable member for Boothby does not realise it-the Department of Health is responsible for quarantine matters. Effectively, the decisions made by the Government addressed the changed requirement reported to us by the Department of Health. This will have the side effect of freeing up, down the line, resources for the more extensive activity in the area of coastal surveillance that we anticipate arising out of this report. It will, I hope, free up funds available, if this is recommended, for ships and aircraft of a type perhaps more directly associated with the members of the police force and others who will be associated with the coastal surveillance activity.

I think we can look forward to a far more effective coastal surveillance regime . As I said at the outset, the totality of the coastal surveillance regime, the defence assets, the new police assets and the current civil contract assets, all need to be seen as a whole and not taken out and pinpointed separately as was done by the previous speaker from the Opposition.

We expect and are seeking, as has not been sought before, the active co- operation of the States because they have very distinct civil surveillance requirements. We have invited them to come on to co-ordinating committees with us. I am very pleased to be able to say that we have just received from the Western Australian Government an indication of its willingness to join us in this regard. I hope that the Queensland Government and the Northern Territory Government adopt the same view. I am sure they will. In fact, I think the Northern Territory Government already has. When the review is done by the new controlling body, by the State authorities and by our own co-ordinating committees, I think that what will emerge will be a far more effective regime on coastal surveillance at both the search end and the enforcement end. I am very proud to have been associated with the committee process that arrived at these conclusions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 April 1983, over a year ago, the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) was charged with the most important task of conducting an inquiry into a review of Australia's peacetime coastal surveillance and protection. He was requested to examine Australia's needs for coastal surveillance and protection in peacetime and how they are met, and to make a report and recommendations. The recommendations he was to make included recommendations on equipment, facilities and infrastructure and resources most appropriate to fulfil the requirements having regard to national benefit and economy. God knows, he has had plenty of time to do that. He has had over a year to direct his mind to this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: The magnitude of peacetime surveillance and protection tasks faced by this country can be understood if one contemplates two figures only. We have a coastline of about 20,000 kilometres plus the Great Barrier Reef. We have an extended economic zone of roughly 6,500,000 square kilometres, an area just about the same size as Australia's continental land mass. Surveillance and protection is designed, amongst other things, to protect us against illegal migrants, environmental damage such as oil spill damage to the Great Barrier Reef, plunder of our fisheries, damage, whether intentional or unitentional, to our off-shore installations in the North West Shelf and Bass Strait areas, illegal drug running and the introduction of plant and animal diseases.

I will say one or two things about two areas of those problems. We all know about the blight of narcotics that affects this country, of hard drug use. Narcotics are smuggled into this country in a variety of ways. For relevant purposes, there are three ways: There are drops from ships in coastal waters, small boat landings and drops from light planes. There are 540 known air strips within 1,000 nautical miles of Dili in Indonesia and 400 known air strips within 1,000 nautical miles of Bali.

As for diseases, let us contemplate the problems that foot and mouth disease or the introduction of rabies would occasion in this country. Both occur in Indonesia. Rabies is endemic to that country. Reference was made in the report to the damage that would be caused if there was a foot and mouth outbeak. It states:

In its submission to the 1981 Coastal Surveillance Review the Department of Health estimated that rural output could be expected to fall as much as $2,500m in the year of outbreak resulting from the closure of many overseas markets and price reductions in other markets. In subsequent years, losses in rural output could be as high as $1,700m per annum.

That estimate was made in 1981. We would expect from this Government a serious report, a thoughtful report. It has, after all, been highly critical of the previous Government's actions. There is a commitment in the platform of the Australian Labor Party to a coastal protection force. As late as 27 February 1983 the eminent Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes), who was the then Opposition' s spokesman on defence, spoke to the Australian Defence Association on the Australian Labor Party's defence priorities. Mark the words 'defence priorities' . He said:

Coastal surveillance activities should be the responsibility of a coastal protection force under a single unit command with uniform Federal/State legislative authority for operations against smugglers, drugs and illegal immigration, landings or operation within Australia's economic or fishing zones.
That was his commitment. What happened to it? It has disappeared. He continued:
This will entail careful examination of-
1. the types of patrol craft needed for different areas of the Australian coast -
mark that very important and thoughtful statement from a very thoughtful man-
2. the advantages of properly equipped aircraft for coastal surveillance;
3. the specific need to provide patrol boat basing facilities on the north west coast;
4. the need for diversification of coastal surveillance and patrol facilities with special consideration of the needs of northern Australia, the currently neglected south coast, and Tasmania.

So much for the commitments of the Government when in opposition. If one looks at the 10 pages of the recommendations and reads them carefully one will see that effectively they add up to what the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) called a shuffling of the cards. We have a reordering of machinery, co-ordination and control. There is to be no change in the system in the field. There is to be no attempt to answer the recommendations required of the Minister for Aviation. I remind him, since he is in the House, that he was asked to give recommendations on the equipment, facilities, infrastructure and resources most appropriate to fulfil the requirements having regard to national benefit and economy. No new resources are being allocated, although this evening we heard the Minister talk about over-the-horizon radar. I think that he was talking also about an airborne warning and controlling system. When will we get this system? Will it be in the 1990s or the year 2000? The Minister does not know. He does not have the slightest idea. He has done nothing to tell this House about the Government's proposals for coastal surveillance and protection, for the protection of our extended fishing zone and all else that was encompassed within his terms of reference. All he came up with was a bland, round and rotund statement designed to fob off the problems to another day and to another person.

No new resources are being allocated to this most serious of national concerns. Instead we will have a net loss of resources. We will have a loss in flying hours. This matter was referred to by the honourable member for Boothby. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young), in the manner to which we are not unaccustomed, managed to forget to point out that flying hours were going down when he was interviewed on PM. There is to be a real reduction in surveillance. At least the Special Minister of State got that right. I must quote his statement again-it has been quoted also by the honourable member for Boothby- because it is a jewel. He said:
However, the Department of Health maintains that current levels of aerial littoral surveillance are excessive.
I will return to that. He continued:
In line with this assessment contract aerial surveillance arrangements will be rationalised-
Mark the word 'rationalised'; does it not sound intelligent and logical-
to provide significant cost savings and minimise the predictability of flights over the north Australian coastline and the Great Barrier Reef.

If one rationalises and provides significant cost savings one will certainly minimise the predictability of aerial surveillance because one is cutting down on it. The Special Minister of State should have pursued that piece of logic and simply abandoned the flights altogether, in which event he would be able to say that they were wholly unpredictable since they would not be taking place. Let us look at something the Special Minister of State did mention. No doubt it was an oversight on his behalf. He said:
The Department of Health maintains that current levels of aerial littoral surveillance are excessive.
However, what he did not refer to was the other recommendation of the Department of Health, which is to be found in the report. The Department of Health said:
