The Department of Health's review proposes a shift in emphasis from surveillance by aircraft to more regular, routine patrolling by patrol boats and other surface surveillance vessels.

Where was there any mention of that by the Special Minister of State? Where was there any mention of that by the Minister for Aviation? Where has there been any attempt in this report and in the so-called recommendations of the Minister for Aviation to deal with that issue? Nowhere at all. What equipment would we have available to conduct such surveillance? There is talk of using patrol boats. We have nine boats-five in Cairns and four in Darwin-which, subject to repairs and refit, have 10,000 kilometres of coastline to patrol. On top of that we have the discontinuance of the use of the Tracker aircraft and the use of the Nomad aircraft with the far more effective radar which was referred to by the honourable member for Boothby. That represents a very great net diminution in the effectiveness of our surveillance and protection work.

In the report which was presented to us-it took a year in gestation-there was no analysis of the need for search and rescue services. That is a Commonwealth responsibility and one of which we are all grievously aware. It was not so long ago that this House debated the Bass Strait tragedy. Because search and air rescue services could not get to a man in time he died, even though he was found in the waters of the Strait and could be seen there alive and waving, no doubt hoping that somebody would manage to get to him. What of the trawlers in the northern waters? It is not long ago that we all read of the terrible tragedy where two people were taken by a tiger shark after being left in the water. Why does the Government not direct its mind to these sorts of questions? There was not a mention of that in the Minister's recommendation and there was but a fleeting reference to search and rescue in the report itself. This would be a bad enough measure of the shortcomings of the report, but there are others, reflecting on the Government's integrity and the demonstrable incompetence of the Minister for Aviation. Let me read the Minister's recommendation on narcotics:
I recommend that the national surveillance effort in future give more attention to assisting in activities relating to the prevention of the illegal entry of narcotics.

We all agree with that but, as the Minister in charge of the task had a year in which to consider it, one would think he would have told us how that was going to happen. He did not. What else do we have? We have the proposals of the Minister for Defence about a coastal protection force. No mention is really made of that; it is dismissed. That was a commitment solemnly made by the Labor Party on the eve of the election when even the Minister for Defence was able to concentrate his mind on essentials. That proposal has been entirely scrapped.

Let me remind honourable members of the specific issues with which the Government intended to deal. The Government intended to examine the type of patrol craft needed for different areas of the Australian coast. Where has the Minister done that? There is reference to advantages of properly equipped aircraft for coastal surveillance. What do we have of that? What about the specific need to provide patrol boat base facilities in the north-west? That has gone. What about the need for diversification of coastal surveillance and patrol facilities with special consideration of the needs of northern Australia? I ask honourable members to listen to this: What about the currently neglected south coast and Tasmania? Tasmania features in the report only to be dismissed and not given any consideration by the Minister. There is no reference for any need to do anything for Tasmania in the Minister's recommendations.

I will summarise this examination of a long report, a report which has quite a few appendices to it, a report which runs for over 100 pages. It is slipshod; it is padded. It fails to address serious issues. It is bereft of any considered analysis of the terms of reference, raising as they do Australia's need for coastal surveillance and protection which in principle nobody in this House would regard as other than an issue of the highest national importance. We have this from a Minister who has pretentions to be the Minister for Defence. By judgment on his own recommendations he has the sense of direction, purpose, commitment and energy of a school of stranded whales rotting somewhere on the northern coast where they would remain unobserved in the event that this Government continues down the road that it is presently taking. We know why it is going down this road. It is because it does not give a damn what really happens and because it thinks that if it keeps on shuffling the cards and presenting to the people reports which are almost deliberately obscure, somehow the Australian people will be deceived into believing that the Government is a Government of action, integrity and competence when demonstrably on the basis of this report it most certainly is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is the best our eminent QC can glean from reading what is a comprehensive and very valuable report, I can only say: 'Pity help the Opposition'. It is appropriate that he is sitting on the other side with goldilocks rather than over here. The facts are that the coastal surveillance system that was reviewed by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) is the making of those who sit opposite. They spent seven busy years at it. It provides a level of surveillance to Tasmania that Opposition members now deem to be unsatisfactory but it was achieved by their own hands. Glory be to them and let all the thanks and commendations about the quality of surveillance of Tasmania under the system they left us be accredited to them. It is of their own doing.

SPEECH.PARA: Again tonight we have had confessions. We had trotted in the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall ) and others will follow on the trail later. They complained about what they did not do in their seven years of office. I am sorry for the honourable gentlemen. They had their turn. They muffed it and what we have done in the new arrangements is to try to introduce a system that will give better value for the Australian taxpayer's dollar, that will give a much better and more effective coastal surveillance system-a system that will provide a better line of command and control of the coastal surveillance operation, a system that will provide a much speedier response than the shambles that the Opposition left us, and a system in which there will be a much better line of enforcement, all gathered together under a unitary control in this coastal protection unit under the aegis of the Australian Federal Police.

What Opposition members really want, from listening to the discussion tonight, is to keep the system which they developed over seven years. I described it as a Dad's Army effort and on occasions honourable members opposite admitted that. They want it left that way so that they can fiddle with it. It deals with contracts with a nod and a wink. Really, honourable members opposite, particularly the honourable member for Boothby, were complaining about two contractors whose contracts had expired. This is a mixed economy. It is a land of mixed enterprise. There are things such as commercial judgments. Let me deal with the two contracts. One contract was let to a firm called AireSearch Pty Ltd of Townsville and commenced operating in December 1980. It was extended in December 1982. Rather than going to tender with other firms in this mixed economy, firms that would like to supply that service, it was extended in December 1982 by the previous Government. We were then left to extend it again in March 1983, April 1983 and June 1983 until March this year to give time to review the system that those opposite had left us. I must say in respect of AireSearch that that company made a commercial judgment when it tendered. If it did its homework it would have amortised its investment for the period of the contract. That is a commercial judgment. Are we to expect that Australian firms operating in the market place should be featherbedded and should not-

TALK.START.PARA: —But did you ask them to re-tender?

—The Opposition was in Government, not us. The honourable member for Dawson should not come to me with his problems. The company made a commercial judgment in making that investment and in tendering for it. But it did not finish then. Let us compare that with the position of Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd in Western Australia. Under the previous Government its contract expired on the due date. The company tendered against the rest of the market and won the contract again on its merits. I will now give the history of the case of Northern Territory Aerial Work. That contract was originally let to Connair Pty Ltd but, because of the action of that Government, the company sold out to Northern Airlines (Operations) Pty Ltd before it took delivery of the Nomad aircraft which were essential to the provision of the service. In February 1981 Northern Airlines was unable to continue the contract and it sub-let the contract to a firm called trans executive for 60 days.

SPEECH.PARA: At that stage the Northern Territory Government, that great champion of democracy and integrity, stepped in and said to the Commonwealth-to the then Government-that Ansett Airlines of Australia was the only operator that it was prepared to licence for airline and other service operations within the Northern Territory. Northern Airlines then applied to the then Federal Government to assign the coastal surveillance contract to Ansett and that was approved. Again, it was an intrusion in the market place and again it was an intrusion in the rights of firms that would have liked to tender for the provision of that service. Surveillance operations were then carried by NTAW, an Ansett subsidiary . The contracts were re-negotiated and extended until 31 March 1983, after four various extensions because of the late delivery of the Nomads, NTAW could have expected a total of 125 aircraft months of operation under the littoral and off- shore contracts it took over. The refugee or boat people patrols, the Darwin approaches, ceased on 31 March last year. That was a decision taken by those who now sit opposite, not by us. We simply confirmed it. It was their decision. They should not come in here complaining that we have terminated contracts that they determined should be terminated in March last year.

As far as NTAW is concerned, that company received, by extensions, some 39 aircraft months of operation over and above the original contract. Again, I put to those who sit opposite: This is a mixed economy. There is such a thing as a commercial judgment and that judgment was made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Marxist economy.

—The honourable member for Denison can speak for himself. That decision was made by the company. When Connair sold out to Northern Airlines, Northern Airlines valued the assets and liabilities of Connair and the contracts it held. It would have placed a value upon those contracts, a commercial judgment of what they were worth and what they could have yielded. Similarly, when Ansett took over from Northern Airlines, it would have made a commercial judgment on the value; so that case does not stand. The Government has operated in a way that can only be seen as honourable and appropriate in all of the circumstances. As I said earlier, the mess that we inherited was the doing of those who sit opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer now to some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Boothby. But before doing that, I seek leave-the honourable member for Boothby had agreed to this-to incorporate in Hansard a document entitled 'Previous Aerial Charter Arrangements for Coastal Surveillance'. I have approval from the honourable member for Boothby.

TALK.START.PARA: — A ruling has been made by Mr Speaker regarding the incorporation of written material in Hansard.
—This is not lengthy material. It is very brief.
—Mr Speaker has ruled that only charts, tables and things like that will be incorporated in Hansard.
—I will table it, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Do you seek leave to table it? Is leave granted?

—I do not need leave to table it. As a Minister, I can table it. As I explained, the terms of those two contracts were terminated in those circumstances. The reduction in the number of hours was a recommendation of the Department of Health. It is in the report. It is very easy to see. Obviously, the honourable member for North Sydney was not able to glean that from the report. It is there in bold type. The reasons are given for it. Is there anything more ludicrous than having a littoral surveillance in a time of monsoon when the coastline, the littoral, is floodbound? Does the honourable member really believe that people will make illegal entry into the Australian coast in small boats from the vast north at a time when the whole area is floodbound? The Department of Health said in its submission that there would be better value for the Australian taxpayer and better protection against quarantine breach when there was a better organisation of the utilisation of aerial surveillance and surface craft surveillance.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Boothby talked about the range of the Lytton 360 degree radar. I think he took his information from the segment on Nationwide on Australian Boardcasting Corporation television last night. It showed that a Nomad aircraft with Lytton radar had a range of 125 kilometres. Sure, it has-at 10,000 feet. I am quite sure that a Nomad aircraft at 10,000 feet, which is the limit of its operating height can see a lot. It may even detect a small craft in difficulty at 10,000 feet. But the comparison was made with the side looking airborne radar system of the Shrike aircraft at 1,500 feet. It is a simple matter of geometry. If one aircraft is at 1,500 feet and the other is at 10,000 feet the aircraft at 10,000 feet will have a much wider span. It is completely dishonest to put that argument against those aircraft. It is a total misrepresentation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But your Minister said it; your colleague said it.

—I am explaining it to you so you will understand, Goldilocks. I do not have time to repeat it but that is the position. The simple fact is that the SLAR system is half the price of the Lytton system. It is used by the Swedish coastguard. I imagine that it would have assessed its effectiveness beforehand. It is used by seven other national systems around the world quite effectively. For the purposes for which it is now being delineated in coastal surveillance it is effective and appropriate. It is a total misrepresentation on the part of any of those involved to suggest that it is a weaker system than the Lytton 360 degree system.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a tragedy that people have attacked Skywest and its employees and attempted to disparage that firm to the vested interest of AireSearch and NTAW. I think it is quite sad. I have flown with the people of Skywest. I have flown with AireSearch and I have inspected the facilities of NTAW. I have the greatest confidence in the personnel of each of the three firms in their professionalism and dedication to their services on behalf of this country. No one has suggested in the past that the personnel of Skywest do a lesser quality job in the task of coastal surveillance than those of AireSearch or NTAW. What we have heard from the Opposition, some sections of the media in recent days and certainly from the lobbyists of AireSearch has been a very distorted and dishonest emotional campaign. It was designed to advance the financial interest of two organisations , without having regard to the fact that it disparaged the professionalism and dedication of all the people who serve in coastal surveillance.

I am positive that the new arrangements will be more effective, that they will allow heightened co-operation with the States and a more efficient utilisation of total resources. Originally, civil coastal surveillance co-ordination became part of the responsibilities of the transport portfolio mainly because my Department operated a 24-hour a day, seven days a week Marine Operations Centre. Its principal role was, and remains, marine search and rescue and the safety of life at sea. Over three-quarters of its work load is related to this service. I reassure the maritime industry and those who serve at sea that the Centre's primary function will continue. It will also continue to be controlled and manned by officers of my Department. The experience, expertise and professionalism built up by the Centre will be maintained and improved.

After the Centre was set up it became increasingly a focus for all kinds of information about unusual occurrences in the maritime zone. It was logical and cost effective to use it for the receipt of surveillance reports. This role will be maintained. The Coastal Protection Unit will now be a joint user of the Centre. An officer of the Unit will be posted there, able to monitor, analyse and interpret information received through its extensive communication facilities and to initiate response action. Current plans provide that some members of the Coastal Protection Unit will be located on the same floor of the Centre when it moves into the first stage of new offices for my Department in Canberra City in July or August next. This will have the Centre--

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing about night surveillance?

—What did the former Government do in seven years? It did absolutely nothing. The honourable member should not come to me with his problems. This will have the Centre located with the Department and in close proximity to the central offices of the Australian Federal Police and the Department of Aviation. Additionally, the Department of Transport will maintain the contracting, supervision and training of civil contractors engaged in the performance of coastal surveillance tasks, tasks which it has undertaken previously and which it has the skills and experience to continue to provide for the benefit of the Coastal Protection Unit. Policy co-ordination and the direction of effort including response, system development and evaluation will be the role of the Coastal Protection Unit, responsible to my colleague the Special Minister of State (Mr Young).

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will have noted that the new arrangements retain the sensible aspects of the previous scheme. These include the undoubted discipline of the user pays arrangements, co-ordination of Commonwealth effort and effective utilisation of a significant defence resource contribution. The new arrangements, however, set in place features, including other new features, which will be welcomed by all Australians, particularly those in north Australia . The certain identification of those responsible for coastal protection, the establishment of regional centres in the North for those departments sharing interests and responsibilities in this important area and the establishment of formal liaison arrangements with State governments are significant steps forward . Their value will become more apparent as the new system is developed and put into place. I commend the new arrangements to honourable members and I register my commendation of the Minister for Aviation for this thorough and comprehensive report in what was a very difficult task in a system left to us after seven years of incompetence, bungling and mismanagement by those who now sit opposite and seek to blame us for their own inefficiencies and defects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister.

-Order! It is the usual practice, when anyone claims to have been misrepresented, to come to the Chair beforehand and discuss the matter. There is some business before the Chair before the honourable member for Boothby will be heard.
—Can I take a point of order?

—Perhaps the honourable member will just give the Chair a moment. The Miniser for Transport asked that a document be tabled. While a Minister may present a paper at any time when other business is not before the House and not require leave, to present a paper, when the House is debating a motion before it he requires leave. Is leave granted for the Minister to table the document? There being no objection, leave is granted. The document is tabled . I call the honourable member for Boothby.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise with no disrespect to you at all. If I have transgressed in not speaking to you, I apologise. However, I rise under the respective standing order, which I understand allows me to make a personal explanation if I am not interrupting a member who is on his feet at the time. Is my understanding correct?
—Yes. Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is a straight transgression by the honourable member against your earlier ruling.

—No it is not. My ruling was that it is a matter of courtesy to the Chair which is usually observed. I now call the honourable member for Boothby to make a quick explanation of how he has been misrepresented.
—The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) who is at the table , has claimed that Opposition speakers have criticised the employees--
—Has the honourable member been personally misrepresented?

—He personally misrepresented me in claiming that I had criticised the firm Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd and, by imputation, its employees. I have not. Nowhere in my speech did I criticise the firm Skywest for any proposition whatsoever. My criticism was directed quite clearly at the Ministers responsible for the change in policy in relation to Australian coastal surveillance.
—Order!

—If I may finish on this point: We are concerned about the choice of equipment, which severely limits the performance of those who provide this service in relation to what they can survey. I must reject any claim that I have criticised the personnel, for whom I have the greatest admiration but who will now have to continue their work with less efficient equipment at their disposal because of this Minister's agreement with the change.
—Order! I do not think we need a protracted debate.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek a similar indulgence from you on the same matter. I think that such a request is reasonable and fair.
—If the Minister can be short and sweet about it, I will allow him to speak.

—Well, I will try to do better than the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). The fact is that the Opposition, including the honourable member, has cast aspersions on the quality of the new arrangements and the effectiveness of the service. That service is being provided by the same personnel who operated for Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd for some years. By the criticism he has heaped upon the service and the aspersions he has cast on it he is directly criticising the people who provide the service.
—Order! The Minister is going far beyond a personal explanation. He is debating the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to assure the Government that it is not a matter of attacking Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd or protecting the interests of the contractors, as was implied by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris). There is certainly no attack on Skywest. You will appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I have no animosity towards Skywest. In fact, I have recently flown with that airline. The Opposition is attacking Government practices. It takes Ministers on the other side of the table a heck of a long time to get it through their heads that they are under attack. They are probably unaware of this because they have such thick hides. The imputation by the Minister for Transport that we have supported two contractors in the eastern and northern coasts is not in keeping with the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the Minister leaves the chamber I would like to make a comment in connection with commercial transactions. All the firms involved in coastal surveillance contracts entered into a commercial transaction. We are asking that the people who provided the services and the aircraft be given the right to make a commercial decision as to what the cost of fresh arrangements would be. There is no way in the wide world that the Government can say this is not a fresh arrangement. It is not correct to suggest, as the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) did early last month, that the whole arrangement is a deployment. It is not a deployment, it is a fresh arrangement. I am sure that the three companies which have an interest in the contract believe that the Government will put this matter beyond question. I believe that this is the correct way to handle such a matter. I hope the Minister recognises the fact that he is under attack, not Skywest.

I agree that a tremendous amount of work has been put into the Review of Australia's Peacetime Coastal Surveillance and Protection Arrangments by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley). The review was necessary and I believe that the work the Minister has done is of great value to this Parliament. Obviously the recommendations in the report have been taken into account by the Government . In saying that, again we are not decrying or attacking the report. What we are trying to do is sift the facts on which the Government is now basing its decision. No one suggests that the arrangements were not necessary. No one suggests the surveillance of Australia should not be put in the hands of one authority instead of the mish mash that existed before. What more appropriate authority could one have than the Australian Federal Police centred in Canberra, where it can be readily contacted and can handle any emergency situation that may arise. This arrangement will also allow the Australian Federal Police to do all the other things that need to be done with the information it will receive.

Honourable members with electorates around the coastline from the Northern Territory right round to the electorate of Dawson, are vitally concerned about surveillance of Australia, and they are in the chamber tonight. The comments of some of my colleagues on this matter prior to the presentation of the report and the Government's decision emphasised that the continuation of surveillance was absolutely vital. I want to refer to a comment made by the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) which was reported in the Innisfail Advocate. He said:

'I told the Minister for Aviation, Mr Beazley, it was imperative that constant and adequate surveillance be maintained along the 1,200 miles of Queensland coastline bounded by the Great Barrier Reef' . . .
The newspaper also reports the honourable member as saying that the role of coastal surveillance involves much more than might be initially indicated by just surveying the coast. He continued:
It also involves search and rescue, ship source pollution, merchant vessel movements, and protection of historic shipwrecks and marine life.

I believe that that is a very adequate reflection of what the people of North Queensland and, I suggest, the Northern Territory, feel about this. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), who is also in the chamber tonight , has stressed that there should be no downgrading of the present standard of the surveillance service and that surveillance should be improved, the search and rescue capability maximised and the deterrent effect enhanced. I believe that these comments were recorded in the Cairns Post on 17 December 1982.

It is interesting to note the views of these two honourable members following the statement by the Minister late in March. The honourable member for Herbert is now saying that coastal surveillance should not be confused with air-sea rescue. I believe that air-sea rescue is a very important aspect of coastal surveillance. The honourable member for Leichhardt was reported as saying on 4 April that 'not a single arrest for drug smuggling had been made as a result of air surveillance' and that criticism of the new arrangements was unwarranted. Yet item 3.37 of the report we are discussing tonight sets out the sightings, the reports and the follow-ups by Customs and the transgressions that were prosecuted. It is interesting that all the transgressions that ended in prosecution resulted from sightings by Nomad aircraft. I think that that fact is significant in itself. If we are to make judgment of the effectiveness of the aircraft and equipment used to date for surveillance purposes we must come down on the side of the Nomad aircraft.

We have the suggestion that there has been no downgrading of surveillance. Yet, the cost aspect has been very relevant in all the discussions we have heard. In fact, I would suggest that in making the original statement a cost saving exercise involving $1m or $2m was paramount in the mind of the Government. I believe that the Government has reduced the efficiency of the service by adopting this course. In addition, it has put aside the normal practices of government in terms of calling for tenders and allowing individuals to compete for the best price. Australia will not have the best surveillance available by opting for the cheapest alternative, and I believe the Government has failed in this regard.

About two weeks ago I took the opportunity to fly in the Nomad aircraft and I was able to observe the use that is made of its equipment. I cannot say that I have been in the Shrike aircraft or observed the side-looking airborne radar that is carried by that aircraft. However, I can say that I am impressed by what the Nomad aircraft did. The radar observer was able to direct the pilot right on to a target by using information transferred from the back of the aircraft. I understand that the equipment has no equal in the world today. We have been talking about over-the-horizon radar. But when, in the name of goodness, will we get it? Can Australia be left undefended? We need this facility immediately to deter other people from the temptation to offend against our laws.

I understand that the side-looking airborne radar is not immediately available for the Shrike aircraft to put into use. With one contract having been terminated at the end of April, the equipment necessary to go ahead with the surveillance contemplated is not available. So for just one month Australia is undefended. Do we tell the rest of the world that for a month it is open market in Australia and the people can do what they like? This decision is a shortcoming of the Government.

There is no suggestion in the new arrangements as to who is to bear the cost of the new equipment. Will the Government bear the cost? Has that factor been taken into account? I understand that the equipment costs between $350,000 and $500, 000 a set. Who will bear this cost? Will Skywest be given the opportunity to acquire it and increase its charge? This has not been mentioned. However, I understand that the Government intends to buy the equipment. What a great commercial arrangement that is! There will be an aircraft fitted with equipment belonging to two separate owners. I believe these matters should be understood. I really want to come to the basis of what has been accepted under the regulations of the Australian Parliament. I refer to the finance regulations and finance directions applicable to all Commonwealth Departments. Section 25 refers to tenders and quotations and states:

The underlying intention of regulations 51, 52, 52AA and 53 is that Government procurement procedures should be, and be seen to be, beyond reproach: ie, that all who wish to participate in Government business are given the opportunity to do so: That the Government maintains a reputation for fair dealing . . .

The question that has to be asked in this case is whether the Government has maintained a reputation for fair dealing and given all who wish to participate in government business the chance to do so. I suggest that that is not the case. The mischievous excuse of redeployment has been used. I refer now to the regulations relating to exemptions from quotations and tendering procedures. They state:
Regulation 52AA (2) empowers the Secretary to the Department of Finance to certify that, for certain kinds of supply, it is impracticable or inexpedient to use the tender or quotation procedures.

In these cases a 'certificate of exemption' can be issued. The question has to be asked: Was that permission sought and was that certificate of exemption given ? I would suggest in both cases that the Government has failed its own tests under the Audit Act in this regard. Because of what was revealed in the Beazley report I believe that everybody should be given the chance to retender. It should have been a commercial decision in the first instance. The cost of the aircraft would have been written off in the period of the contract. Is it not obvious that that same company now, in the face of competitition, the reduced cost and the depreciated value of the aircraft, could lower its tender?
On 4 April 1984, during an adjournment debate, I asked two questions. The same two questions have not yet been answered by the Government in this debate. I asked:
Firstly, is the cost of the reduction in the service worth the downgrading of coastal surveillance?
I refer particularly to night surveillance. I then asked:
Secondly, why, if the standard of surveillance is to be downgraded, was the revised program not put out to normal tender by the Government in preference to the Minister's opinion?
All that the Special Minister of State could say was this:

. . . people make a commercial decision when they tender for a government contract, whatever their field may be. They make their capital investment based on the successful tender that they may be granted, and that is what these people have done.
I suggest that these people have not been allowed to retender in accordance with the new circumstances. But the Minister wiped all of these questions by just saying 'we are redeploying'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie. That is a lie and you know it.
—I would like that comment withdrawn. The Minister was not even listening to what I was saying. He is as thick in the hair as he is in the head and I believe he should withdraw the comment.

—Order! The honourable member for Dawson has sought a withdrawal of the comment by the Minister for Transport. Obviously he is a little sensitive about that comment. Would the Minister for Transport withdraw the remark he made?
—I seek a mutual withdrawal, Mr Deputy Speaker. I withdraw but I seek a mutual withdrawal of a similar offensive comment from the honourable member for Dawson.

—The Minister for Transport has withdrawn his offensive remark . He also was offended by the comment made by the honourable member for Dawson. Would the honourable member for Dawson withdraw his remark.

—It surprises me that he could be offended but I will withdraw. There are more matters to this surveillance than meets the eye. If the surveillance scheme is to be taken out of the hands of this Parliament the Government should be called to account for all these aspects now. We are talking about search and rescue. What price does the Government place on the value of a life? That is one of the main aspects of what we are talking about.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reeves Mr J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The distance between the most northern part of the Northern Territory's coastline and East Timor is about 400 kilometres. The distance between the most northern tip of Cape York and Papua New Guinea is about 140 kilometres. To put those figures in context for those southerners in this House who have spoken tonight, the Northern Territory-East Timor distance is about the same as the distance between Sydney and Dubbo or between Melbourne and Mount Gambier. The Cape York-Papua New Guinea distance is shorter than the distance between Sydney and Newcastle or between Melbourne and Bendigo.

SPEECH.PARA: If the people of Sydney thought that there was in the Dubbo or Newcastle area or if the people of Melbourne thought that there was in the Mount Gambier area or Bendigo area a rabies outbreak, a hostile army, an illicit drug operation or thousands of people who wanted to get into Sydney or Melbourne, they would throw up the largest barriers they possibly could and guard them day and night to try to stop the entry of the plague, the army, the drugs or the fleeing refugees. Unfortunately, Australia's concern about these types of problems, about diseases , drug smuggling and illegal immigrants in northern Australia reduces in inverse proportion to the distance beween the south east triangle of Australia and the area affected wherever that area is, whether in Australia or not.

The best example of that syndrome is the fact that the vast majority of Australia's Defence Force is still stationed in our south east corner and not in the north of Australia where any threat to Australia is most likely to come. In northern Australia, specifically in the Northern Territory, the concern about these problems is real and considerable. Thus coastal surveillance is a very real and sensitive issue in the north. Australia has operated some form of coastal surveillance for many years. This surveillance has been done by the Department of Defence, the Australian Customs Bureau, the Department of Transport and many others. In the past five or six years there have been two reviews of Australia's coastal surveillance operations, one in 1978 and the recent review which has led to this debate.

So far as the Northern Territory is concerned the recommendations in 'A Review of Australia's Peacetime Coastal Surveillance and Protection Arrangements' have two broad effects. Firstly, the existing coastal surveillance contracts with Northern Territory Aerial Work Pty Ltd have been terminated, effective from last Monday. Secondly, a regional office of the new Coastal Protection Unit will be established in Darwin thus ensuring better local co-operation of coastal surveillance in the north and a more effective response mechanism for coastal surveillance in the Northern Territory. As a result of the first broad effect I mentioned, 37 people in Darwin lost their jobs. I think I should make a number of points about that. Firstly, it was the previous Fraser Government which killed Northern Territory Aerial Work Pty Ltd some 2 years ago. It did that by by removing the tender conditions that it specifically set that forced contractors to use Nomads.

It is interesting to note that tonight the Opposition's spokesman on Northern Territory development was telling us that Nomads are the answer. A couple of years ago his Government specifically changed the rules and forced Northern Territory Aerial Work into using Nomads and then changed the rules half-way through the contract and left that company stranded. If Northern Territory Aerial Work had been able to tender for contracts it could not have competed because it was competing against cheaper planes, such as the Shrike, that the former Government allowed into the contract.

The second aspect of this broad first effect that I am referring to is that, having dealt this death blow to NTAW, the former Government did not have the decency to bury it. Why? Because an early election was coming up. Instead, it extended the contracts for short periods to try to tide it over the election period. It did not tell NTAW what it had in mind. It did not tell the people of the Northern Territory what it was going to do about coastal surveillance. By contrast, in the past 14 months this Government has carried out a very complete and detailed review of coastal surveillance in Australia. I compliment the Minister for Aviation Mr Beazley, on the excellent report that he has produced. It sets out clearly the Government's position on coastal surveillance and the recommendations contained in it have introduced some certainty into the future of coastal surveillance.

Thirdly, while the previous Government is directly responsible for what happened to NTAW, this Government is concerned about the people who lost their jobs. Both the Office of the Special Minister of State and I have had discussions with Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd and Hawker Pacific Pty Ltd about the employment prospects which can be offered by those two companies when they establish facilities in Darwin. It is good to see that three of the observers have already got employment with Skywest, and it is reported that one or two more have prospects of employment as well. Several engineers have found employment but, so far as the pilots are concerned, the picture may not be as bright. Northern Territory Aerial Work is a subsidiary of Ansett Airlines of Australia. Despite that Ansett has refused to take on the pilots displaced by the decision. Ansett seems to have wiped its hands of these pilots. However, Skywest is interested in setting up a facility in Darwin not only for coastal surveillance but also for its regular passenger transport operations. The establishment of such a facility will open up employment opportunities for the pilots displaced in Darwin.

The fourth point that I would like to make about the NTAW situation relates to the amount of notice it received. As has already been observed tonight, any government contractor has to run the gauntlet of tendering for ongoing contracts such as this. Northern Territory Aerial Work had no guarantee it would continue to get this contract. Given the position it was put in by the previous Government whereby it was forced into buying more expensive aircraft it really did not have much chance of winning the contract if it tendered. But I do think that in the particular circumstances NTAW should have been given more time than one month's notice of the termination of its contract-perhaps a few months more.

The debate about the future of the former NTAW employees has overshadowed the announced changes to the coastal surveillance system and the benefits which will flow from those changes. The table at page 3-24 of the report entitled 'A Review of Australia's Peacetime Coastal Surveillance and Protection Arrangements' indicates the broad range of departments and incidents which are or could be covered by coastal surveillance. The table nominates 14 departments which have an interest in coastal surveillance, and it also nominates 21 separate tasks covered by coastal surveillance, from quarantine to the inspection of navigational aids.

In the past the major task of coastal surveillance has been quarantine. The Northern Territory office of the Federal Department of Health made a submission to the review conducted by Mr Beazley, and it made a number of fairly relevant points in the quarantine surveillance area. The first point that I would like to refer to is the fact that the Department's assessment is based on five years actual experience in coastal surveillance. With that experience the Department is probably in the best position to assess quarantine needs. What is more, if it happens to be wrong, the Department will be responsible. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has already pointed to the section of the report which sets out what effect a rabies scare or plague in Australia may have on our primary industry. The figures contained in the report are certainly very sobering. I suggest that the report recommends a system which will ensure that there is a better system of co-ordination and response in coastal surveillance in relation to quarantine and a number of other areas.

The second point on which the Northern Territory section of the Department of Health made some comment is that of the 95 sightings concerning quarantine in the Northern Territory since March 1982, two involved actual breaches of quarantine regulations or legislation. The Department points out that each of these breaches of quarantine costs over $1m to detect. It went on to point out that the overall quarantine threat is, in its assessment, very low. This is not a case of somebody making this assessment from ivory towers in Canberra; it was done by the Northern Territory establishment of the Federal Department of Health -the people on the ground in the Northern Territory.

Further, the Department has said that it would favour the banning of pets on foreign fishing vessels licensed to fish in the Australian fishing zone. That is aimed at reducing the threat that they pose through the introduction of rabies. I think that suggestion should be followed up and acted on. The Department states further that in many instances responses have been rather unprofessional and disorganised. This supports many other similar suggestions, and it is dealt with by the recommendations in the report, to establish a coastal protection unit under the Australian Federal Police with a regional co-ordination unit in Darwin. The Department of Health concluded that it favoured a military based surveillance system. That view is not supported by the recommendations in the report for two reasons. Firstly, the Australian Federal Police is responsible for law enforcement and it is not really the role of the Department of Defence to conduct law enforcement in Australia. Secondly, as is indicated by the report , the cost of a coastal protection force was estimated at between $365m and $ 450m in capital costs in 1977 figures, and a further $55m a year in operational costs thereafter. That is clearly an enormous expense. The Federal Department of Health's submissions have raised many of the issues relevant to quarantine. The report also recommends boosting surveillance on drug smuggling. This recommendation is very important because, as the Customs and police operations become more effective in detecting entries through traditional ports in Australia, illegal drug entry through remote areas of the north is likely to increase.

As I said earlier, the Minister should be commended on his report. It is very unfortunate that one section of the media in the Northern Territory, specifically the Northern Territory News, has chosen to attack the report and its recommendations. On this issue the Northern Territory News has continued its biased campaign against the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Labor Government. I do not know which of the two is worse-the Northern Territory News or the Northern Territory Government. But it is very interesting to contrast its attitude towards the decision made by this Government with a very similar decision made by the previous Government just over two years ago. In January 1982 the former Government made a decision relating to coastal surveillance. That is the decision that has been referred to about changing the rules on the Nomads. An editorial in the Northern Territory News had this to say about it:

Improved radar, communications and navigation equipment will undoubtedly make better use of airborne hours. And provided the same efficiency can be obtained from more cheaply-operated aircraft, there is no reason why the relatively expensive Nomads should be retained, other than for the approaches to Darwin and along the Great Barrier Reef.
Two years later, when this Government made a decision in basically the same areas, the newspaper had this to say:
The Nomad surveillance aircraft with their excellent radar equipment will be replaced by smaller, cheaper aircraft which will conduct what amounts to no more than beach patrols.
For those honourable members who have any doubt about what the newspaper said about the overall effect of the previous Government's decision, I shall quote from the editorial of 12 January 1982-

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Live Sheep Exports-Aeterna Lucina-Australian Coal Industry-Flinders Electorate: Unemployment-Australia Post Mail Delivery System-Orthomolecular Medicine-Death of Hon. Lindsay North

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to talk briefly about the live sheep export trade, which is worth over $150m to the Australian economy. Every year it involves the export of over six million live sheep. Of those six million, over one and a half million go through the port of Portland. During the last six years there have been several inquiries into the live sheep trade. These inquiries have repeatedly shown that the live sheep trade should continue. They have also reiterated that the net effects of the live sheep trade on employment are beneficial to Australia. In releasing last year the most recent report of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the scope of the BAE report is much wider than the employment implications of the live sheep trade, its clear message is that retricting the live trade would be self-defeating, ultimately resulting in a smaller national flock and fewer slaughterings in Australia.
Mr Kerin went on to say:

The BAE study presents strong evidence that the live sheep trade leads to an increase in the number of females in the Australian flock and more lambs are produced. This is turn provides more animals for the carcass trade and to renew the national flock.

In Portland, which I mentioned earlier, we have a rather strange situation. Over the last three weeks in particular three ships have been loaded there, but every truck that takes sheep into the wharf has to go across a picket line composed of a small group of picketers. This picket line is not endorsed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, but it is a remarkable thing that the Cain Labor Government has given a new status to this picket line. The Cain Labor Government has given a directive to the Victoria Police to allow these unionists in the picket line to 'put their point of view'. This means that the picketers can direct the Victoria Police to stop every truck that goes across that picket line . This is in fact what is happening. So a truck which may cross the picket line 10 times in one day has to stop every time at the direction of the Victoria Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a police state.
—It sounds like it. I believe that this is quite a remarkable situation when the Cain Government is endorsing a picket line which the ACTU will not.
—Don't you care about the workers from Borthwicks?

—I say for the benefit of the honourable member for Melbourne that if he reads the BAE report he will find that more employment is created by this trade than was ever taken away by it. As I was saying, it represents gross interference with the responsibilities of the Victoria Police to have the Victorian Government directing the police to take their orders from a picket line. I believe this is quite outrageous. To prove that I support those truck drivers and waterside workers and quite a few other unions in Portland who go across that picket line, I crossed that picket line this week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to draw attention to a subject I raised in the House some time ago. It concerns what I consider to be treasonable action in the establishment of the so-called sovereign state of Aeterna Lucina by a Dr Neuman, a German national in New South Wales. Anyone who doubts the veracity of my statements has only to look at various Press reports. I draw the attention of honourable members to the following headlines: 'Bush monarch rules a health State'. This came from the Daily Telegraph of 16 January 1984. The Brisbane Sun of 12 February had the following headliner: 'Strawberry Lord Rules Regal Fray'. I have a copy of a local paper, the Cooma-Monaro Express of 1 December 1983, which is headed: 'State of Eternal Light'-Aeterna Lucina is apparently some crude latinisation of that phrase 'just 50 kilometres from Cooma '.

SPEECH.PARA: This gentleman, Dr Neuman, has devised a neat scheme. He has preyed upon the hopes and fears of people in Germany and has induced them to buy property in Australia. He has acquired some hilltop land in the Snowy Mountains , worth probably about $40 an acre, and he has sold it to unsuspecting families in Germany for $3,000 for each building block. Of course, he maintains the title to this land under the Torrens land title system as it operates in New South Wales, but he sells them a land title in the sovereign state of Aesterna Lucina. So these people have no title whatsoever. This is really an outrageous confidence trick. It is to the eternal shame of this House that Dr Neuman has been aided and abetted by the actions of the then Minister for Trade, Mr Doug Anthony, who presented this House with a petition which called upon the Government 'to give moral support to the 'Sovereign Humanitarian Mission 17 State Aeterna Lucina'. The words 'moral support' are significant. Government approval has not been asked for at all. That was a fait accompli. Those who signed that petition accepted that. They are merely asking the Parliament to endorse the setting up of a sovereign state in this country. When this same idea was tried in Germany, within three days the German Government dispatched the Army-not the police, but the Army-to make it known to the people that the Government would have none of that nonsense.

The real tragedy is that people's lives and hopes have been involved. People who understand Europe know that in Europe lots of fiddling little states exist over there. I refer to places like Lichtenstein or Monaco. We understand why people in Germany would have been fooled, particularly when they saw the sorts of publications which were supplied. Photocopies of these publications show the quality of the paper on which they are printed. One document is headed: ' Declaration of Independence and Constitution'. Another is headed 'Dreams and Realities', and a third is headed 'A Promised Land, the Sovereign State of Aeterna Lucina'.

I have elaborate certificates of citizenship. The ploy was that people were told that because Aeterna Lucina was an island within Australia, they could come to Australia, virtually walk across the border and be guaranteed permanent residence. I have a copy of the Land Act, if you please, headed: The Supreme- Lord of The Sovereign State Aeterna Lucina', which is an Act relating to the declaration of title of land and to facilitation of its transfer. That is very very impressive stuff, particularly when it was sent to the people in Germany accompanied by these Australian Press cuttings to which I referred. I have letters written by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) supporting Dr Neuman. On 18 April 1983 Dr Neuman sent a letter, which stated words to this effect: 'I am forwarding correspondence asking for help'. The honourable member for Warringah replied that he would be happy to give help. I ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), to extend compassion to these people who have been fooled and conned by this confidence trick, taken in, aided and abetted by prominent members of the Opposition. I hope that the Minister will extend permanent residence in Australia to these people. They are all thoroughly good families. I have met them all. I am sure they can make a contribution to this country, and I ask our very compassionate Minister to take into account that these people were outrageously misled in part by the honourable member for Warringah and Doug Anthony and, I might add, by the Foreign Minister at that time. It is absolutely mindboggling and unbelievable that these same Opposition members who wax eloquent about our heritage should be prepared without question to give away this sovereign state in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I should say at the commencement of these remarks that I did endeavour to notify the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) that I would be speaking on this subject in the adjournment debate, but I ascertained when I rang his office that he had already departed for Sydney prior to going overseas. I want to raise a number of matters which affect him relating to the present dispute over the collapse of some parts of the Australian coal industry, particularly in relation to the reduction of the Japanese price.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last 24 hours we have been treated to the spectacle of the Deputy Prime Minister roundly condemning two Australian companies for the price reduction in the Japanese coal market. There has now come into my possession some information which indicates that, far from those companies being responsible, it could have been the conduct of the Minister himself which was responsible for sabotaging the coal price negotiations of Japan. Four months ago the Minister for Trade approved a 400,000 tonne coal contract with Pakistan at $ 2 a tonne below the Japanese steel mill price.

TALK.START.PARA: —Repeat it.

—It was $2 a tonne below the Japanese steel mill price. This was four months ago that the Minister for Trade approved a contract involving 400,000 tonnes of coal. The news of this contract must have come into the possession of the Japanese. It is inconceivable that the Japanese negotiating with the Australian coal companies were not aware that the Minister and the Australian Government had given this permission some four months ago. I also understand that this approval was given to a company not listed among those now blamed by the Government for the latest price fall, and that it was justified by the Government at the time on the false grounds that it involved an extension of an incomplete contract. In fact, that contract had expired several months previously. There is no doubt that the Japanese steel industry would have been aware of the Minister's endorsement of this breach of what were supposed to be firm price guidelines before the present negotiations began. Importantly, other exporters who had accepted governmental instructions to tender for the Pakistan contract on the basis of the agreed price guidelines were, in effect, doublecrossed by the Minister's acceptance of the discounted price without giving them the opportunity to match it. The unsuccessful tenderers warned the Government at the time that this would provide a disastrous precedent for the present reduction in coal export prices to Japan and they objected strongly to the Minister's guideline-breaking decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Against this sort of background it is incredible that the Minister is now, in blaming the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd and the Utah Development Company , seeking scapegoats for the price cuts that his own actions of four months ago must have made inevitable. Not only did the Minister for Trade undermine the negotiations, the collapse of which he is now blaming on BHP and Utah, but also those companies were subject to the disastrous consequences of a prime ministerial visit to Japan only a couple of months ago. While the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was in Japan giving false hopes about the way his special relationship with the Japanese Government would protect Australian exporters, the Japanese suspended coal contract negotiations with Australia in view of the impossible situation generated by the Prime Minister's totally false assertions.

The fact is that the Minister for Trade should immediately stop blaming BHP and Utah for what is happening. If he insists on an absurd policy of Government intervention in these kinds of negotiations, he has to accept the natural and probable consequences of his own stupid decisions in the course of those interventions. He approved that Pakistan coal contract four months ago. When he approved it he knew that knowledge of it had to come into the possession of the Japanese, and it is that knowledge more than anything else which has led to the disastrous outcome that has now occurred in relation to the Japanese coal contracts. Finally, I can tell the House that I was aware of this information some time ago but deliberately refrained from making any reference to it until the negotiations with the Japanese steel mills had been completed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish this evening to bring to the notice of the House the serious problem of unemployment within the electorate of Flinders. We have approximately 9,000 unemployed amongst those who live in Flinders. We have few major industries which are capable of expansion or are in an expansionary phase. We have had a large increase in employment within the building industry, which is a direct result of Government policies. We have also been granted over $2m for various community employment program schemes. However, this has only scratched the surface of this huge problem. Many unemployed have come to me for assistance with the many problems that they encounter as members of a very disadvantaged group.

SPEECH.PARA: I am the elected representative of all the people of flinders, including the unemployed, and I would like to suggest some actions to help alleviate the problem of unemployment. First, I would like the Government to establish a Commonwealth regional office, to be located in a new building within the electorate. The centre would handle all Commonwealth matters within the region. It could have incorporated in it facilities for data transmission to Melbourne and elsewhere to give public servants who travel large distances and waste many hours the opportunity of working close to their places of residence and, hand in hand with that, obtain the many advantages that such a move would achieve. New technology has given us the opportunity of working away from a central office and we would be fools not to make use of this golden opportunity. I can see a great potential for employment in the establishment of this regional centre. I have also spoken to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr John Brown) and he is extremely receptive to the suggestion. I will be making further representations on this matter and I trust I will be able to achieve results.

The second suggestion I make is the establishment of a high technology or innovative park within the Flinders electorate. I have already spoken to many within the high-tech area and all are enthusiastic about the establishment of such a park. I have spoken to people at the Chisholm Institute of Technology regarding the setting up of computer links and the many facilities that it, as a progressive institute, can supply. It is extremely enthusiastic and is already investigating the setting up of facilities on the Frankston campus. I have also spoken to members of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones). Again , all are enthusiastic. As the chairman of the Caucus sub-committee on science and technology, my position on high-tech industry is well known. We have a great opportunity to set up in Flinders, an industry with a future. The peninsula has the possibility of becoming the high-tech centre of Australia.

We are blessed by being in an area which has not been spoiled and which is relatively unpolluted. The areas of employment I have suggested will not affect the magnificent environment in which we live. I am also a member of the Caucus tourism committee. This is another great area for expansion. Tourism in the Flinders electorate has not reached anywhere near its true potential. I trust that these suggestions will help alleviate the problem of unemployment within Flinders, and I will pursue them to achieve greater opportunities for employment for all within the beautiful electorate of Flinders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw to the attention of the House and the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) a serious issue concerning the Australian Postal Commission. I did notify the Minister that I would be speaking. This matter concerns the mail bag and mail depot problem which has emerged in Sydney over the past two weeks. This is my first opportunity to speak on the matter as it is the first adjournment debate we have had since then. I refer to the practice of Australia Post dropping mail bags in thousands of places around Australia to assist the postman in his mail deliveries. These places include shops, houses and hotels. Until a Mr Newby, whose $15,000 cheque was stolen from a mail bag initially left in the London Tavern in Paddington, in desperation spoke to the media and to the proprietors of that tavern, in an attempt to recover that money, probably the great majority of Australians, and that includes me, were unaware of this Australia Post system.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that as the practice has been in place for many years but remains generally unknown to Australians it must have been a reasonable system. As succeeding non-Labor and Labor governments have not challenged the system, I will therefore speak in a non-party political way. I urge the Minister to investigate the matter to ensure the efficiency and security of the mail system and the good public image of Australia Post.

I note that the Minister was reported in the media earlier this week as expressing concern and calling for a report on the practice. However, what may have been a reasonably acceptable informal arrangement in the past has been shown by the Newby and London Tavern incident to be not acceptable any more and raises very serious questions about Australia Post's management procedures, its efficiency and the security of the nation's mail. The first of these questions concerns the general procedure to guarantee the efficiency and security of the mail services. The various newspaper and electronic media reports of this incident reveal that Australia Post at no stage contacted the London Tavern proprietors, in the four years that they have been the proprietors, about the procedure of dropping this bag. Since that incident Australia Post has not contacted these people to clarify or formalise the arrangements. It did not notify them after the theft that the depot was being transferred. It did not notify them that the mail bag was stolen or even thank them for four years of honorary assistance.

The whole system is too haphazard. Although I note the gradual change to lockable deposit areas in public mail boxes I urge the Minister, after his consideration of the report he is to receive from Australia Post, to ensure the following: Firstly, that the installation of secure lockable depots is accelerated; secondly, that existing informal depot procedures are improved from the point of view of the security of the mail and that satisfactory, clear and more formal arrangements are made with the non-Australia Post people who generously provide depot assistance; thirdly, that reporting procedures for theft are heightened so that people like Mr Newby or the London Tavern operators are officially advised; and, fourthly, that postmen must report all thefts.

That brings me to the final point, the security of the nation's mail. In reporting this incident, various Australia Post people have made the following contradictory points about mailbag theft. First, quite a lot of mail bags are stolen. That was stated by one spokesperson. The second is that only five bags have been stolen in New South Wales in the past 18 months. The third point is that two or three bags have already been stolen in the eastern suburbs of Sydney alone in the first four months of this year. The total for the Sydney area or for New South Wales as a whole is considerable. This theft, together with the increasingly long delays in mail deliveries-I have received plenty of complaints that it is taking four to six weeks for mail to get from Sydney to Canberra or Brisbane, particularly with the Leightonfield mail exchange problem-means that the good public image of Australia Post is now at risk. I urge the Minister not to be mollified by a superficial, all-is-well report from Australia Post but to ensure that the whole procedure is tightened and improved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to comment on the practice of orthomolecular medicine and in particular refer to the operations of an organisation known as Clinical Assays Pty Limited of Sydney. Clinical Assays came to my attention recently when a constituent visited my office. My constitutent is an invalid pensioner who had taken out private medical insurance but was faced with a bill from Clinical Assays of over $700, a bill which his fund would not pay. His fund, the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Limited, has advised me that his claim was refused by the Commonwealth Department of Health and suggested that I should discuss the matter further with the Department. I chose to discuss it instead with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). I was advised by him that the matter of non-payment of medical benefits in this case had been investigated by the Department once and then reconsidered. Both investigations confirmed that medical benefits would not be payable because of the position of orthomolecular medicine. I was naturally interested in orthomolecular medicine because my constituent, a pensioner who had nevertheless insured himself privately to provide cover, had been placed in a position where he was faced with a bill for over $700, a bill which his insurer would not pay.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been advised that orthomolecular medicine has as its basis the theory that many psychiatric and organic disorders affecting the central nervous system are the result of excessive or deficient intake of heavy minerals and vitamins, allergic cerebral conditions or manifestations of autoimmune disease. Numerous and costly pathology tests which may range up to $700 per patient are involved, including estimations of metals and vitamins, tests for allegines, detection of tissue anti-bodies and white cell function tests. Some practitioners of orthomolecular medicine have similar tests carried out on all members of the patient's family, apparently to ascertain whether there are familial or hereditary factors involved.

Representatives of the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists, the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia, and the Royal Australasian College of Physicians met on 8 October 1980 and came to the unanimous conclusion that orthomolecular medicine had no status in the practice of medicine or psychiatry. Its clinical role was unproven and the pathology tests could not be justified for the rational practice of internal medicine or psychiatry. I point out at this stage that the tests carried out on my constituent and his wife by Clinical Assays occurred in May 1983 and that the determination by the royal medical colleges took place in October 1980. It appears, therefore, that my constituent, believing himself to be fully covered, was either wrongly referred by his doctor, poorly advised by his fund or poorly advised by Clinical Assays. He assures me that at no time was he advised by his fund or his doctor or Clinical Assays that he would not be covered for the expense involved in these tests prior to taking them. The only indication he had that he would not be covered was when he received the account from Clinical Assays.

My constituent is in no position to pay this account and naturally I am in no position to advise him about payment or non-payment. I can only advise the House that debt collectors sent by Clinical Assays have been calling on my pensioner constituent, and that so far they have come away empty handed. I regard it as an absolute scandal that someone in his position should have been let down so badly by people supposedly involved in his care and certainly well paid for assuming that role. In my view the responsibility in this matter lies either with the fund, which did not inform him of his position, the referring doctor, who again did not inform him of his position, or Clinical Assays, who did not inform of his position before the tests. In my view-and I expect it to continue to be the view of my constituent-they can sort out the matter of payment among themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take a few moments of the House's time tonight to place on record a tribute to the Hon. Lindsay North who was buried today. He was a member of the Legislative Council in New South Wales for many years and was a great Labor man. He was very much respected by this Party, by the Labor movement in New South Wales and by the trade union movement in that State. He was a member of the Australian Council of Trade Unions Executive for some time in his career. He began his union career as an organiser with the Australian Textile Workers Union in 1943 and rose to the position of Secretary of that union. At one stage Lindsay organised my mother into that union when she worked at the Australian Woollen Mill in Marrickville, in 1944, as a weaver. Lindsay never forgot the area from where he came and never forgot that one of the greatest roles in life was to work for the advancement of working men and women. In those days the textile industry was the largest single employer of women industry of any industry in Australia. Lindsay was in the forefront of achieving equal pay for those people. Trades people in that industry, whether men or women, did well because of the organisation of the Textile Workers Union.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, Lindsay was a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council for a number of years and worked to put the voice of the union movement into that Parliament on behalf of the people of his union and the people of New South Wales. He was a returning officer of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party and a returning officer for the Australian Council of Trade Unions for some 25 years. He was the one person who participated in both union and political ballots in this country over two decades whose decisions, as a returning officer, were never challenged by anyone. I think that is a great tribute to Lindsay North's impartiality. On behalf of both sides of the Parliament and, indeed, the Labor movement in New South Wales and Australia as a whole, I offer our condolences to his wife Dorothy and her family for the tragic loss of Lindsay. I am sure his loss will be felt by all of us, a loss to all.
