SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My purpose in speaking is to respond to the matter raised by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) this evening. It involves the activities of a certain Paul Robert Neuman and his self-styled Order of the White Cross. Mr Neuman not only claims to be a Lord of the Knights of the White Cross but also claims to have established an independent sovereign state of Aeterna Lucina on a property near Cooma. His operation appears to be to persuade the naive that it is possible to migrate to Australia as citizens of this so-called state. He appears to have had some initial success. There is considerable evidence that Neuman has knowingly and quite deliberately sought to circumvent our immigration laws and procedures, and has sought to mislead people in West Germany into believing that he, Neuman, had authority to arrange their immigration to Australia and to grant them citizenship in his so-called sovereign independent state.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that the stated aim of Neuman's so-called order is to promote the divine laws of God. However, Neuman claims that it has no religious or political affiliation. The alleged principles of the organisation are the defence and protection of life, promotion of peace, defence of endangered nature and faith in the divine laws of God. Mr Neuman claims that it is his intention to establish a pollution-free subsistence agricultural and trading community called Vitama. Neuman first attempted to establish himself in the Byron Bay area but ran into trouble with the local authorities. By late 1981 he had moved his activities to the new location near Cooma where he appears to have purchased two parcels of undeveloped land at the reported price of $24 an acre. To many people in West Germany where Neuman has been seeking his recruits among people concerned with issues of industrial pollution and nuclear proliferation, this community may well have appeared to be attractive.

Neuman's claims were given unnecessary and inadvertent credibility by the previous Government. A petition to the Parliament in which Neuman claimed that Aeterna Lucina, and its establishment Vitama, was an independent state within Australia was lodged on 10 October 1978. The petition was presented to the House by the then Leader of the National Party and Deputy Prime Minister of Australia. Important here is the fact that there was no subsequent denial of Neuman's claims by the then Government. He represented to his naive clients that the former Australian Government had afforded at least de facto recognition to his independent so-called state and was thereby helped to convince prospective settlers of his bona fides.

I am informed that Neuman and the Order of the White Cross first came to the notice of my Department late in 1982 when he lodged an application for one of his recruits to enter Australia as an occupational trainee. That application was rejected. In April 1983 he applied for several persons to enter as temporary residents. At about this time my Department's office in West Germany received inquiries from prospective recruits to the Order of the White Cross claiming that Neuman was offering Australian citizenship and migration facilities. Letters from the Order to these recruits contained phrases such as 'your application will then be checked and as soon as you have received your citizenship certificate and purchased your property for which you will receive a regular ownership certificate the Order can then guarantee for your entry so that you can settle unencumbered in Aeterna Lucina' and 'we need all types of tradesman and other skilled people. For these people we will undertake to give a guarantee for their migration'.

Our office responded by pointing out that the Australian Government alone had these responsibilities and urged the inquirers to approach the organisation with the utmost caution. The letter was a timely warning to people who may have been in the process of being duped by Neuman's activities. That letter came to Neuman 's attention. It seems that one result was that he advised his potential recruits not to approach the Australian authorities in Bonn and he actually had the gall to complain to several Opposition members.

Neuman's community of Vitama seemed to be capable of making him a lot of money. It appears that the land he bought around Cooma cost him $24 an acre and his disillusioned recruits paid as much as $3,600 for a quarter-acre block plus 10 per cent turnover tax and a $50 registration fee. These fees have been paid to Neuman and his Order, not to the New South Wales authorities. The land is mortgaged and Neuman is still seeking approval for multiple occupancy title. The most his recuits could ever hope for in the way of title to the land is a leasehold under the New South Wales multiple occupancy guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. If no other Minister rises he may continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Neuman's claims have misled several families to join the Order of the White Cross and to come to Australia on visitors visas. Three of these families are now in Cooma. As visitors to Australia they are not entitled to work. In interviews with officers of my Department they have claimed that they came to Australia solely on the basis of misrepresentations by Neuman and his Order and are considering taking legal action to recover their investment. I accept that if the claims they have put forward against Neuman are established, the situation in which they have found themselves is most distressing indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: Neuman is aware that the Australian Government would not let him bring his overeas recruits to Australia. Applications lodged in 1982 and 1983 had been refused and he was counselled by officers of my Department in April 1983. It is significant that he accepted the Government's decisions in these cases and did not defend his claim to independence. But he continues to negotiate his multiple occupancy plans with the New South Wales authorities while claiming independence from Australia. He advised his recruits not to approach the officers of my Department. When they sought entry to Australia they made no reference to their entanglement with the Order of the White Cross. One of the families which is in Cooma at present has since admitted that it deliberately withheld this information on Neuman's advice. Neuman has evidently set out to deceive the former Government and this Government and, to the extent that was necessary, his gullible recruits.

I am considering the options that may be available. There are others who have been involved with the Order who need to be interviewed. Documents provided by the disillusioned recruits in Cooma need to be examined. Decisions need to be taken on questions such as whether Neuman has breached the provisions of the Migration Act. I have asked my colleague the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to review the papers and to determine whether any Federal action can be brought against Neuman. I have also asked the Attorney-General to consider referring the matter to the New South Wales authorities to determine whether any New South Wales laws have been broken. But irrespective of the extent to which he can be charged under Australian law, I am most determined that Neuman's nefarious activities will be publicly exposed in the Australian and international community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 11.08 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the United Nations Charter allow military action by the peace-keeping force only (a) by request of the Security Council (b) by regional arrangements or agencies, if authorised by the Security Council or (c) in self-defence against armed attack.
(2) Did these conditions authorise armed attacks on Grenada in 1983 by neighbouring countries, including the United States.

(3) Was there any substance, established by a UN forum or organ, in the claim that the military action was not intervention in the internal affairs of a sovereign nation but in response to the appeal of the legal government to release hostages or besieged citizens.

(4) What steps will Australia take to strengthen the UN so that (a) it has a permanent peace-keeping force able to intervene before violence breaks out in support of universal human rights, self-determination and international law generally, (b) conciliation and/or arbitration are enforceable where threats to the peace or grave international disputes occur and (c) the veto is abandoned in favour of moves towards a democratically representative UN Assembly with guaranteed revenue sources.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to state with certainty what kinds of peace-keeping operations and military action the United Nations Charter does, and does not, allow, although of course it does provide for such action in the cases mentioned in the question. The practice of States sometimes has gone beyond the apparent original intention of the drafters of the Charter. The term 'peacekeeping force' , for example, appears nowhere in the Charter, and there is a considerable degree of academic discussion, and controversy among States, as to the basis in Charter and customary law for some instances of collective military action and so-called 'peacekeeping operations' by States. On some occasions (e.g. in the Commonwealth) operations relating to peacekeeping have been conducted outside the United Nations.

(2) Various legal bases were given by members of the multi-national force which intervened in Grenada in 1983 as the authority for their action. Some of these referred specifically to the United Nations Charter, and I refer the honourable member to the various views expressed in the Security Council debate on Grenada on 27 October 1983.

(3) No United Nations body, as far as I am aware, has made a formal pronouncement in relation to the argument that the military action was '. . . in response to the appeal of the legal government to release hostages or besieged citizens.'

(4) Under the Charter of the United Nations, the Security Council has primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security. Australia supports proposals to make the Council a more effective instrument for discharging this responsibility, in accordance with the provisions of the Charter and in the interests of its member States. Australia is a candidate for the election to the Council for a two-year term in 1985-86, and if elected will join actively in efforts to improve the Council's work in regard to the specific settlement of disputes and action with respect to threats to the peace, breaches of the peace and acts of aggression. Initiatives to these ends, however, must be capable of gaining the support of the permanent members of the Security Council, each of which has the power of veto over all decisions of the Council other than those dealing with procedural matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce , upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 978 (Hansard, 29 February 1984, page 245) referring to the definition and use of 'fast track' anti-dumping action, can the fast track system also be used in relation to horticultural products from New Zealand.
(2) To which other countries and products does it apply.
(3) Is it possible to give a general definition and criteria for the fast track action; if so, what is it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1 and 2. As indicated in my answer to question No. 978 (Hansard 29 February 1984, page 245) special procedures have been introduced to expedite investigation of dumping complaints against steel imports. These procedures do not apply to other products.
The dumping of goods in Australia, regardless the commodity, is of a major concern to this government.

As a demonstration of that concern, shortly after the government came to office it directed an immediate review of both the legislation and the procedures for investigating dumping and subsidisation complaints.
On 7 November last year, as a result of that review, I announced that the investigation of all dumping and subsidisation complaints was to be speeded up.

Unless there are exceptional or complex circumstances a preliminary finding of whether injurious dumping or subsidisation exists will be reached within 45 days of the complaint being accepted by the department. If the preliminary finding is positive the investigation will then be finalised within a further 120 days.
At the preliminary finding stage, if a threat of injury from future dumped or subsidised imports is apparent, provisional action against these imports can be taken.
These procedures which will ensure a speedy resolution of dumping or subsidisation complaints will apply to all complaints regardless the commodity or the source of the goods.

In addition, a special liaison committee comprising officers from the Departments of Trade, Primary Industry and Industry & Commerce was established in 1982 to monitor clearances of certain horticultural products imported from New Zealand. It is envisaged that this committee would, in the same way as the Steel Industry Authority, provide early warning of possible injurious dumping or subsidisation of these products.

3. The expedition of investigation of dumping complaints against steel imports is possible as a result of the detailed and continuous monitoring of overseas and domestic steel prices by the Steel Industry Authority. The immediate availability of this information will facilitate the reaching of a preliminary finding in respect of a dumping complaint against steel imports ahead of the 45 days which apply in the case of other complaints.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 27 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many employees have been stood down or dismissed as a result of industrial action on the new Parliament House site.
(2) What claims have been made by unions in the present dispute.

(3) What additional payments, allowances and other entitlements have employees on the new Parliament House site received over and above normal awards and conditions of service for working on a building site.
(4) What is the estimated additional cost to the completed building of acceding to the union demands.
(5) To what extent has industrial action delayed the time-table for construction of the building.

(6) Are there any additional costs associated with resuming work at the conclusion of the industrial action and maintaining the present time-table for completion of the building; if so, what are the estimated costs.
(7) How many contractors are employed by the Parliament House Construction Authority on the new Parliament House.
(8) To what extent is the work to be completed by these contractors impeded by the present industrial campaign in support of a severance pay claim, and the consequent pickets on the site.
(9) What provisions are made in contracts with contractors and sub-contractors for dislocation resulting from industrial action.
(10) Are contractors and sub-contractors suffering financially as a result of the industrial action; if so, what is the estimated extent of financial damage in each case.

(11) Will the viability of any contractors and sub-contractors to complete contracts be affected; if so, what action will be taken by the Parliament House Construction Authority to ensure their continued viability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Approximately 400 employees were involved in direct industrial action and were subsequently dismissed. An additional 150 employees were stood down by contractors who also relocated other employees to jobs on other sites.

(2) The major claims made by the unions in the present dispute include a claim for severance pay of six weeks for every twelve months worked on the site and an increase in the site allowance of up to $2 per hour, and the implementation of a non-contributory superannuation scheme.

(3) Workers on the site are paid in accordance with relevant awards in the building industry. In addition to the award, workers receive a $1.12 1/2 site allowance approved by the Arbitration Commission.
(4) The estimated present day additional building cost of acceding to the union demands is approximately $20m. This is calculated according to a breakdown of the three issues concerned; namely:
(i) Site Allowance Increase-0.875 cents (per hour) x 38 hours = $33 per week per worker
(ii) Severance Pay Costs-(based on an average weekly wage of $400) 6 weeks/52 weeks x $400 per week average = $46 per week per worker
(iii) Non-Contributory Superannuation Costs-$10 per week contribution plus $1 per week administration = $11 per week per worker

Additional Weekly Cost of meeting demands = $90 per week. Based on an average of 1200 workers on the site for the remaining 3 1/2 years of the project the total additional cost is calculated as: $90 per week x 52 weeks/year x 3 1/2 years x 1200 = $19.656m.

(5) It is difficult to estimate the extent of time delay caused by the dispute as this is dependent on the ultimate length of the dispute. It is estimated that following the resumption of work it is likely to be at least a further two months to restore the labour force to pre dispute levels.

(6) There will be additional costs associated with the resumption of work on the site. At this stage it is difficult to estimate the extent of these costs until the date for the resumption of work is known and the longer term availability of labour established.
(7) The Parliament House Construction Authority currently employs 47 site contractors.

(8) As a result of the current industrial dispute, all work on the site has ceased. Offsite work such as granite quarrying, cutting and finishing, precast panel manufacture, mechanical and electrical component manufacture and lifts manufacture is proceeding.
(9) Current contracts do not contain provisions for reimbursement of costs resulting from industrial action. However, provisions are made for the granting of extensions of time.

(10) It is inevitable that contractors and sub-contractors are incurring financial costs as a result of the dispute; however, the extent of financial damage cannot be assessed until the dispute is resolved.
(11) Several contractors are claiming that their viability is at risk as a result of the dispute. The implications of these claims are being considered but no undertakings can be given at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reeves Mr J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy , upon notice, on 28 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government maintain a stockpile of uranium oxide at Jabiru, Northern Territory; if so (a) where at Jabiru is the stockpile located, (b) what quantity of uranium oxide is in the stockpile, (c) who is able to use the uranium oxide, (d) what, if any, conditions are applied to the use of the uranium oxide and (e) what plans, if any, does the Government have for the stockpile.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth maintains a stockpile of uranium concentrate which was accumulated from Rum Jungle production not committed under contract.
(a) The bulk of the Commonwealth uranium stockpile is currently securely stored in the Ranger project area within the Ranger concentrate storage facility at Jabiru East in the Northern Territory.
(b) The total quantity of the Commonwealth stockpile including material held at Lucas Heights, is some 2,260 short tons U308.

(c), (d) and (e) The use and disposition of the stockpile is a matter for the Commonwealth to decide. The Commonwealth at present has no proposals before it in relation to the use of the stockpile and has yet to address this question.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Resources and Energy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) to (f) Since the 1983 general election the Department of Resources and Energy has reviewed its staff selection procedures with a view to effecting the Government's equal employment opportunities principles. An ongoing assessment is made of applicants for advertised vacancies to determine if there are any apparent barriers to the recruitment and promotion of women in the Department. The Department has placed a high priority on equal opportunity matters and will take further action once the proposed guidelines are released. There is frequent contact with Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau.
(2) There are no clearly identifiable costs attributable to equal opportunity activities in the Department.
